questions.text: An outbreak of Staphylococcal infection involving the umbilical cords of seven newborn babies was reported in the nursery of a well-known hospital. A bacteriological survey reveals that two nurses have a large number of Staphylococcus aureus in their nasopharynx. What test should be performed to determine whether these nurses may have been responsible for the outbreak?

choices.text: Nasopharyngeal culture on mannitol salt agar

questions.solution:
Option A: Bacteriophage typing

  • Bacteriophage typing should be performed to determine whether these nurses may have been responsible for the outbreak.
  • It is a method for epidemiological typing of Staphylococcus aureus strains.
  • Staphylococcus is a facultative anaerobe.
  • The optimum pH for growth is 7.4 - 7.6, and the optimum temperature is 37°C.
  • Staph aureus produces golden yellow pigment, which is maximum at 22°C.
  • Strains of Staphylococcus aureus can be distinguished by their patterns of lysis by an internationally recognized set of 23 standard typing phages.
  • The phage-type of the strain is expressed by the designations of all the phages that lyse it.
  • Phage types 80/81 are known to cause hospital infections throughout the world.

Option B: Coagulase testing

  • To differentiate Staphylococcus from other species of Staphylococci known as CONS (Coagulase-negative Staphylococci).
  • Coagulase is a virulence factor of Staphylococcus aureus. Hence it is used for the identification of coagulase-positive Staph. Aureus.

Option C: Nasopharyngeal culture on mannitol salt agar

  • Nasopharyngeal culture on mannitol salt agar is performed for detection of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus from nasopharyngeal specimens.
  • It is known as both selective and differential growth media at the same time because it can select organisms that can live in areas of high salt concentration.

Option D: Protein A typing

  • Protein A is an important virulent factor found in the cell wall of the aureus.
  • It is used in certain tests to identify the type of Staphylococci because it is not produced by coagulase-negative staphylococci.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with a unilateral erythematous ulcerative lesion over left the nipple. Histopathology of the lesion showed large cells with clear cytoplasm and atypical nucleoli located between normal keratinocytes of the nipple epidermis. Which of the following is the best next step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Breast conservative therapy (BCT)

  • Paget's disease accounts for 1% or less of breast malignancies. It is characterized by nipple erythema and irritation and may progress to crusting and ulceration. The condition may also spread outward from the nipple onto the areola and surrounding breast skin.
  • The differential diagnosis includes eczema, contact dermatitis, and post-radiation dermatitis.
  • A biopsy should be performed, and a specimen containing Paget cells (large cells with clear cytoplasm and atypical nucleoli) located between normal keratinocytes of the nipple epidermis confirms the diagnosis. Paget cells spread into the lactiferous sinuses under the nipple and upward to invade the overlying epidermis of the nipple.
  • Paget cells do not invade the dermal basement membrane and are categorized as carcinoma in situ.
  • More than 95% of patients have underlying breast carcinoma.
  • Paget's disease may be accompanied by a palpable mass in slightly more than 50% of patients.
  • Treatment involves mastectomy with axillary staging or wide local excision of the nipple and areola (breast conservative therapy) to achieve clear margins, axillary staging, and radiation therapy. For patients with BCT, surgery should include excision of the full nipple-areola complex with a cone of underlying retro areolar tissue and complete excision of any tissue with abnormal radiologic findings.

Option A: Warm compresses and antibiotics

  • Mastitis presents with pain, redness, and swelling in breastfeeding women. It can be unilateral or bilateral, although unilateral is more common.
  • Warm compresses are advised for mastitis, and antibiotics are considered for patients with mastitis complicated into breast abscesses.

Option B: Topical steroids

  • Eczema may also present with irritation and erythema and may also progress to ulceration or crusting. However, as it is an autoimmune condition, histopathology findings would only show inflammatory infiltrates, and Paget cells will be absent.
  • Also, eczema commonly affects the extensor surfaces of the body.
  • Topical steroids are the first-line treatment for eczema.

Option D: Observation and reassurance

  • Fibrocystic breast disease is related to the menstrual cycle. It leads to the development of fluid-filled round or oval sacs and more prominent scar-like tissue, making breasts feel tender and lumpy.
  • It does not usually need treatment, and only observation and reassurance to the patient are sufficient. However, sometimes puncturing and draining the cyst can relieve symptoms.

questions.text: A group of neurologists is studying signal-transmitting cells of the nervous system. They concluded that a myelin sheath covers neurons. Loss of myelin can occur due to direct damage to the myelin sheath or indirectly through a primarily genetic disorder or attack during inflammation or toxic exposure. Which of the following cells form myelin in CNS?
questions.solution:
Option A: Oligodendrocytes

  • The Glial cells are classified into two types: macroglia and microglia.
  • Astrocytes and oligodendrocytes are macroglia.
  • Astrocytes are central nervous system-supporting cells that provide a variety of roles, such as structural support, insulating receptive surfaces, and buffering the extracellular compartment.
  • Oligodendrocytes: CNS nerve myelination; one oligodendrocyte myelinates several neurons (1:20).
  • In the CNS, oligodendrocytes generate the myelin sheath.
  • Oligodendrocytes are the primary CNS-supporting cells.
  • Each oligodendrocyte may myelinate up to 30 CNS axons.
  • As a result, oligodendrocytes are the most common kind of glial cell in white matter.
  • Derived from neuroectoderm, it shows on histology slides as a 'fried egg.'
  • Multiple sclerosis, leukodystrophies, and multifocal leukoencephalopathy can all cause indirect myelin sheath damage.

Option B: Schwann cells

  • The Myelin sheath of the peripheral nerves is formed by the Schwann cells.

Option C: Microglia

  • Microglia are neuronal support cells (Neuroglia) found in the central nervous systems of invertebrates and vertebrates that predominantly operate as immune cells.
  • Microglia, like peripheral macrophages, are the major immune cells of the central nervous system.
  • They do not myelinate neurons in any way.

Option D: Astrocytes

  • Astrocytes are supporting cells within the central nervous system that have numerous functions, including providing structural support, insulating receptive surfaces, and buffering the extracellular compartment.
  • These are the most common glial cells in CNS but do not form the myelin sheath, so this answer is wrong.

questions.text: A 6-month-old male child presents to the clinic accompanied by his mother with a rash, as shown in the picture below. The rash started appearing on his trunk this morning, and the mother believes it is spreading to his arms and legs. He has a history of high-grade fever and a seizure three days back. At that time, his work-up was normal, and he was sent home with acetaminophen and fluids. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Roseola

  • Lack of symptoms during the febrile phase and the appearance of the eruption as the fever subsides are suggestive of Roseola.
  • The organism involved in the pathogenesis is the Human herpes virus 6 (HHV-6).
  • Manifests as a rosy rash on the trunk & neck after three days of high fevers; it may later spread to the arms, face, and legs.
  • The rash usually fades within two days.
  • It is a self-limited disease requiring no treatment.

Option A: Fixed Drug Eruption

  • Fixed: As lesions always occur at the same site.
  • Drug: As it Occurs after consumption of drugs like:
    • NSAIDS
    • Tetracycline
    • Cotrimoxazole
  • Eruptions
    • Initially, the patient develops erythematous lesions.
    • Later, these heal with Hyperpigmentation.

Option B: Erythema infectiosum/5th Disease

  • Caused by Human Parvovirus B19.
  • SLAPPED CHEEK APPEARANCE.

Option C: Measles (RUBEOLA)

  • The maculopapular rash begins at the hairline, then involves the face and upper neck. Later involves extremities.
  • Fever, running nose, and congested eyes.
  • Infectivity period → 4 days Before ←RASH → 5 Days after.
  • Most characteristic Feature → Koplik Spots

questions.text: A 10-day newborn is brought to the clinic by his father due to evaluation of a blue-grey patch on her buttocks and lower back. The diameter of the patch is almost 6 cm with an irregular shape, unclear edges, and normal skin texture. She is otherwise healthy and has no dysmorphic features. Which is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D:Mongolian spot

  • Congenital dermal melanocytosis (Mongolian spots) are blue-gray pigmented macule (may also be green or brown) that are formed commonly on the back, buttocks, flanks, and shoulders.

  • Benign, flat, and congenital birthmark.
  • The most common color is blue, although they can be blue-gray, blue-black, or deep brown.
  • Equally predisposed Male and female infants.
  • Underlying Pathophysiology: Melanocytes migrating from the neural crest to the epidermis during development become entrapped in the dermis.
  • Prognosis: usually resolves spontaneously during childhood (typically by the age of 10 years).
  • It is important to document the diagnosis of Mongolian spots, as they may resemble bruises and lead to false suspicions of child abuse.

Option A: Blue Nevus

  • Benign skin lesion that is four times more common in children, typically affecting the extremities and face.
  • Small, slightly elevated, and blue-black lesions. However, blue-black papules and nodules that are new or growing must be evaluated to rule out nodular melanoma.

Option B: Milia neonatorum

  • Milia neonatorum is tiny epidermal papules caused by the build up of keratin and sebaceous secretions.
  • Clinical features: pinhead-sized lesions located on the face/trunk.
  • Treatment: not necessary

Option C: Infantile hemangioma

  • Strawberry, capillary, or cavernous hemangioma
  • Benign endothelial proliferation that represents the most common tumor in infancy.
  • Most commonly on head and neck areas.
  • Superficial ones presents as bright red-colored plaque.
  • Deep ones present as a soft dermal or subcutaneous nodule with a bluish-purple color.
  • More than 90% of untreated hemangiomas involute, that is, attain maximal regression by 9 years of age.
  • Up to 30% of hemangiomas leave post involution changes, including hypopigmentation, scarring, telangiectasia, and fibrofatty tissue.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the office with a painful non-indurated ulcer on the glans penis for the last 5 days. He has had a history of unprotected sexual intercourse with multiple partners in the last six months. On physical examination, undermined sloughed edges of margins were noted. The most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Option B: Haemophilus ducreyi

This sexually active male with a history of unprotected sex with multiple partners has developed a painful non-indurated ulcer on the glans penis with undermined sloughed edges of margins. The most probable diagnosis is Chancroid.

  • Haemophilus ducreyi is the causative organism.
  • It is a highly contagious but curable disease.
Characteristic Chancroid
Primary lesion Pustule
Number of lesions Multiple
Diameter Variable
Edges Undermined Ragged
Depth Excavated
Base Purulent Dirty grey Base
Induration not indurated
Lymphadenopathy Large inflamed bubo
  • Tender, often unilateral, regional lymphadenopathy develops in approximately 50% of infected individuals.
  • Antibiotic treatment should be initiated for individuals with either a confirmed or presumed diagnosis of Chancroid.
  • Untreated individuals run the risk of progressing to painful regional lymphadenitis.

Option A: Treponema Pallidum

  • Causes primary syphilis
Characteristic Syphilis
Primary lesion Papule
Number of lesions Usually 1
Diameter 5-15 mm
Edges Sharply demarcated elevated
Depth Superficial or deep
Base Smooth, non-purulent, Covered with serous exudate
Induration Buttonhole
Lymphadenopathy Shotty lymph nodes

Option C: Herpes

Characteristic Herpes
Primary lesion Vesicle
Number of lesions Multiple
Diameter 1-2 mm
Edges Erythematous Polycyclic
Depth Superficial
Base Erythematous
Induration None
Lymphadenopathy Palpable tender

Option D: Chlamydia

  • Chlamydia trachomatis serotypes L1 -L3 cause Lympho granuloma venereum
Characteristic LGV
Primary lesion Papule, vesicle pustule
Number of lesions Single
Diameter 2-10 mm
Edges Elevated Round or oval
Depth Superficial Or deep
Base Variable
Induration not indurated
Lymphadenopathy Buboes - inflammatory

questions.text: A mother brings her 4-year-old boy to the medicine outpatient department with a complaint of fever for 5 days. On examination, the child has red eyes. The patient also had dry as well as cracked lips. The child was also having rashes on his hands and feet. The doctor also noticed edema on his soles and palms and had unilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. The patient also had a red tongue. The doctor suggested radiological imaging of coronary arteries to confirm the suspected vasculitis. Closely observe the image and analyze the symptoms mentioned above. Choose the correct statement regarding the disease

choices.text: IV immunoglobulin is used in treatment

questions.solution:
Option C: IV immunoglobulin is used in the treatment

  • The image show child having a strawberry tongue

Kawasaki disease:

  • Also known as "mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome."
  • Most common vasculitis in children aged less than 4 years.
  • It is a Necrotizing Vasculitis involving Medium-sized vessels, most commonly the Coronary arteries.
  • Diagnostic Criteria for Kawasaki Disease:
  • Fever lasting for at least 5 days + at least 4 out of 5 characteristic symptoms should be present:
    • Conjunctivitis (bilateral)
    • Rash, primary truncal
    • Asymmetric cervical lymphadenitis
    • Crusting of lips, fissuring of mouth and oropharyngeal erythema
    • Oedema & erythema of palms & soles
    • Adenopathy
    • Mucosal involvement: Strawberry tongue
  • Management:
    • High dose Aspirin and IV immunoglobin.
    • Steroids are contraindicated (danger of vessel rupture).
    • Add Warfarin if there is a high risk of thrombosis (very high platelet count).

Option A:  Aspirin is contraindicated in this disease

  • Aspirin is an NSAID. Also known as acetylsalicylic acid.
  • It is used to treat inflammation, minor aches/pain and fever.
  • Aspirin is given with IV Immunoglobin in Kawasaki to prevent abnormalities in the coronary artery.
  • It prevents the development of Myocardial infarction in a patient with Kawasaki disease.
  • Aspirin is contraindicated in bleeding disorders and patients under 16 years except in Kawasaki disease.

Option B:  Bilateral purulent conjunctivitis is present

  • Purulent conjunctivitis is a violently severe conjunctival infection.
  • The patient is presented with profuse pus (white or coloured), eye pain/itch/puffiness and a clear propensity for corneal involvement.
  • Purulent conjunctivitis is most commonly caused by N. gonorrhoea and Neisseria meningitidis
  • The patients have bulbar congestion in Kawasaki Disease.
  • There is an Absence of any discharge.

Option D: Lymphadenopathy is rare

  • Lymphadenopathy means swelling of lymph nodes.
  • Swelling of lymph nodes occurs due to
    • Infections,
    • Autoimmune diseases,
    • Malignancies
    • Drug reactions.
  • The patients develop  Unilateral cervical lymphadenopathy with fever in the initial part of Kawasaki Disease.
  • Kawasaki illness also causes swelling in the glands (lymph nodes) and mucous membranes within the mouth, nose, eyes, and throat.
  • Formerly referred to as mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents to the clinic with the complaint of lesions on his trunk for the past few days. Except for an upper respiratory tract infection three weeks ago, there is no other significant history. Lesions are non-itchy and non-painful. On examination, multiple erythematous, annular lesions with a collarette of scales at the periphery of the lesions are present on the trunk. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Multiple erythematous, annular lesions with a collarette of scales at the periphery of the lesions on the trunk suggest Pityriasis rosea.

Option C: Pityriasis rosea

  • Pityriasis rosea:
    Pityriasis rosea is an acute, self-limited, exanthematous skin disease characterized by the appearance of slightly inflammatory, oval, papulosquamous lesions on the trunk and proximal areas of the extremities.
  • In 50 to 90 percent of cases, the eruption begins with a "herald" or "mother" patch, a single round or oval, sharply delimited, pink or salmon-colored lesion on the chest, neck, or back.
  • The herald patch is usually 2 to 5 cm in diameter.
  • The lesion soon becomes scaly and begins to clear centrally, leaving the free edge of the cigarette paper-like scale directed toward the center.
  • This clinical finding is often described as a "collarette" of scale.
  • The eruption spreads centrifugally or from the top down over a few days.
  • Erythema gradually subsides, desquamation is completed, and the eruption fades, leaving few residual changes, except post-inflammatory dyspigmentation.
  • In most cases, the papules and plaques resolve in four to six weeks; occasionally, the disease will persist for several months.

Option A: Lichen planus

  • Lichen planus presents with Purple, Polygonal, and Pruritic papules.
  • Lacy white markings are present.
  • Associated with mucous membrane lesions

Option B: Seborrheic dermatitis

  • Seborrheic dermatitis presents with central facial erythema with an overlying greasy, yellowish scale.

Option D: Tinea versicolor

  • Hyperpigmented or hypopigmented scaly patches on the trunk

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents to the Pediatric outpatient department with a painless nodule on the inner surface of his lower eyelid. Her mother reported that it started as a small lesion, progressively increasing in size over several weeks without any pain in the surrounding area. On physical examination, a lipogranulomatous inflammation is noted. Which of the following do you think is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Chalazion

  • It is a small swelling or lump on the eyelid which presents as a painless nodule due to obstruction of the sebaceous glands in the eyelid.
  • Obstruction of the Zeis or meibomian eyelid glands, due to which thickened secretions lead to blockage of glands, producing a granulomatous inflammatory response.
  • A patient can present with eyelid discomfort from swelling and even eyelid pain in cases of secondary infection.
  • Lipogranulomatous inflammation is usually present.
  • Diagnosis is mostly made clinically based on the eye exam finding of a painless eyelid nodule.
  • In case of recurrent chalazion or seborrheic blepharoconjunctivitis, rule out sebaceous cell carcinoma.
  • Incision and curettage are done from the conjunctival side.
  • Horizontal incisions are avoided to minimize damage to meibomian ducts.

Option A: Fungal infection

  • Fungal keratitis can occur suddenly from an eye injury or using a contact lens.
  • It can cause vision loss without treatment.
  • The risk of fungal infections is associated with an eye injury, eye surgery, chronic eye disease, contact lenses, fungal bloodstream infection, and immunocompromised people.
  • This patient does not present with features of fungal infection.

Option B: Tuberculosis

  • Ocular TB can also involve any part of the eye and can occur with or without evidence of systemic TB.
  • Tuberculosis and viral agents cause infection and associated inflammation but not lipogranulomatous inflammation.

Option D: Viral infection

  • Most viral infection causes conjunctivitis, which is highly contagious, usually due to adenovirus.
  • Symptoms include irritation, photophobia, and watery discharge.
  • There is no lipogranulomatous inflammation.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman is referred to the ophthalmology clinic by her primary care physician, complaining of deteriorating vision in her right eye that had started four months prior without accompanying pain. She was a known case of squamous cell carcinoma of the left lung. A detachment was seen in the lower part of the retina during her ophthalmoscopic examination. In addition, any plaques, tumor masses, and metastases were absent. She was then diagnosed with unilateral paraneoplastic exudative retinal detachment. Which of the following condition causes exudative retinal detachment?
questions.solution:
Option A: Toxemia of pregnancy

  • Pre eclampsia is defined as systolic blood pressure more than or equal to 140 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure more than or equal to 90 mm Hg or higher, on two occasions at least 4 hours apart in a previously normotensive patient.
  • In addition to this criterion, proteinuria of more than 0.3 gms in a 24-hour urine specimen or a PCR ratio of 0.3 or greater is required to diagnose preeclampsia.
  • The patient may present with retinal involvement as well.
  • Exudative retinal detachment can be found in 1-2% of the cases with preeclampsia/eclampsia.
  • Subretinal fluid accumulates in the space between the neurosensory retina and the underlying retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) due to leakage of vessels resulting in retinal detachment. Exudative retinal detachments have a convex configuration, no retinal breaks, and no holes or tears.

 

Underlying disease classification

Examples

Neoplastic

Choroidal melanoma

Choroidal metastasis

Choroidal haemangioma

Retinoblastoma

Inflammatory

Vogt-Koyanagi – Harada disease

Posterior scleritis

Sympathetic opthalmia

Infectious

Toxoplasmosis

Syphilis

Tuberculosis

Vascular

Coats disease

Malignant hypertension

Eclampsia or pre – eclampsia

Congenital

Morning glory syndrome

Optic nerve head pit

Coloboma

Nanophthalmos

 

Option B: Lattice Degeneration

  • Peripheral retinal degeneration comprises localized retinal thinning, overlying vitreous liquefaction, and marginal vitreoretinal adhesion.
  • Associated with atrophic retinal holes, retinal tears, and retinal detachments.
  • Patients are generally asymptomatic, and the lesions are usually an incidental finding of dilated ocular examination.
  • There can be blurriness in the distance due to myopia, commonly presented with lattice degeneration.
  • The sudden onset of floaters, flashes of light, peripheral field loss, or central vision loss may indicate the presence of retinal detachment.

Option C: CMV Retinitis

  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Retinitis is an acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS)-related opportunistic infection.
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis is an important ocular AIDS-associated illness. It is a full-thickness retinal infection that can lead to necrosis, retinal breaks and detachments, and blindness.
  • Most patients are without symptoms, but few may experience floaters, flashes and blind spots.

Option D: Diabetic retinopathy

  • Diabetic retinopathy can cause tractional retinal detachment or combined rhegmatogenous-tractional retinal detachment.
  • It does not lead to the development of exudative retinal detachment.
  • It has different stages depending on the severity.
  • Stage 1: background retinopathy
  • Stage 2: pre-proliferative retinopathy
  • Stage 3: proliferative retinopathy
  • Diabetic maculopathy

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy comes to the emergency room complaining of chest pain, palpitations and shortness of breath. ECG shows P wave is tall in lead II and upright in V1 along with right axis deviation. Based on the information provided, what appropriate auscultatory findings will be noted?
questions.solution:
Option D: All of the above:

  • The first heart sound (S1 ) is usually accentuated in the early stages of the disease and slightly delayed.
  • The pulmonic component of the second heart sound (P2 ) also is often accentuated with elevated PAPs, and the two components of the second heart sound (S2 ) are closely split.
  • The mitral valve's opening snap (OS) is most readily audible in expiration at, or just medial to, the cardiac apex.
  • This sound generally follows the sound of aortic valve closure (A2 ) by 0.05–0.12 s.
  • The time interval between A2 and OS varies inversely with the severity of the MS.
  • The OS is followed by a low-pitched, rumbling, diastolic murmur, heard best at the apex with the patient in the left lateral recumbent position; it is accentuated by mild exercise (e.g., a few rapid sit-ups) carried out just before auscultation.
  • In general, this murmur's duration correlates with the stenosis's severity in patients with preserved CO.
  • The S1 sound is initially narrow split and then heard as a single sound which then progresses to reverse splitting.
  • In patients with sinus rhythm, the murmur often reappears or becomes louder during atrial systole (presystolic accentuation).
  • Soft, grade I or II/VI systolic murmurs may be heard at or medial to the apex and signify mixed mitral valve disease with regurgitation.
  • Hepatomegaly, ankle oedema, ascites, and pleural effusion may occur in patients with MS and RV failure, particularly in the right pleural cavity.

Option A: Narrow split S1

  • In the initial stages of the disease, there is a narrow splitting of S1.

Option B: Single S1

  • In moderate cases, S1 becomes single.

Option C: Reverse split S1

  • In severe MS, there is often the reverse splitting of S1.

questions.text: Which of the following represents normal 'Y' descent in the JVP?

choices.text: Isovolumetric relaxation of the right ventricle

questions.solution:
Option C: Opening of the tricuspid valve

  • “y” wave indicates a fall of right atrial pressure due to the opening of the tricuspid valve leading to the ventricular filling.

Option A: Atrial diastole

  • P wave on ECG indicates the atrial diastole followed by atrial systole.

Option B: Closure of the tricuspid valve

  • Its closure produces the first heart sound, which is pronounced as Lub.

Option D: Isovolumetric relaxation of the right ventricle

  • It is masked under the QRS complex and does not appear on ECG.

questions.text: Which of the following organs have the maximum blood flow per 100 gm per min?
questions.solution:
Option C: Kidney

  • The kidneys have the highest blood flow (100ml/100 gm of tissue/min.).
  • However, the Carotid body receives 2000 ml/100 gm of tissue/min., the highest for any tissue in the body.
  • Renal blood flow:
    • The blood volume flows through the kidney per unit of time.
  • Usually, the renal regulatory mechanism keeps 20% of cardiac output, i.e., 1.2L/min, at a constant rate.
  • It means the perfusion rate per tissue mass of the kidney exceeds that of any other organ.
  • RBF = RPF/(1- Hct)
  • Renal plasma flow (RPF):
    • The volume of plasma that flows through the kidney per unit of time.
    • The RPF has more clinical relevance than RBF because only the plasma components can pass through the glomerular filtration barrier.

Option A: Brain

  • It has the highest perfusion rate.
  • It comprises 2% body weight and receives 15-20% of total cardiac output.
  • So, the brain is one of the most highly perfused organs in the body.

Option B: Heart

  • The highest arterio-venous O2 difference is seen in the heart.
  • It is the least in the kidneys.
  • The heart has maximum cardiac output.

Option D: Liver

  • The liver has the highest blood flow (ml/min).
  • It has the greatest amount of blood pumped per minute in each circulation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with Type I diabetes mellitus came to the OPD with complaints of abdominal distension and puffiness of the face. He was found to have elevated urea and creatinine levels. On further evaluation, the patient was found to have end-stage renal disease. The patient was advised for simultaneous kidney-pancreas transplantation (SKP). A brain-dead donor is found. Which of the following is a contraindication to being a pancreas donor?

choices.text: History of diabetes mellitus in the donor
No indication for liver transplant in the recipient
Technical complication rates are higher for pancreatic transplants than other solid organ transplants
Complications are less when compared to other solid organs

questions.solution:
Option A: History of diabetes

  • A kidney-pancreas transplant is an operation to place both a kidney and a pancreas, at the same time, into someone who has kidney failure related to type 1 diabetes.
  • Both transplanted organs may come from one deceased donor. However, it is also possible for the kidney to come from a living donor (a family member or friend) and the pancreas from a deceased donor
  • Pancreatic transplants are performed in three recipient categories:
    • Simultaneous pancreas and kidney (SPK) transplant in diabetic and uremic patients
    • Pancreas after kidney (PAK) transplant in diabetic and post uremic patients
    • Pancreas transplant alone (PTA) in non uremic patients with brittle diabetes mellitus

Contraindications to be a donor of the pancreas:

  • Type I diabetes mellitus in the donor is an absolute contraindication.

Relative contraindications to be a pancreas donor:

Relative contraindications are

  • Previous pancreatic procedures
  • Pancreatic disorders such as chronic pancreatitis and intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm.
  • Hyperglycemia in itself is not a contraindication.
Exclusion Criteria Inclusion Criteria
Type 1 or 2 diabetes (A1c>6.5%) 
Malignancies other than primary brain tumor
Septicemia
Viral hepatitis
Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome
Human immunodeficiency virus
Syphilis
Viral encephalitis
Creutzfeldt-Jacob disease
Rabies
Tuberculosis
Periods of relevant hypotension
Elevated serum creatinine (>2) 
Abnormal liver function tests ( >3  times normal range)
Elevation in serum amylase
Elevation in serum lipase
History of promiscuous sexual behavior
History of IV drug use		 Multiorgan donors
Either sex 15-70 years of age Warm ischemia time (WIT) <10 min  Cold ischemia time (CIT) <12 h  in the absence of TLM

Option B: No liver donation

All three abdominal organs (pancreas, liver and intestine) can be procured at the same time and transplanted into three different recipients.

Option C: No replaced hepatic artery vessels arising from the superior mesenteric artery (SMA)

  • If a replaced or aberrant right hepatic artery, the first branch of the superior mesenteric artery (SMA), is present, it is carefully dissected out from the posterior surface of the pancreas.
  • A replaced or aberrant right hepatic artery does not transverse the pancreas and is not a contraindication to the combined pancreas and liver procurement.

Option D: Complications are less when compared to other solid organs

The technical complication rate for pancreatic transplants is higher than for any other solid organ transplant.

  • The most common surgical complications are thrombosis, intra-abdominal abscesses, and bleeding.
  • The most common non-surgical complication post-transplant is rejection.

questions.text: A community medicine intern was asked to compare two study patterns. As compared to a routine case-control study, a Nested case-control study avoids problems related to which of the following?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option A: Temporal association

  • In Nested case-control studies, the exposure has been either measured before the study itself or the samples have been collected, so that the findings cannot change due to any bias.
  • Temporal association
    • It implies that the suspected cause comes before the observed effect or that the effect comes after the alleged cause.
    • It is the most crucial criterion for determining causality.
    • The best way to find out is to do a concurrent cohort study.

Option B: Confounding bias

  • Confounding: Any factor associated both with exposure as well as the outcome.
  • Confounding leads to wrong results or errors.
  • Confounding bias is not reduced by the Nested case-control study.

Option C: Need for long follow up

  • Since a nested case-control study is part of a cohort study, it actually takes more time.
  • In a Nested case-control study, interviews are performed at the beginning of the study (at baseline), and data are obtained before the disease has developed, thereby eliminating the problem of Recall bias.

Option D: Randomization

  • Randomization is not involved in a nested case-control study.

questions.text: A total of 5000 patients of glaucoma are identified and surveyed by patient interviews regarding family history of glaucoma. Such a study design is called?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option A: Case series report

  • A case series report is a descriptive study where more than one patient having a particular disease is studied.
  • No cause-related analysis or hypothesis testing is involved.

Option B: Case-control study

  • Backward-looking/retrospective study in which multiple risk factors are studied together.
  • It is studied from effect to exposure.
  • Odd's ratio can be calculated in a case-control study.

Option C: Clinical trials

  • It is a type of experimental or interventional study which is used for hypothesis confirmation and such trials are conducted on individuals.

Option D: Cohort study

  • Forward / prospective study in which multiple outcomes can be studied together.
  • From exposure to affect
  • Incidence & relative risk can be calculated in a cohort study.

questions.text: A 28-year-old lady has put on weight (10 kg over 3 years) and has oligomenorrhoea followed by amenorrhoea for 8 months. The blood pressure is 160/100 mm of Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate investigation?
questions.solution:
Option B: Plasma cortisol

  • Weight gain + Oligomenorrhea → Cushing syndrome.
  • Cortisol inhibits gonadotropin release, which explains amenorrhea.
  • Hypertension in these patients is secondary to increased cortisol that has some mineralocorticoid activity also.
  • Excess glucocorticoids also interfere with central regulatory systems, suppressing gonadotropins with subsequent hypogonadism and amenorrhea and suppressing the hypothalamic-pituitary-thyroid axis in decreased TSH (thyroid-stimulating hormone) secretion.
  • Weight gain + Oligomenorrhea + isolated diastolic hypertension in the question would have prompted Option D as the first Answer.

Option A: Serum electrolyte

  • Serum electrolytes would have been the answer if there was only hypertension to look for hyperaldosteronism by looking for hypokalemia

Option C: Plasma testosterone and ultrasound

  • Plasma testosterone and ultrasound are not indicated here as it is a case of Cushing's syndrome. It would have been necessary if there was any suspicion of ovarian cancer, but that would not explain the weight gain

Option D: T3, T4 and TSH

  • T3, T4 and TSH would have been done if there was any clinical suspicion of thyroid dysfunction. If the patient had isolated diastolic hypertension along with weight gain and oligomenorrhagia, it would prompt us to look for hypothyroidism

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient presents to the outpatient department for a routine health visit. He has no presenting complaints. He works as an accountant in a construction company. He does not smoke but drinks alcohol on social occasions. He has a family history of diabetes mellitus in two successive generations. He has no symptoms suggestive of diabetes. The physician recommends screening for diabetes based on his family history, and the results show fasting blood glucose levels of 250mg/dl. On further workup, the radio Immune Assay of Insulin is normal. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Maturity-onset diabetes of young

  • MODY presents impaired blood glucose levels induced by diminished insulin release due to an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern.
  • The onset of MODY is 25 years or younger
  • The beta cell mass is normal, but decreased insulin secretion occurs.
  • It involves mutations in the nuclear transcription factor gene (most commonly Hepatic nuclear factor 1-alpha) that regulates islet gene expression
  • Patients are responsive to sulfonylurea, which causes increased insulin secretion.

Option B: Wolfram Syndrome

  • Wolfram syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition and neurodegenerative disorder leading to childhood-onset- insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus.
  • It also causes:
    • Diabetes insipidus
    • Optic atrophy
    • Deafness.
  • It is a due mutation in a gene named WFSI, which encodes a 100.3 DKa transmembrane protein localized in the endoplasmic reticulum.

Option C: Type 1 diabetes mellitus

  • Type 1 diabetes mellitus has immune-mediated insulinopenia due to reduced beta cell mass.
  • In this condition immune system destroys the beta-pancreatic cell. This is also associated with a mutation in genes associated with T-cell tolerance.
  • Symptoms may include:
    • Extreme thirst
    • Vomiting, upset stomach
    • Dry mouth, blurry vision, and fatigue

Option D: Latent autoimmune Diabetes in adults

  • It is a slow-progressing form of immune-mediated type 1 diabetes mellitus.
  • It leads to a decrease in insulin release because of damage to insulin-producing beta cells in the pancreas
  • The onset is over 30 years of age.
  • It often would not require insulin for several months up to years after diagnosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman who underwent a mastectomy for breast cancer 2 years ago presents to the emergency department with headache, backache, and frequent vomiting. She is extremely thirsty and confused. Which of the following tests is most likely to identify the cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option D: Serum Calcium Concentration

  • Hypercalcemia is defined as a serum calcium level above the normal range of 8.5 to 10.5 mEq/L or an increase in the ionized calcium level above 4.2 to 4.8 mg/dL.
  • This patient is a known case of breast cancer operated on 2 years ago and now presents with symptoms of bone metastasis such as backache, headache, and frequent vomiting.
  • The metastasis to the bone causes increased osteoclastic activity in the bone, leading to hypercalcemia. Increased thirst sensation and confusion are symptoms of hypercalcemia. Hence the investigation needed to be done now is Serum Calcium Concentration.
  • Primary hyperparathyroidism and malignancy or secretion of the parathyroid hormone-related protein account for most cases of symptomatic hypercalcemia.
  • Multiple myeloma, lymphoma, and solid tumors metastasis to bone (particularly breast, lung, and prostate cancer) cause hypercalcemia by excessive osteoclastic activity
  • Symptoms of hypercalcemia
    • Gastrointestinal -Anorexia, nausea/vomiting, abdominal pain
    • Neuromuscular - Weakness, confusion, coma, bone pain
    • Cardiovascular - Hypertension, arrhythmia, polyuria, worsening of digitalis toxicity. ECG changes include shortened QT interval, prolonged PR and QRS intervals, increased QRS voltage, T-wave flattening and widening, and atrioventricular block
    • Renal - Polydipsia
  • Definitive management of hypercalcemia depends on the correction of the primary problem. Patients with a malignant neoplasm and hypercalcemia may respond to surgical excision, radiation therapy, or chemotherapy.
  • Symptomatic patients with severe hypercalcemia related to the malignant disease can be quickly and effectively treated by saline infusion followed by the administration of a loop diuretic to induce saline diuresis with associated urinary calcium clearance.
  • Severe hypercalcemia, referred to as hypercalcemic crisis, occurs with serum calcium concentration above 14mg/dL and is related to the release of calcium from bone by tumor; it can be managed by administration of bisphosphonates (zoledronic acid, pamidronate disodium, and etidronate disodium). They have a potent capacity to reduce the osteoclast-mediated release of calcium from bone.

 

Option A: CT Brain plain

  • CT brain plain is ordered to look at the structures of the brain and evaluate for the presence of pathologies such as:
    • Mass/tumor
    • Fluid collection (abscess)
    • Ischemic injury (stroke)
    • Hemorrhage
    • Hydrocephalus
    • The trauma of fracture of the skull
  • However, this patient's backache and history of breast cancer are concerning for hypercalcemia. CT would be in line with the management of this patient, but it is not the next best step in the evaluation of this patient's symptoms.

Option B: X-ray of the spine

  • X-ray of the spine is performed to diagnose:
    • Back pain
    • Fractures of the spine
    • Arthritis
    • Spondylolisthesis
    • Degeneration of the disks
    • Tumors
    • Abnormalities in the curvature of the spine, like kyphosis or scoliosis
    • Congenital abnormalities

 

Option C: Serum sodium concentration

  • Low serum sodium levels also cause nausea, vomiting, headache, and confusion.
  • However, this patient's history of breast cancer and backache are more concerning for hypercalcemia.

questions.text: A professor explains to second-year medical students the physiology of body fluid compartments. He explains that tissue interstitial fluid (TIF) bathes cells in tissues. 80% of extracellular fluid (ECF) is found in localized areas: Lymph, cerebrospinal fluid, synovial fluid, aqueous humor, a vitreous body of eyes, between serous and visceral membranes, and glomerular filtrate of kidneys. Which is the most important buffer in interstitial fluid?
questions.solution:
Option B: Bicarbonate

  • Bicarbonate buffer is quantitatively the most important buffer in the ECF compartment; it buffers non-carbonic acid. Hence, option B is correct.

Importance of bicarbonate buffer system

  • The bicarbonate buffer system is not powerful as the other buffer systems because of the large difference between the pH of ECF (7.4) and the pK of the bicarbonate buffer system (6.1). However, this buffer system plays an important role in maintaining the pH of body fluids than the other buffer systems.
  • It is because the concentration of two components (HCO3– and CO2) of this buffer system is regulated separately by two different mechanisms.
  • The concentration of HCO3– is regulated by the kidney, and the concentration of CO2 is regulated by the respiratory system.
  • These two regulatory mechanisms operate constantly and simultaneously, making this system more effective.

​​​​​​Option A: Phosphate

  • This system consists of a weak acid, the dihydrogen phosphate (H2 PO4 – protonated substance) in the form of sodium dihydrogen phosphate (NaH2 PO4), and the base, hydrogen phosphate (HPO4 – unprotonated substance) in the form of disodium hydrogen phosphate (Na2 HPO4).
  • The phosphate buffer system is more powerful than the bicarbonate buffer system as it has a pK of 6.8, which is close to the pH of the body fluids, i.e., 7.4. In addition to intracellular fluid (ICF), phosphate buffer is useful in tubular fluids of kidneys also. It is because more phosphate ions are found in the tubular fluid.

Option C: Histidine

  • Histidine makes a good amino acid buffer under physiological conditions, not very acidic or basic conditions, and is the best amino acid buffer within its buffering range.
  • Elements of proteins that form weak acids include the Imidazole group of histidine.

Option D: Protein

  • Protein buffer systems are present in the blood (both in the plasma and erythrocytes.) Intracellular proteins account for >70% of I/C buffering.
  • Protein buffer systems in plasma are more powerful due to their high plasma concentration and pK being very close to 7.4.

questions.text: A researcher is investigating the effect of hypoxia and hypercapnia on the central nervous system. He finds that hypoxic exposure is a potent activator of the autonomic nervous system (ANS). Hypoxia induces tachycardia when oxygen concentration is lower than 17%. Tachycardia caused by hypoxia is due to?
questions.solution:
• The primary reflex evoked by hypoxic stimulation of carotid chemoreceptor leads to excitation of the medullary vagal center. This will decrease the heart rate.
  • There is also a secondary reflex. Hyperventilation caused by hypoxic stimulation of chemoreceptor initiates pulmonary inflation reflex.
  • Stretch receptors in the thorax stimulated by hyperventilation initiate this reflex which will inhibit the medullary vagal center. This will result in tachycardia. There is also the effect of hypocapnia produced by hyperventilation; it will also add to the secondary reflex-induced tachycardia.

questions.text: Where are short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) produced by bacteria maximally absorbed?
questions.solution:
Option D: Colon

  • The SCFAs produced by bacteria are maximally absorbed in the colon.

Option A: Duodenum

  • It is an incorrect option.
  • In humans the fermentation products are produced and absorbed in the colon. Both small bowel and colonic mucosa readily absorb un ionized short-chain fatty acids.

Option B: Jejunum

  • It is an incorrect option.

Option C: Ileum

  • It is an incorrect option.

Learning Objective

  • Short-chain fatty acids (SCFA) are produced in the colon by the action of colonic bacteria on complex carbohydrates, and other dietary components that could not be digested in the small intestine. (like dietary fibres-60% of the total is acetate, 25% propionate, 15% butyrate).
  • These short-chain fatty acids are absorbed from the colon.
  • SCFAs have trophic effect on colonic epithelial cells, they also combat inflammation and maintain acid-base equilibrium.
  • SCFAs are not only a source of energy but also signaling molecules for the local regulation of the GI tract and systemic regulation via release of gut hormones. Targeting SCFA signals may be a novel therapeutic for GI diseases and metabolic syndrome.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with mucosal bleeds on trauma and has a history of menorrhagia. Bleeding time (BT) and Partial Thromboplastin Time (PTT) are elevated. The Ristocetin assay is negative. The use of desmopressin is best indicated in this disease. Which of the following is most likely the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Von Willebrand disease (VWD)

  • It is the most common inherited bleeding disorder caused by the deficiency of Von Willebrand factor, which is a carrier protein for factor VIII and a mediator for platelet adhesion to endothelium.
  • It is characterized by prolonged PTT and bleeding time.
  • It affects the coagulation pathway by decreasing factor VIII (prolonged PTT) and platelet adhesion (prolonged bleeding time).

Option A: Severe haemophilia A

  • Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive disorder with a deficiency of factor VIII.
  • It is characterized by the following:
    • Delayed or prolonged bleeding.
    • Intracranial hematomas
    • Hemarthrosis
    • Intramuscular hematomas
  • It is diagnosed by the following:
    • Deficiency of factor VIII
    • Increase activated PTT
    • Normal PT and platelet count
  • It is treated with factor replacement or desmopressin (in mild form).

Option B: Severe haemophilia B

  • Hemophilia B is an X-linked recessive disorder with a deficiency of factor IX.
  • It is characterized by the following:
    • Delayed or prolonged bleeding.
    • Intracranial hematomas
    • Hemarthrosis
    • Intramuscular hematomas
  • It is diagnosed by the following:
    • Deficiency of factor IX
    • Increase activated PTT
    • Normal PT and platelet count
  • It is treated with factor replacement.

Option D: Glanzmann thrombasthenia

 

  • It is a bleeding disorder characterized by prolonged or spontaneous bleeding starting from birth.
  • It is an autosomal recessive disorder.
  • It occurs due to a mutation in the ITGA2B gene, which is normally present on platelets and helps them to bind together during clot formation.
  • It has the following signs/symptoms:
    • Epistaxis
    • Gum bleeds
    • Red or purple plaques
    • High menstrual bleeding
    • Excessive blood loss during pregnancy or childbirth
  • The platelet count is usually normal/low, and there is an increased bleeding time (BT).
  • The blood smear shows no platelet clumping.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man with lung cancer is admitted with breathlessness. He has a raised jugular venous pressure, a tender and distended liver, and marked pedal oedema. ECG and chest X-ray were ordered, which are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Pericardial effusion

  • The heart rate is 100 beats/min with a normal axis. Low voltage ECG is noted. Normal sinus rhythm is noted.
  • The chest X-ray shows a typical “water bottle heart" with an increased cardiothoracic ratio. Hence the diagnosis is malignant pericardial effusion.

Option B: Cardiac tamponade

  • Cardiac tamponade has pulsus paradoxus with electrical alternans, a variation in the amplitude of QRS complexes.

Option C: Constrictive pericarditis

  • Constrictive pericarditis has low voltage ECG, but the cardiothoracic ratio is normal. Also, calcification can be seen around the heart. The chest X-ray in the Question shows an increased cardiothoracic ratio with no calcification around cardiac borders.

Option D: Canon ball metastasis

  • Multiple, well-circumscribed, round lung metastases that resemble cannonballs are known as cannonball metastases.
  • Metastases that display this characteristic are typically after cell carcinoma and choriocarcinoma, less commonly by primary tumours such as prostatic, endometrial, adrenal, and synovial sarcoma.
  • Lung fields are clear, ruling out Cannonball metastasis.

questions.text: A patient was treated for mantle cell Hodgkin lymphoma with radiation therapy. After 6 months, he develops an electric shock-like pain along the spine on flexing his neck. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Cervical spinal cord pathology

  • The patient experiences an electric shock-like sensation along the spine as he flexes his neck. This indicates the Lhermitte sign seen in cervical spinal pathology
  • It can be found in many conditions like transverse myelitis, cervical spondylosis
  • It can also appear after radiation and chemotherapy
  • This sign is also sometimes seen as part of a "discontinuation syndrome associated with certain psychotropic medications, such as selective serotonin reuptake  inhibitors and serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors, particularly paroxetine and venlafaxine
  • Typically, it only occurs after having taken the medication for some duration and then stopped or withdrawn rapidly or after administering a reduced dose

Option A: Cervical arthritis

  •  Cervical arthritis Presents with stiffness in neck muscles and reduced neck movements

Option C: Multiple sclerosis

  • Uthoff sign is seen in multiple sclerosis, which is worsening of symptoms of M.S. due to an increase in body temperature

Option D: Spinal cord compression

  • Patients with spinal cord compression have severe pain and bowel and bladder abnormalities

questions.text: A 48-year-old male patient who recently underwent lobectomy for bronchogenic carcinoma has come to OPD for a follow-up. Which of the following finding will you expect in the Pulmonary function test/Spirometry?
questions.solution:
Option C: Increased dead space ventilation

  • In the case of lobectomy, since the remaining lung tissue is lesser, all parameters like vital capacity, residual volume, and closing volume will reduce.
  • Hence, post-operative lobectomy patients will take rapid shallow breaths due to hypoxic stimulus.
  • This will lead to increased Dead space ventilation.

Option A: Increased residual volume

  • After lobectomy, residual volume decreases.

Option B: Increased vital capacity

  • After lobectomy, vital capacity decreases

 Option D: Increased closing volume

  • After lobectomy, closing volume decreases

questions.text: A 28-year-old male comes to the physician with the complaint of increasing fatigue for the past year. He has been following a vegetarian diet for the last 8 years. Initial laboratory investigations reveal decreased haemoglobin. The physician establishes the most likely diagnosis, and the patient is prescribed vitamin supplements. Following the treatment initiation, the patient reports improvement in his symptoms. Which of the following is least likely to be associated with this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Increased Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin Concentration

  • This patient, who has been following a vegetarian diet and is presenting with anaemia, most likely has vitamin B12 deficiency leading to megaloblastic anaemia.
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency is most commonly caused by decreased intake due to a vegetarian diet.
  • It can also be caused by decreased intestinal absorption secondary to gastrectomy, pernicious anaemia, or malabsorption syndromes.
  • Megaloblastic anaemia is caused by folic acid or vitamin B12 deficiency resulting in impaired DNA synthesis.
  • Macro-ovalocytes are large, oval red blood cells characteristically seen in megaloblastic anaemia.
  • Mean corpuscular haemoglobin concentration (MCHC) is the average haemoglobin concentration in red blood cells.
  • It is calculated by dividing mean corpuscular haemoglobin (MCH) by mean corpuscular volume (MCV).
  • The defective nuclear maturation due to inadequate DNA synthesis secondary to vitamin B12 or folic acid deficiency results in an increase in the size of red blood cells.
  • However, these macrocytes in megaloblastic anaemia have adequate haemoglobin and often lack the central pallor seen in normal red blood cells.
  • Since both parameters (MCV and MCH) are increased proportionately in megaloblastic anaemia, MCHC remains normal.
  • This patient is, therefore, unlikely to have an increased mean corpuscular haemoglobin concentration (MCHC).
  • Note: Increase in MCHC is seen in hereditary spherocytosis.

Option A: Macro-ovalocytes

  • Vitamin B12 and folic acid are the co-enzymes coenzymes required for synthesising thymidine, one of the four bases found in DNA.
  • Decreased thymidine synthesis results in delayed nuclear maturation, and the resulting red blood cells have a large size and oval shape (macro-ovalocytes).

Option B: Reduced Reticulocyte Count

  • Vitamin B12 and folic acid deficiency cause megaloblastic anaemia, characterised by ineffective erythropoiesis due to defective DNA synthesis.
  • The reticulocyte count would decrease due to decreased red blood cell maturation.

Option C: Hypercellular Bone Marrow

  • Megaloblastic anaemia is characterised by delayed maturation of red blood cells due to deranged DNA synthesis.
  • As a result, the red blood cell precursors are accumulated in the bone marrow and can sometimes completely replace the fatty marrow → hypercellular bone marrow.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents to a physician with a 3-day history of progressively worsening facial droop, difficulty swallowing, and blurred vision. Over the prior 4 months, she has had a productive cough, fevers, night sweats, and unintentional weight loss. Physical examination revealed a swollen cheek and facial droop involving the forehead, cheek, and chin. Her posterior pharynx was erythematous, but no areas of oropharyngeal fluctuance were noted. Initial investigations were done. A probable diagnosis of Heerfordt’s syndrome was made. Which of the following is a feature of this syndrome?
questions.solution:
Option A: Anterior uveitis

  • This is a case of Heerfordt's syndrome in which the patient presents with complaints of progressively worsening facial droop, difficulty in swallowing, and blurred vision for 3 days.
  • Heerfordts syndrome is a variant/ sub-type of Sarcoidosis
  • Sarcoidosis is a multisystem disease comprised of noncaseating granulomatous inflammation.
  • It can either present as acute or chronic

It has 3 sub-types

  •  Heerfordt Syndrome
  •  Lofgren syndrome
  • Jungling disease
  • The etiology of Sarcoidosis is still unknown. Environmental and genetic predisposition might have a role.

Sarcoidosis mostly affects the lungs, but it may also have extra-pulmonary involvements such as:

  • Arthritis
  • Neurosarcoidosis
  • Meningitis
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Lupus pernio
  • Scar sarcoidosis

Option B: Hypothermia

Hypothermia is not associated with Heerfordt’s syndrome

Option C: Facial puffiness

  • Heerfordt’s syndrome usually does not cause facial puffiness.
  • The patient usually presents with facial weakness.
  • The blurring of vision is also involved in this pathology.

Option D: Pharyngitis

  • Heerfordt’s syndrome causes difficulty in swallowing.
  • It is not associated with pharyngitis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old smoker presented to the emergency department with a non-productive cough, shortness of breath, and sudden onset pleuritic pain on the right side of the chest. On physical examination, the patient is afebrile and vitally stable. A chest examination showed diminished breath sounds on the right hemithorax. The physician ordered a chest X-ray, and a subsequent diagnosis of primary spontaneous pneumothorax (PSP) was made. Which of the following should be the appropriate management step for the above-mentioned case?
questions.solution:
Option C: Simple needle aspiration

  • Primary spontaneous pneumothorax (PSP), a pneumothorax without underlying lung illness, is more common in young, slim males.
  • Pleural blebs or bullae that have burst are the typical culprits. PSP often manifests as an initial onset of localised pleuritic chest discomfort and shortness of breath when the patient is at rest.
  • Most PSP cases are confirmed by an upright posteroanterior chest radiograph, which can accurately determine the size of the pneumothorax.
  • An upright posteroanterior chest radiograph, which may be utilised to accurately gauge the extent of the pneumothorax, is used to confirm most PSP cases.
  • Among the therapeutic possibilities are bed rest, oxygen supplements, manual aspiration, chest tube drainage, and thoracoscopic and surgical treatments.
  • Needle aspiration should be performed on patients who have a primary spontaneous pneumothorax for the first time, who are hemodynamically stable, have a large pneumothorax (more than 2-3 centimetres of air on a chest X-ray or more than 15% of the hemithorax), have a progressive pneumothorax, or who are symptomatic with chest pain or dyspnea.
  • The patient can be released once the treatment is successful (less than 2 millimetres of air in the chest X-ray and an improvement in the breathing pattern), with follow-up from 2 to 4 weeks.

Option A: Intermittent positive pressure ventilation (IPPV)

  • Intermittent positive pressure ventilation (IPPV) is considered if the patient's respiratory status is in peril, is likely to become so, or when respiratory failure affects other bodily systems.
  • IPPV is still most frequently used under anaesthesia, but the therapy is also used to treat a wide range of illnesses in the general intensive care unit (ICU).

Option B: Closed drainage

  • In routine clinical practice, a chest tube—a tube thoracostomy—is done to drain fluid, blood, or air from the pleural cavity.
  • Simple needle aspiration may immediately relieve pressure in a life-threatening scenario.
  • A chest tube is often employed when a pneumothorax cannot be resolved with needle aspiration.

Option D: Thoracotomy

  • The traditional surgical treatment for PSP has been a thoracotomy, which involves making an incision into the pleural space of the chest.
  • Surgery is indicated when an initial episode of PSP returns and causes chronic air leaks or a collapsed lung following the insertion of pleural drainage.
  • Due to its limited invasiveness and low morbidity, video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) for primary spontaneous pneumothorax has been presented as a novel surgical approach. It has replaced open thoracotomy in this situation.

questions.text: Protein synthesis machinery consists of ribosomes which are either bound to ER or freely present in the cytosol. All of the following proteins are synthesized by free-ribosomes, EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Cytosolic ribosomes synthesize: Rough ER ribosomes synthesize:

Proteins present in-

  • Mitochondria
  • Nucleus
  • Peroxisomes
  • Cytosol

Proteins present in-

  • ER
  • Golgi and Plasma membrane
  • Secretory proteins
  • Lysosomal enzymes

questions.text:
A fifty-five-year-old female comes to your clinic complaining of difficulty reading books. The patient loves to read and has been reading for as long as she can remember.

She has no problems with her vision otherwise. She also loves to read medical articles and wants you to explain to her the reason for her symptoms. The property of the human eye to increase the refractive power of the crystalline lens to focus near objects on the retina is known as accommodative power. Which of the following statements is not true regarding the accommodative power of the lens?

choices.text: Involves change in the anterior capsule of the lens
Accommodative power is 0.5 D at 75 years of age

questions.solution:
Option D: Accommodative power is 5 D at 75 years of age

  • Accommodation is the process by which the eye changes optical power to maintain a clear image or focus on an object as its distance varies.
  • It is the function of the anterior capsule of the lens and ciliary zonules.
  • The inability of the eye to focus on near objects is known as presbyopia.
  • Presbyopia is slowly progressive and is common in older adults.
  • The accommodative power of the lens is the amplitude of the accommodation of the lens.
  • Accommodative power decreases as a person ages:
    • Emmetropic child - 10D
    • 40-45 years  - 4D
    • 45-55 years  - 3D
    • 55-65 years - 1D
    • 70-75 years - 0.5D
  • Hence, the accommodative power is 0-0.5 D at 75 years.

Option A: Decreases with age

  • As a person gets older, he has difficulty seeing near objects.
  • This is due to a decrease in accommodative power.

Option B: Lost after cataract surgery

  • Accommodation is the function of the anterior capsule of the lens and ciliary zonules.
  • These structures are removed during cataract surgery.
  • Hence accommodative power is lost after surgery.

Option C: Involves change in the anterior capsule of the lens

  • Accommodation is the function of the anterior capsule of the lens and ciliary zonules.

questions.text: A 70-year-old diabetic and hypertensive male presents to the emergency department with complaints of fever, abdominal discomfort, dyspnea, and moulted skin rash. The patient says that 2 days ago, a coronary angiogram was performed on him when he was being investigated for angina. His great toe appears black. His blood pressure is 180/100 mmHg. His creatinine is found to have risen from a pre-angiography. He has eosinophilia. Which one of the following statements is correct regarding this condition?

choices.text: N-acetylcysteine would have prevented this condition
Heparin is the treatment of choice
Kidney biopsy will show micro-vessel occlusion with a cleft in the vessel.

questions.solution:
Option D: Kidney biopsy will show micro-vessel occlusion with a cleft in the vessel.

  • In patients undergoing angiography, catheterization can lead to embolism of a vulnerable atherosclerotic plaque in descending aorta downstream to renal arteries leading to an atheroembolic kidney disease.
  • The symptoms of the diabetic patient developed after angiography, and since atherosclerotic lesions can involve the aorta, the atheroembolic event would explain the events.
  • The presence of eosinophilia and mottling of toes, and reduced kidney function confirm the diagnosis of Atheroembolic kidney disease.
  • Lab findings include: 
    • Rising serum creatinine
    • Transient eosinophilia
    • Elevated sedimentation rate
    • Hypocomplementemia
  • A definitive diagnosis is made by doing a kidney biopsy: Microvessel obstruction with cholesterol crystals that leave a cleft in the vessel.

Other options

Option A: N-acetylcysteine would have prevented this condition

  • N-acetylcysteine prevents contrast-induced nephropathy, and it does not prevent aethroembolic kidney disease due to microvascular obstruction with cholesterol crystals.

Option B: 55% increase in serum creatinine

  • In Contrast-induced nephropathy there is 25% increase in serum creatinine

Option C: Heparin is the treatment of choice

  • Heparin will not manage cholesterol embolism.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female presents with diazepam and alcohol overdose. She is comatose. The temperature is 34.5°C. BP is 100/80 mmHg. Creatinine is 2.4mg/dL, AST-500, GGT-35 IU. The urine dipstick showed 3+ for blood, but urine analysis was normal. USG abdomen was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Rhabdomyolysis

  • In the setting of a drug overdose, the patient has presented with hypothermia and deranged kidney function.
  • The keyword in the question is “urine dipstick is 3+ for blood, but urine microscopy is normal”. This implies that myoglobin in urine is giving a false positive report for blood detected by urine dipstick.

Rhabdomyolysis causes:

  • Traumatic crush injuries
  • Alcohol intoxication with prolonged immobility
  • Prolonged seizures activity
  • Excessive exercise
  • Heatstroke
  • Myopathies, drug-induced, metabolic or inflammatory

Clinical Manifestations

In adults, Rhabdomyolysis is characterised by the triad of:

  1. Muscle weakness
  2. Myalgia
  3. Dark urine

Lab findings:

  • Elevation of creatinine kinase.
  • Myoglobin is not protein bound and can easily be detected in urine (half-life: 2-3 hours).
  • Other manifestations include hepatic dysfunction, AKI, hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia and hyperuricemia (release of purines from damaged muscles).

Option A: Hypothermia

  • Hypothermia can cause AKI and LOC but rarely cause myoglobin in the urine

Option B: Alcoholic Hallucinosis

  • Alcoholic hallucinosis is characterised by auditory hallucinations, paranoid symptoms and fear.
  • Overdose can cause AKI but does not cause myoglobinuria and rhabdomyolysis

Option D: Acute interstitial nephritis

  • Acute interstitial nephritis (AIN) is a renal lesion that typically causes a decline in kidney function and is characterised by an inflammatory infiltrate in the kidney interstitium.
  • Although diazepam and alcohol can cause it, but due to this, myoglobin does not appear in the urine.

questions.text: A 55-year old man, who is a diabetic for 15 years on irregular treatment came to hospital with a wound on the left foot for 2 weeks. He used a hot water bottle to warm his feet, next day he noticed the wound. On examination the burn wound has a thick leathery eschar with purulent discharge. Which of the following topical antibiotics is used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Mafenide acetate

  • Mafenide acetate - It is a Broad-spectrum antibacterial agent with an excellent eschar penetration

Topical antimicrobials:

Silver sulfadiazine Mafenide acetate 0.5% Silver nitrate

It is the most commonly used topical antibiotic

Broad antibacterial spectrum

Painless on application

Fair to poor eschar penetration

No metabolic side effects

Mild inhibition of epithelialization

May leave black tattoos from silver ion

Transient leukopenia may develop in 3 to 5 days and resolve spontaneously.

Destroys skin grafts and is contraindicated on burns or donor sites in proximity to newly grafted areas

Painful on application

Broad-spectrum antibacterial

Particularly useful against resistant Pseudomonas and Enterococcus species

Reserved for small full-thickness injuries

It is an excellent antimicrobial for fresh skin grafts

Excellent eschar penetration

Mild inhibition of epithelialization

Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor and hence may cause metabolic acidosis

Broad-spectrum antibacterial and antifungal

Painless on application

Poor eschar penetration

Stains contacted areas

Leaches sodium from wounds

May cause methemoglobinemia

Option B: Neomycin

  • It is a petroleum-based antimicrobial ointment
  • It is commonly used for the treatment of facial burns, graft sites, healing donor sites, and small partial-thickness burns
  • Easy to apply
  • Painless
  • Has an antimicrobial spectrum not as wide as silver sulfadiazine
  • However, Mafenide acetate is preferable for eschars due to its good penetration.

Option C: Silver nitrate

  • Silver nitrate can be used for burns as an anti-infective agent. However, it is not as good for eschars as mafenide acetate is.

Option D: Silver sulfadiazine

  • Silver sulfadiazine is used for burns to prevent bacterial infections.
  • Silver sulfadiazine has a wide spectrum of bactericidal activity against both gram-positive and gram-negative organisms.
  • However, it is not the best choice for eschars

questions.text: A young adult concludes that he is never going to be in a relationship after his experience of twice being rejected for a date. This is :
questions.solution:
The example in the question is of over-generalization.

In this cognitive error or cognitive distortion, the individual makes conclusions based on very little data or experience. Alternative possibilities are not considered.

Cognitive distortions - These are errors in thinking that impinge upon the person's view of themselves, of other people and of their own future. Seen in persons depression. Their presence increases the risk of occurrence of depression in future.

Personalisation - You see yourself as the cause of some negative external event, which in fact you were not primarily responsible for, for example blaming yourself when your child is misbehaving at school. The emotional consequence is guilt.

All-or-nothing thinking Things are seen in black and white; if performance falls short of perfect, the person regards themselves as a total failure, for example if a person fails to be promoted to the post they desperately wanted, they believe they will never
be promoted and that their career is in ruins.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female presents to Gynaecology OPD reporting increased vaginal discharge from two days. On examination, it is clear, slippery and stretchable between fingers. The rest of the examination is unremarkable. She has been married for 5 years, has two live children, and uses natural fertility awareness methods for contraception. What advice should be given to her?

choices.text: Avoid intercourse for the next 3 days.
Get herself checked for vaginal infection.
Can safely have intercourse from the next day.

questions.solution:
Option A: Avoid intercourse for the next 3 days

  • The cervical mucus method is also called the "ovulation method" or, more commonly ", Billings' ovulation method."
  • The method is based on recognizing the changes in cervical mucus due to the effect of estrogen and progesterone at different times of the menstrual cycle.
  • At the time of ovulation, the mucus becomes more copious, clear, and slippery, resembling the white of a raw egg, and can be stretched slowly between two fingers (Spinnbarkeit Phenomenon). This is due to estrogen, which peaks just before ovulation. The vagina and vulva feel moist or wet. This persists for about 3 days. These are called "wet days"; the last day of wet mucus is called the "peak day." These days mark the peak of fertility.
  • Post ovulation, as estrogen decreases and progesterone increases, the mucous becomes thick and non-stretchable due to the progesterone effect.
  • The ovulation method can be used for both contraception (by avoiding contact on fertile days) and to achieve a pregnancy (by having intercourse during the fertile period). Hence in this question, since the woman has thin, stretchy mucous, she must practice abstinence for the next few days.
  •  

Option B: Can safely have intercourse

  • The patient must not have intercourse for the next few days, as a thin and stretchy mucous implies a peak of estrogen, and thus ovulation is about to occur. Intercourse around this time can lead to a pregnancy.

Option C: Get herself checked for vaginal infection

  • Thin, stretchy vaginal discharge around ovulation is normal and not suggestive of infection.

Option D: Can safely have intercourse from the next day

  • The patient must not have intercourse for the next few days, as a thin and stretchy mucous implies a peak of estrogen, and thus ovulation is about to occur. Intercourse around this time can lead to a pregnancy.

questions.text: A patient has primary open-angle glaucoma in his right eye. His visual acuity was 10/90; despite being on timolol, pilocarpine, and acetazolamide, the IOP remains 20 to 24mmhg. A subsequent visual field test showed further field loss progression in this eye. Which one of the following is the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Argon laser trabeculoplasty

  • This is a case of medically refractory open-angle glaucoma. In this case, surgery is commonly undertaken to arrest visual field loss.
  • Laser trabeculoplasty, both argon laser trabeculoplasty(ALT) and selective laser trabeculoplasty (SLT) types is used to increase aqueous outflow facility through the trabecular meshwork (TM) to lower intraocular pressure (IOP) in cases of ocular hypertension and glaucoma.
  • This is the best treatment choice for this patient.

Option A: Seton Placement

  • It is done in cases of refractory glaucoma where trabeculectomy has failed.

Option B: Trabeculectomy

  • Trabeculectomy is a filtering surgery where an ostium is created into the anterior chamber from underneath a partial thickness scleral flap to allow for aqueous flow out of the eye. The aqueous flows into the subconjunctival space, usually leading to an elevation of the conjunctiva, referred to as a filtering bleb.
  • Trabeculectomy is performed for treatment of glaucoma inadequately controlled by maximally tolerated medical therapy. But, better choices like laser trabeculoplasty are available.

Option D: Addition of apraclonidine

  • This is a medically refractive open-angle glaucoma case. In this case, Surgery is commonly undertaken to arrest visual field loss.
  • So, this is the wrong option.

questions.text: A three day-old term infant born at home, breast-fed exclusively, presented with lethargy, bulging fontanel, and bright red blood from rectum. What is the most likely etiology of his disease?
questions.solution:
• Vit K deficiency is associated with hemorrhagic disease of newborn which has manifested in this baby as Intracranial hemorrhage (bulging fontanel) and GI bleed (blood per rectum).
  • Moreover, home delivery (Vit K may not have been given at birth) and exclusive breastfeeding (Vit K is deficient in breast milk) clearly point to Vit K deficiency as etiology.
  • Calcium deficiency: Tetany, rickets, and osteoporosis
  • Iron deficiency: Iron deficiency anemia is associated with impaired performance in mental and physical functions including physical coordination and capacity, cognitive abilities, and social and emotional development
  • Fluoride deficiency - Dental caries, osteoporosis

questions.text: A 22-year-old female presents to the clinic complaining of joint pain and facial rash. She describes that her facial rash appeared after exposure to the sun. Lab analysis shows an elevated level of antibodies against dsDNA. A diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus is made. Which of the following is least likely to be decreased in expression?
questions.solution:
options in terms of their expression levels in SLE:

  1. B cells: B cells are responsible for producing antibodies, including autoantibodies. In SLE, there is often an increase in B cell activation and antibody production. This leads to the production of autoantibodies, such as anti-dsDNA antibodies, which are characteristic of the disease. Therefore, B cell expression and activity are not likely to be decreased in SLE.

  2. CD4-positive T cells: CD4-positive T cells are immune cells that play a central role in coordinating immune responses. In SLE, CD4-positive T cells can be activated and involved in the autoimmune response, leading to inflammation. Therefore, CD4 expression and activation may not be decreased in SLE; they can actually be increased due to immune dysregulation.

  3. Complement proteins: Complement proteins are part of the immune system and play a role in inflammation and immune defense. In SLE, there can be a decrease in the levels and function of complement proteins. This deficiency can lead to impaired immune regulation and increased susceptibility to infections. Therefore, complement protein expression and function are likely to be decreased in SLE.

  4. Erythrocytes (Red Blood Cells): Erythrocytes are not directly involved in the immune response or the production of autoantibodies. Their primary function is to transport oxygen. In SLE, erythrocytes themselves are not a central focus of the disease, and their expression levels are not typically affected in the same way as immune cells or complement proteins.

So, among the options provided, option 4 (Erythrocytes) is least likely to be decreased in expression in the context of SLE.

questions.text: Which of the following structures forms the posterior boundary of the carotid triangle?
questions.solution:
Option D: Sternocleidomastoid

  • The neck is divided into anterior and posterior triangles by the Sternocleidomastoid muscle. The anterior triangle is further divided into four triangles.
  1. Carotid Triangle
  2. Submental Triangle
  3. Submandibular Triangle
  4. The muscular triangle is also known as the infrahyoid triangle

Boundaries of Carotid Triangle:

  • Superior: Stylohyoid and posterior belly of digastric
  • Anterior: Superior belly of omohyoid
  • Posterior: Anterior margin of sternocleidomastoid muscle

Contents of Carotid Triangle:

  • The common carotid artery divides into internal and external carotid arteries within the carotid triangle
  • Internal jugular vein
  • Hypoglossal Nerve
  • Vagus nerve 
  • Carotid Sinus    

Its floor is formed by

  • Hyoglossus
  • Thyrohyoid membrane
  • Medial and inferior constrictor muscles.

 

Option A: Superior belly of the omohyoid

  • The superior belly of the omohyoid forms the anterior border of the carotid triangle.

Option B: Posterior belly of digastric

  • The posterior belly of the digastric forms the superior border of the carotid triangle.
  • The posterior belly of the digastric is attached to the hyoid bone & mastoid process.

Option C: Mylohyoid Muscle

  • The Mylohyoid muscle is not a part of the carotid triangle
