  • It extends between the mandible and hyoid bone and is present on the floor of the Digastric Triangle.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient is exhibiting symptoms of persistent fatigue and muscle weakness, suggesting a potential disruption in oxidative carbohydrate metabolism. In the TCA cycle, the formation of reduced coenzymes involves dehydrogenase reactions. Which specific enzyme, serving as the FAD-linked dehydrogenase in the TCA cycle, could be implicated in this patient's clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Option C: Succinate dehydrogenase

  • Succinate dehydrogenase is the only FAD-linked dehydrogenase in TCA cycle.
  • Reaction catalyzed by this enzyme is as:

  • FADH2 produced here directly participate in the ETC.

Option A and B: Malate dehydrogenase and isocitrate dehydrogenase

  • Both are NAD linked dehydrogenases of TCA cycle.
  • MDH is a simple dehydrogenase whereas IDH also performs decarboxylation along with dehydrogenation.
  • Their reactions are shown as:

Option D: Glyceraldehyde 3-P dehydrogenase

  • Glyceraldehyde 3-P dehydrogenase is a dehydrogenase of Glycolysis.
  • Its also an NAD linked dehydrogenase but also transfer Pi to its substrate glyceraldehyde 3-P

questions.text: Which of the following structures develops the muscles of mastication?
questions.solution:
Option C: C

  • Somites form muscles of mastication.

Paraxial mesoderm/somite

  • Somites are mesoderm blocks on either side of the neural tube in the developing vertebrate embryo.
  • Somites develop from the paraxial mesoderm and participate in the facilitation of multiple developmental processes.
  • Dermatome [lateral part] forms skin dermis.
  • Myotome [middle part] forms skeletal muscles, including the muscle of mastication.
  • Sclerotome [medial part] forms bone [vertebra].

 

 

 

 

Option A: A

Notochord

  • It arises from the axial mesoderm and is completely formed by the beginning of the 4th week.
  • The main function of the notochord derived from the mesoderm is the development of the vertebrate and as a midline tissue providing directional signals to surrounding tissue during development.
  • It is a defining structure that has an important role in the development of the vertebrate. The primary function of the notochord is to support the body of the organism. It becomes an integral part of the backbone as it grows.
  • Nucleus pulposus is a vestigial remnant of the notochord found in the intervertebral disc.

 

Option B: B

Intermediate mesoderm

  • A narrow section of the mesoderm lies between the paraxial and the lateral plate mesoderm.
  • Intermediate mesoderm derivatives are:
    • The genitourinary system, smooth muscles [destructor], and epithelial components of the kidney, testis, and ovary

 

Option D: D

Somatopleuric mesoderm

  • The lateral plate mesoderm has two parts: somatic and visceral mesoderm.
  • The somatopleuric mesoderm forms the parietal layers of pleura, peritoneum & pericardium.

questions.text: A woman presents 2 weeks after the intake of medical abortion pills with a history of minimal bleeding after intake of pills. She did not pass any clots or fleshy mass. On ultrasound, there is a single live intrauterine pregnancy. The doctor suggests that she may continue the pregnancy if she wishes, however, there is a small risk of fetal malformation. Which of the following syndromes, the baby may be born with?
questions.solution:
Option B : Moebius syndrome

  • Moebius syndrome results from the underdevelopment of the VI and VII cranial nerves.
  • It is characterized by facial paralysis and there is an inability to move the eyes from side to side.
  • Most people with this syndrome are born with complete facial paralysis and cannot close their eyes or form facial expressions.
  • There is a strong association between Moebius syndrome and antenatal use of Misoprostol.

Option A : Kartagener's syndrome isa rare, autosomal recessive genetic ciliary disorder comprising the triad ofsitus inversus, chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis. The basic problem lies in the defective movement of cilia, leading to recurrent chest infections, ear/nose/throat symptoms, and infertility.

Option C : Down's syndrome, also known astrisomy 21, is a genetic disorder, usually associated with physical growth delays, mild to moderate intellectual disability and characteristic facial features.

Option D : Williams syndrome isa developmental disorder that affects many parts of the body. This condition is characterized by mild to moderate intellectual disability or learning problems, unique personality characteristics, distinctive facial features, and heart and blood vessel (cardiovascular) problems.

questions.text: On performing refraction using plane mirror on a patient who's has a refractive error of -3 D sphere with -2 D cylinder at 90 degree from a distance 1 metre under no cycloplegia, the reflex would be seen to move

choices.text: With the movement in the horizontal axis and against the movement in the vertical axis
With the movement in both the axis
Against the movement in both the axis
With the movement in the vertical axis and against the movement in horizontal axis

questions.solution:
Error of -3 D sphere that is person using concave sphere(diverging) advised in cases of myopia.

Reflection of ligth with Retinoscope

  • Against / opposite movement - Myopia > -1
  • With / same movement - Myopia < -1 or Emmetropia = 1 or Hypermetropia = + value
  • No movement - Myopia = -1

This patient is having a -3DS with -2DC x 90 - compound myopic astigmatism, so the reflex would move in opposite direction to the beam irrespective of the axis

questions.text: An experiment is performed in the laboratory to study the movement of ions across the membranes. Scientists have prepared two solutions of potassium chloride with different osmolarities. The lab's temperature has been optimized to normal physiological conditions of the living cells. Solution A and solution B are separated by a membrane, which is permeable to K+ and impermeable to Cl- Solution B is at 1 mM KCl and solution A is at 100 mM KCl. Which of the following statements best relates to Solution A and Solution B?

choices.text: K+ ions will diffuse from solution A to solution B until the [K+] of both solutions is 50.5 mM
K+ ions will diffuse from solution B to solution A until the [K+] of both solutions is 50.5 mM
KCl will diffuse from solution A to solution B until the [KCl] of both solutions is 50.5 mM
K+ will diffuse from solution A to solution B until a membrane potential develops with solution A negative with respect to solution B

questions.solution:
Option D: K+ will diffuse from solution A to solution B until a membrane potential develops with solution A negative with respect to solution B

  • In a solution, KCl dissociates into K+ and Cl−. Different concentrations of these and other ions across the membranes determine membrane diffusion potentials.
  • Every cell type functions at a different physiological membrane potential.
  • Charged ions move across the permeable membranes along or against the concentration gradient according to the membrane diffusion potential.
  • So membrane diffusion potential difference determines the movement of charged ions across the membranes.
  • The membrane is permeable only to K+ ions. K+ will diffuse down its concentration gradient from solution A to solution B, leaving some Cl− ions behind in solution A.
  • A diffusion potential will be created, with solution A negative concerning solution B.

Option A: K+ ions will diffuse from solution A to solution B until the [K+] of both solutions is 50.5 mM

  • This option is incorrect because K+ has a positive charge, and its movement across the membranes depends mainly upon the membrane diffusion potentials and not on the osmolarity gradient.

Option B: K+ ions will diffuse from solution B to solution A until the [K+] of both solutions is 50.5 mM

  • This option is incorrect because solution B has a lower osmolarity than solution A and solution A is more positively charged than solution B.
  • So positively charged potassium ions will not move from solution B to solution A.

Option C: KCl will diffuse from solution A to solution B until the [KCl] of both solutions is 50.5 mM

  • KCl solution dissociates into K+ and Cl- ions.
  • The membrane used in this experiment is permeable only to K+ and is impermeable to Cl-.
  • That is why KCl can't move across the membrane as a molecule.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl with irregular menstrual cycles and anemia is diagnosed to have polymenorrhagia. The menstrual abnormality in the girl is?

choices.text: Increase in frequency of cycle along with excessive or prolonged bleeding
Increase in frequency of cycle with average normal bleeding
Increase in duration of cycle with less bleeding

questions.solution:
Option A : Polymenorrhea is defined as cyclic bleeding where the cycle is reduced to an arbitrary limit of fewer than 21 days and remains constant at that frequency. If the frequent cycle is associated with excessive and or prolonged bleeding, it is called polymenorrhagia.

Basic definitions of Menstrual cycle

  • Length of menstrual cycle : 28 +/- 7 days, polymenorrhea is cycle length less than 21 days, oligomenorrhea is cycle length more than 35 days
  • Duration : 2-7 days : hypomenorrhea is duration of cycle < 2 days, menorrhagia is duration of flow more than 7 days
  • Amount : 20-50 ml per cycle : hypomenorrhea is amount < 20 ml, menorrhagia is amount more than 80 ml
  • polymenorrhagia : cycle length less than 21 days and flow > 80 ml per cycle
  • Metrorrhagia : irregular cycles superimposed on regular cycles or intermenstrual bleeding/ spotting

Option B : Increase in frequency of cycle with average normal bleeding is polymenorrhea

Option C : Increase in duration of cycle with less bleeding is oligomenorrhea

Option D : Regular cycle with less bleeding is hypomenorrhea

questions.text: A patient with immense joint pain, biphasic fever, headache, nausea, foreign body sensation in eyes, fatigue, and maculopapular rash for 4 days visited the outpatient department. On examination, lymphadenopathy was present, redness and watering of eyes, fever of 101 degrees Fahrenheit was recorded, and symmetrical large joint involvement resulted in difficulty walking or even standing for long. The patient gave a history of sleeping outdoors for 5 days. Culturing the sample in newborn suckling mice, chikungunya was confirmed. Which of these statements is not true regarding this disease?

choices.text: The proximity of mosquito breeding sites to human habitation is a significant risk factor for chikungunya.
It is transmitted by Anopheles mosquitoes in India
The name chikungunya means "that which bends up."

questions.solution:
Option B: It is transmitted by Anopheles mosquitoes in India

  • Anopheles mosquitoes do not transmit chikungunya.
  • Anopheles is a vector of malarial disease.

Chikungunya Disease:

  • Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus mosquitoes transmit chikungunya.
  • The roots of this viral illness date back to 1953, when it was first described during an outbreak in Tanzania, Africa.
  • It is derived from the Makonde word meaning "that which bends up" about the stooped posture developed as a result of the arthritic symptoms of the disease. In Swahili, this means "the illness of the bent walker".
  • Symptoms usually begin 3–7 days after the infected mosquito bite.
  • The most common symptoms are biphasic fever, joint pain, lymphadenopathy, conjunctivitis, and maculopapular rash.
  • It is worldwide in distribution.

Option A: The proximity of mosquito breeding sites to human habitation is a significant risk factor for chikungunya

  • CHIKV (Chikungunya virus) is spread by Aedes aegypti bite, so living near breeding sites is a potential risk factor for the disease.
  • Habitants are advised to sleep indoors, use mosquito repellents and wear long sleeves shirts and pants.
  • CHIKV has no other animal reservoir, but Aedes aegypti biting an infected patient might act as a reservoir for the virus.
  • Inhabitants are advised to check for water-holding containers and weekly empty or scrub items that hold water.
  • There is no vaccine against CHIKV, so the only prevention is against mosquito bites.

Option C: The name chikungunya means "that which bends up."

  • The name chikungunya is derived from a native word that means “doubled up” or “that which bends up” due to extreme joint pain.
  • There are bilateral and symmetrical involvements of joints.
  • Joint involvement is debilitating and causes the patients to bend up.
  • 14% of cases convert to chronic arthritis.
  • Acetaminophen is recommended for pain relief.
  • Aspirin and NSAIDs are not indicated until dengue is ruled out.

Option D: Its complication include meningoencephalitis

  • The disease complications include meningoencephalitis, myelitis, myocarditis, hepatitis, uveitis, retinitis, Guillain-Barre syndrome, and cranial nerve palsies.
  • Persons at risk include:
    • Neonates exposed intrapartum
    • Adults older than 65 years
    • Persons with underlying medical conditions ( hypertension, diabetes, and cardiovascular diseases )
    • Symptoms typically resolve within 7-10 days.
    • Mortality is rare and occurs mostly in older adults.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male was brought to the emergency day after a road traffic accident 20 minutes ago. He has multiple lacerations to his upper extremities and sustained an open fracture to his lower extremity. Initial CBC reveals white blood cells count at 22 x 103 /µl, and subsequent complete blood count analysis after 5 hours reveals the white blood cells count at 7 x 103 /µl. Which of the following is the reason for the increase in white blood cell count on the initial blood report?

choices.text: Increased production of WBCs by the bone marrow
Release of pre-formed, mature WBCs into the circulation

questions.solution:
Option B: Release pre-formed, mature WBCs into the circulation

  • A traumatic physical event can result in the release of WBCs into circulation.
  • The increase in the given case may not be due to any inflammatory response, but instead, the increase is due to mechanical trauma and associated stress responses.
  • Stress causes an overproduction of white blood cells, which defend the body against diseases but can cause problems when produced in excess.
  • These extra cells can stick to artery walls, causing restrictions in blood flow and aiding the formation of clots that can cause blood-vessel blockages throughout the body.
  • When stimulation, like an increased level of cytokines, these stored WBCs are released into circulation.
  • But still, a physically traumatic event can result in the release of WBCs into circulation.

Option A: Increased production of WBCs by the bone marrow

  • Increased production of WBCs by the bone marrow defends your body against infections and disease. But, when too many white blood cells, it usually means you have an infection or inflammation in your body. Less commonly, a high white blood cell count could indicate certain blood cancers or bone marrow disorders.

Option C: Decreased destruction of WBCs

  • Decreased destruction of WBCs is usually caused by: Viral infections that temporarily disrupt the work of bone marrow.

Option D: Increased production of selectins

  • The selectins are physiologically important in inflammation, lymphocyte homing, immunological responses, and homing of bone marrow stem cells. They play a role in atherosclerosis, ischemia-reperfusion injury, inflammatory diseases, and the metastatic spreading of some cancers.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male complained of generalized fatigue associated with difficulty breathing. On examination, pallor & gingival hypertrophy is noted. Initial investigations revealed hyperleukocytosis. Follow-up investigations showed leukostasis. This feature is most predominantly seen in which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
Option B: Acute myeloid leukaemia (AML)

  • Leukostasis (also called symptomatic hyperleukocytosis) is a medical emergency most commonly seen in patients with acute myeloid leukaemia. 
  • It is characterized by an extremely elevated blast cell count and symptoms of decreased tissue perfusion.
  • The most common symptoms are dyspnea and hypoxia, usually accompanied by visual changes, headache, dizziness, confusion, somnolence and coma.
  • Hyperleukocytosis and leukostasis syndrome are commonly associated with a complication of acute leukaemia (particularly myeloid leukaemia).
  • It can occur when the peripheral blast cell count is >100,000/mL.
  • The frequency of hyperleukocytosis is 13% in acute myeloid leukaemia (AML); however, leukostasis is rare in lymphoid leukaemia.

Option A: Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL)

  • Leukostasis is seen primarily in myeloid leukaemia and is very rare in lymphoblastic leukaemia.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option C: Chronic myelocytic leukaemia (CML)

  • Leukostasis is seen very rarely seen in Chronic myeloid leukaemia
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option D: Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL)

  • Leukostasis is seen primarily in myeloid leukaemia and is very rare in lymphocytic leukaemia.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male was diagnosed with chronic myeloid leukaemia after an incidental finding of leukocytosis last year. He was treated with imatinib, and the treatment was changed to nilotinib because of progressive leukocytosis. On follow-up, investigations revealed worsening of leukocytosis & thrombocytopenia. His peripheral blood showed >30% blasts with promyelocytes. What is the most effective treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Allogeneic bone marrow transplantation

  • The above features are suggestive of the Accelerated phase of CML.
  • Among patients who present with or evolve to the blastic phase, combinations of chemotherapy and Tyrosine Kinase Inhibitors (TKI) should be used to induce remission, followed by allogeneic stem cell transplantation as soon as possible.
  • The same applies to patients who evolve from chronic to accelerated phase. Patients with de novo accelerated-phase CML may do well with long-term TKI therapy; the timing of allogeneic stem cell transplantation depends on their optimal response to TKI (achievement of complete cytogenetic response). The most effective is stem cell transplantation.
  • Among patients who relapse in the chronic phase, the treatment sequence depends on several factors, such as the patient's age and risk factors for stem cell transplantation.

Option B: Autologous bone marrow transplantation

  • Autologous bone marrow transplantation is not the treatment of choice; because the patient's bone marrow is already infiltrated with cancer.

Option C: Chemotherapy

  • The patient's peripheral blood shows >30% blasts with promyelocytes after treatment with imatinib and nilotinib. It shows chemotherapy is ineffective in this case.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option D: Hydroxyurea & interferon

  • Hydroxyurea, a ribonucleotide reductase inhibitor, is used for controlling cell counts.
  • Interferons are given when allogeneic stem cell transplantation is not feasible.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents to the emergency department due to a sudden loss of vision in the right eye. It is associated with pain on eye movement. She had a history of acute disseminated encephalomyelitis 2 months ago, for which she was treated with oral prednisolone. On examination, she can only count fingers when seeing from the right eye (visual acuity). A positive afferent pupillary defect is also present. The ophthalmologist suspects optic neuritis. Which of the following is least likely to diagnose optic neuritis?
questions.solution:
Option C: B-scan ultrasonography (USG)

  • Optic neuritis is a severe, painful visual impairment typically affecting young people.
  • Demyelinating disease, such as multiple sclerosis, is its most frequent cause.
  • Other causes include infections (measles, mumps,  tuberculosis, Lyme disease) and autoimmune disorders (sarcoidosis, systemic lupus erythematosus).
  • Common symptoms include unilateral progressive vision loss, impaired colour vision, pain in eye movement, the presence of relative afferent pupillary deficit (RAPD), and normal-appearing fundus with mild papilledema in ⅓ patients.
  • The investigations used to diagnose optic neuritis involve:
  • MRI
  • Blood tests (ESR, antibodies in neuromyelitis optica)
  • Optical coherence tomography (OCT)
  • Visual field test
  • Visual evoked response.
  • B-scan ultrasonography (USG) is used to diagnose conditions affecting the eyeball's posterior segment.
  • Common diseases in which a USG B scan is used are vitreous degeneration, retinal detachment, trauma, and retinoblastoma.
  • However, it is not useful for diagnosing optic neuritis.

Option A: MRI head and orbit

  • MRI head and orbit is the most important test that detects optic nerve inflammation.
  • It also reveals demyelination foci in the brain, especially in periventricular white matter regions, seen in a patient with multiple sclerosis.

 

Option B:  Erythrocyte sedimentation rate

  • ESR (erythrocyte sedimentation) rate help detect inflammation in the body.
  • It is a nonspecific marker that is increased in infectious causes of optic neuritis.

Option D: Visual field test

  • Checking the visual field is useful for evaluating the progression and extent of the disease and is also important for follow-up.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents to the gynaecology department with a complaint of heavy uterine bleeding associated with dysmenorrhea for the last 2 months. She has been married for 7 years and is multiparous with 5 live births. On ultrasound, she is diagnosed to have a fibroid uterus. Which of the following best describes this neoplasm?

choices.text: Benign monoclonal growth of the myometrium
Endometrial growth extending into the myometrium

questions.solution:
Option B: Benign monoclonal growth of the myometrium

  • Fibroid (Leiomyoma) is derived from smooth muscle cells that rest either from vessel walls or uterine musculature and is best described as a benign monoclonal growth of the myometrium.
  • It is the most common benign tumour of the uterus.
  • It is also the most common benign pelvic tumour in females.
  • Many women who have fibroids are asymptomatic.
  • Symptomatic patients can be affected by the location, size and number of fibroids.
  • The followings are the signs and symptoms:
  • Menstrual abnormalities : polymenorrhea or menorrhagia or both 
  • Pelvic heaviness or pain
  • Urinary symptoms : frequency, urgency, incomplete evacuation
  • Infertility

Option A: Benign tumour of endometrium

  • The fibroid is the benign tumour of the myometrium, not the endometrium.

Option C: Malignant growth of the myometrium

  • A fibroid is a non-cancerous tumour. It is not a malignant tumour.
  • It is a benign tumour of the myometrium.

Option D: Endometrial growth extending into the myometrium

  • There is no extension of a benign tumour. It is the tumour of the myometrium.

questions.text: A 50-year-male presented to the clinic with complaints of abdominal pain, diarrhoea and reflux episodes. He also complains of weight loss and loss of appetite. A provisional diagnosis of Zollinger Ellison syndrome was made. The gastroenterologist suspected the underlying cause to be gastrinoma with metastasis. Which of the following is the best investigation for diagnosing metastatic gastrinoma?
questions.solution:
Option B: Octreoscan

  • Octreoscan is the brand name of somatostatin receptor scintigraphy (SRS).
  • The most accurate non-invasive technique for locating primary tumours and metastases is SRS.
  • It is useful for figuring out whether liver or bone metastases are present. The results of this method can be utilised to distinguish between small liver hemangiomas and small liver metastases. False-positive SRS localisation findings can occasionally happen.
  • It is also helpful in identifying the primary lesions preoperatively
  • The diagnostic sensitivity of SRS is between 80%-100% in cases of metastasised gastrinomas.

Option A: Selective arterial secretin injection

  • This test is rarely advised since it has been demonstrated to be most useful for locating gastrinomas in the head of the pancreas and the proximal duodenum.

Option C: BAO/MAO ratio

  • The BAO/MAO ratio criterion> 0.6 is highly specific for gastrinoma but has a low sensitivity.

Option D: Ultrasound

  • With a sensitivity of 90% for intrapancreatic gastrinomas, endoscopic ultrasonography has also been proven to help detect the primary tumour.
  • Endoscopic ultrasonography is considerably less sensitive for metastatic gastrinomas.

questions.text: A 41-year-old patient comes to see a gastroenterologist complaining of chronic diarrhoea for the last three months. He has no other associated symptoms. There is no history of chronic medical conditions. He only takes naproxen for occasional headaches. His blood pressure is 123/82 mmHg, pulse is 68 beats/min, and BMI is 21kg/m². Physical examination is unremarkable. After considering several differential diagnoses, the physician orders a D-xylose absorption test. What is the principle on which a D-xylose absorption test works?

choices.text: Carbohydrate malabsorption due to mucosal disease
Fat malabsorption due to pancreatic insufficiency
Deficiency of enzymes required for digestion

questions.solution:
Option A: Carbohydrate malabsorption due to mucosal disease

  • D-Xylose is a monosaccharide (a simple sugar) that does not require enzymes for digestion before absorption.
  • Its absorption requires intact mucosa only.
  • In normal individuals, a 25g oral dose of D-xylose will be absorbed and excreted in the urine at approximately 4.5 g in 5 hours.
  • A decreased urinary excretion of D-xylose is seen in small intestine mucosal diseases like celiac and Whipple disease.
  • In contrast, if the D-xylose urinary excretion is normal or elevated, the problem must be due to a non-mucosal cause of malabsorption (e.g., pancreatic insufficiency).
  • The levels of D-xylose in urine would be low in case of small intestinal bacterial overgrowth, as the bacteria would metabolize D-xylose. Hence, it would not be absorbed and excreted in the urine.​​​​​​​

Option B: Fat malabsorption due to pancreatic insufficiency

  • D-xylose is a carbohydrate absorbed through the small intestine's mucosa. The test aims to differentiate between mucosal and non-mucosal causes of malabsorption.
  • It can not specify pancreatic insufficiency as the cause of malabsorption.
  • Decreased faecal elastase is specific for pancreatic insufficiency.​​​​​​​

Option C: Check levels of Intrinsic factor

  • The level of intrinsic factor is measured in case of pernicious anaemia.

Option D: Deficiency of enzymes required for digestion

  • D-xylose test is not used to measure levels of digestive enzymes, as it does not require any digestive enzyme for its absorption.

questions.text: A woman presents with secondary amenorrhea of 4 months duration. She also complains of milk discharge from bilateral breasts. The investigation you should advise apart from serum prolactin levels is:
questions.solution:
Option A : TSH

  • Hyperprolactinemia leads to both Galactorrhea and Amenorrhea.
  • Prolactin secretion is controlled by Prolactin Inhibitor Factor that is secreted from Hypothalamus
  • Vasoactive inhibitory peptide (VIP) and Thyroid releasing hormone (TRH) cause to increase Prolactin secretion.
  • TRH in addition to increasing TSH, causes a rise in prolactin level.
  • In patients with Primary hypothyroidism, increased levels of TRH can cause a rise in prolactin levels.

Option B : LH

  • LH plays no role in regulation of Prolactin

Option C : Urinary ketosteroids

  • Increased levels of 17-ketosteroids may be due to Adrenal gland problems such as tumor, Cushing syndrome, polycystic ovary syndrome, Ovarian cancer, overactive thyroid, obesity, stress
  • Decreased levels of 17-ketosteroids may be due to Addison disease, renal disease, hypopituitarism

Option D : HCG 

  • No role of HCG measurement in prolactin disorders

questions.text: Which of the following genetic abnormalities is associated with the development of hyperkalemia?
questions.solution:
11 beta-hydroxylase deficiency
  • Androgen excess- masculinization of female newborns and precocious puberty in male
  • Hypertension, which may or may not be associated with mineralocorticoid excess, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis
Liddle syndrome
  • AD, hypertension associated with low plasma renin activity, metabolic alkalosis, hypokalemia, and normal to low levels of aldosterone
Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease
  • Since ESRD will ensue in these patients, hyperkalemia will always be a feature of ADPKD
Gitelman syndrome
  • Hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis

questions.text: Glucokinase catalyzes the phosphorylation of glucose to glucose 6-phosphate with a Km for glucose of about 7mM. Blood glucose is 6mM under fasting conditions and can rise in the liver to 21mM after a high-carbohydrate meal. If a person on fasting suddenly eats a high-carbohydrate meal, the velocity of the glucokinase reaction will change as?
questions.solution:
Option C: Increase from <50% Vmax to >50% Vmax

  • This problem can be solved using the Michaelis–Menten equation and comparing the velocity (as a function of maximal velocity) under fasting and non-fasting conditions.
  • Michaelis–Menten equation: V= (Vmax x [S]) / ([S] + Km)

Where,

V= velocity of the reaction.

Vmax= Maximum velocity.

[S]= Substrate concentration.

Km= Michaelis constant.

Given:

  • During fasting, blood glucose conc. [S] = 6 mM, and the Km for glucose = 7 mM;
  • so, v = (Vmax × 6)/ (6 + 7) = 46% Vmax.
  • In the fed state, blood glucose conc. [S] = 21 mM, and the Km for glucose = 7 mM;
  • so, v = (Vmax × 21)/ (21 + 7)  = 75% Vmax.
  • So, Glucokinase is more active in the fed state than in the fasting state, and the velocity will increase from <50% Vmax to >50% Vmax.
  • As calculation shows that the velocity of glucokinase will increase from <50% Vmax to >50% Vmax by increasing the glucose concentration. So, it can be said that Glucokinase is more active in the fed state than in the fasting state.

Option A B and D: Refer to Explanation of C

questions.text:
A patient is being evaluated for jaundice and liver fibrosis. His AST=87 IU/mL and ALT=81 IU/mL. His serological tests are given below. Which of the following is the next step in the diagnosis?


	
		
			IgM Anti- HbcAg
			Non- reactive
		
		
			IgG Anti- HbcAg
			Reactive
		
		
			HbsAg
			Non-Reactive
		
		
			HBeAg
			Non-Reactive
		
		
			Anti-HCV
			Reactive
questions.solution:
Option C: HCV-RNA-RTPCR

  • The serological status of this patient shows HCV infection since the anti-HCV antibody is reactive.
  • Hepatitis B surface antigen is negative, and IgG Anti- HBcAg is reactive, indicating remote infection with hepatitis B.
  • Recovery is the rule in hepatitis B. In contrast, hepatitis C results in the development of Cirrhosis.
  • Even if transaminases are normal, hepatitis C results in long-term damage to the liver.
  • Hence the reason for elevated liver enzymes with the development of liver fibrosis points to HCV being the culprit.
  • The next step shall be to perform a PCR-HCV RNA and initiate treatment based on the prevalent genotype in the area.

Other options

Option A: HBV DNA

  • The presence of HBV DNA in serum is a reliable marker of active HBV replication.
  • HBV DNA levels are detectable by 30 days following infection, generally peak during acute hepatitis, and gradually decrease and disappear when the infection resolves spontaneously.
  • In cases of acute viral hepatitis with equivocal HBsAg test results, testing for HBV DNA in serum may be useful in diagnosing acute HBV infection since HBV DNA can be detected approximately 21 days before HBsAg typically appears in the serum.

Option B: Anti- HbsAg

  • HBsAg is the antigen used to make the hepatitis B vaccine.
  • Hepatitis B surface antibody (anti-HBs): The presence of anti-HBs indicates recovery and immunity from hepatitis B virus infection.
  • Anti-HBs also develop in a person successfully vaccinated against hepatitis B.

Option D: Liver Biopsy

  • A liver biopsy is a test used to diagnose liver conditions. Tissue samples are removed from your liver and checked under a microscope for signs of damage or disease.
  • A liver biopsy can tell if there are cancer cells or other abnormal cells in your liver. It can also tell how well your liver is working.
  • Liver biopsy is ruled out as the question says the patient already has fibrosis.

questions.text: A young female presents to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal distention and swelling in her legs. She has had these symptoms for the past 2 weeks, which have gradually increased in intensity. She also states that she hasn’t been feeling hungry and doesn’t feel like eating anything. She has lost some weight because of that. Physical examination reveals that she is also jaundiced. You diagnose this as a case of Budd Chiari syndrome. The following is the least likely manifestation in an acute case of Budd Chiari syndrome?
questions.solution:
Option D: Venous collaterals

  • Budd Chiari Syndrome (BCS) is a disease caused by the obstruction of hepatic veins.
  • Obstruction of two or more major hepatic veins produces BCS.
  • Obstruction of a single main hepatic vein by thrombosis is clinically silent.
  • The most common cause of hepatic vein obstruction is thrombosis of the hepatic vein.
  • BCS is characterized by right upper quadrant pain, ascites and hepatomegaly.
  • BCS can be fulminant, acute, chronic, or asymptomatic. Subacute is the most common form.
  • Long-term blockage leads to the formation of venous collaterals around the occlusion.
  • These are formed due to portal hypertension.
  • Venous collaterals are only seen in chronic disease.
  • These are not formed in acute forms.

Option A: Enlarged tender liver

  • Liver enlargement occurs in acute settings of this disease.

Option B: Ascites

  • Ascites occur in acute settings of this disease.

Option C: Jaundice

  • Jaundice is one of the first findings in many liver diseases.
  • Jaundice will be present in acute BCS.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female who had nacho cheese the night before presented to the emergency department with complaints of diplopia, followed by dyspnoea, chest tightness, congestion and dysphagia. The patient was resuscitated, and initial investigations were done. The edrophonium tensilon test and lumbar puncture came out to be negative. The botulinum toxin test was positive. The most potent toxin produced in the given condition is?
questions.solution:
Option A: Botulinum Toxin A

  • Eight antigenically distinct Clostridium botulinum toxins are known: A, B, C (alpha), C (beta), D, E, F, and G.
  • Types A, B, E and rarely F cause human disease.
  • Toxins A and B are the most potent, and consuming small amounts of food contaminated with these types has resulted in full-blown disease.
  • During the last 20 years, toxin A has been the most common cause of food-borne outbreaks; toxins B and E follow in frequency.

Option B: Botulinum Toxin C

  • Toxin C causes disease in various animals.

Option C: Botulinum Toxin D

  • Toxin D causes disease in various animals.

Option D: Botulinum Toxin F

  • Toxin F can rarely cause human disease

questions.text: A 37-year-old patient is admitted to the ward and diagnosed with cerebral malaria. Which of the following findings would not be expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Bloody CSF

  • Bloody CSF is seen in subarachnoid haemorrhage and herpes encephalitis.
  • Cerebral malaria manifests as diffuse symmetric encephalopathy
  • Focal neurological signs are unusual.
  • Seizures are usually generalised and often repeated.
  • On Routine Fundoscopy following findings are found:
    • Discrete spots of retinal opacification (30-60%)
    • Retinal haemorrhage
    • Papilledema

Option B: Retinal haemorrhages

  • Retinal haemorrhages are frequently observed in cerebral malaria, retinal opacification, and papilledema.

Option C: Extensor plantar reflex

  • Exaggerated tendon reflexes and bilateral planter extensors demonstrate symmetrical upper motor neuron damage, the most prevalent neurological manifestation.

Option D: Absent abdominal reflex

  • Ankle and patellar clonus, as well as extensor plantar reflexes, may be exaggerated by cerebral malaria. However, the abdominal and cremasteric reflexes are always absent.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female presents with fever and cough for four days. The cough produces yellowish sputum, and she has no chronic illnesses. Respiratory auscultation reveals bilateral coarse crackles. She took paracetamol for fever relief. If used therapeutically, what's true about the drug's termination of action?

choices.text: Paracetamol must only be excreted from the body to terminate its action
Metabolism of drugs always abolishes their pharmacologic activity
Hepatic metabolism and renal excretion are the two most important mechanisms involved
Distribution of the drug out of the bloodstream terminates its effects

questions.solution:
Option C: Hepatic metabolism and renal excretion are the two most important mechanisms involved

  • This is a case of pneumonia in which the patient presents with complaints of fever and productive cough for four days. She further explains that she coughs up yellowish-coloured sputum.
  • On respiratory auscultation, the patient has bilateral coarse crackles.
  • Acetaminophen is a commonly used over-the-counter NSAID medication for pain due to various etiologies. When given in the therapeutic dosage range, it undergoes hepatic metabolism into glucuronides & sulphates and later is excreted outside the body via the renal system. On overdose, there is noted hepatotoxicity due to the metabolite NAPQI.
  • The action of a drug can be terminated either by hepatic metabolism or by renal excretion. Other pathways, like excretion in sweat or saliva, play minor roles.

 

Option A: Drugs must be excreted from the body to terminate their action

  • Acetaminophen has renal excretion.
  • But its action is terminated after hepatic metabolism.
  • So, it doesn't require excretion from the body for the termination of its action.

 

Option B: Metabolism of drugs always abolishes their pharmacologic activity

  • Most of the drugs are inactivated by metabolism. However, some drugs may be activated from inactive form (prodrugs), and others may produce active metabolites.

 

Option D: Distribution of a drug out of the bloodstream terminates the drug’s effects

  • Some drugs may act away from blood, e.g. digoxin leaves the bloodstream and enters the heart to produce its action.

questions.text: Which receptors do the adrenergic agonists act upon in a patient with glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Option D: α2 receptor

  • Based on the symptoms and signs in the scenario, the most likely diagnosis is glaucoma, and the adrenergic agonists act on the α2 receptors to reduce the aqueous secretion.
  • The α2-agonists reduce intraocular pressure by decreasing the production of aqueous humour by the ciliary body.
  • They also constrict tiny blood vessels on the eyeball's surface and reduce the eye's redness.
  • α2-agonists generally used in glaucoma are :
    • Apraclonidine
    • Brimonidine

Option A: β1 receptor

  • Based on the symptoms and signs in the scenario, the most likely diagnosis is glaucoma, and the adrenergic agonists do not act on the β1 receptors to reduce the aqueous secretion.
  • Beta-agonists bind to the β-receptors on cardiac and smooth muscle tissues.
  • They also have important actions in other tissues, especially bronchial smooth muscle (relaxation), the liver (stimulate glycogenolysis), and kidneys (stimulate renin release).
  • E.g.,
    • Denopamine β1 agonist
    • Dobutamine β1>β2 agonist
    • Xamoterol β1 partial agonist

Option B: β2 receptor

  • Based on the symptoms and signs in the scenario, the most likely diagnosis is glaucoma, and the adrenergic agonists do not act on the β2 receptors to reduce the aqueous secretion.
  • Beta-agonists bind to the β-receptors on cardiac and smooth muscle tissues.
  • Beta-2 adrenergic receptor agonists are a class of medications used in the frontline management and treatment of bronchial asthma and COPD
  • For example:
    • Salbutamol (albuterol)
    • Terbutaline
    • Salmeterol

Option C: M2 receptor

  • Based on the symptoms and signs in the scenario, the most likely diagnosis is glaucoma, and the adrenergic agonists do not act on the β2 receptors to reduce the aqueous secretion.
  • Muscarinic agonists are parasympathomimetic drugs and are indicated for ileus, urinary retention, glaucoma, Alzheimer disease, and other symptoms.
  • Muscarinic receptor agonist lessens the intraocular pressure of glaucoma mainly by stimulating ciliary muscle contraction and then increasing the aqueous outflow. For example: Pilocarpine

questions.text: An anaesthetist is giving a lecture on different types of blocks. He explains the different surgical procedures and types of anaesthesia used for them. One type of anaesthesia is intravenous regional anaesthesia. It is most suitable for which of the following procedures?

choices.text: Orthopedic manipulation on the upper limb
Vascular surgery on the lower limb

questions.solution:
Option A: Orthopaedic manipulation on the upper limb

  • Intravenous regional anaesthesia (IVRA), also known as Bier’s block, is indicated for procedures on an upper limb or rarely the lower limb of less than one-hour duration.
  • It consists of injection of local anaesthetic (LA) in the vein of the tourniquet occluded limb
  • Drug diffuses from vascular bed to non-vascular tissue such as nerve endings.
  • Regional anaesthesia is produced in 2-5 min and lasts for a minute after deflating the tourniquet
  • Bupivacaine should never be used because of its cardiotoxicity.

Option B: Vascular surgery on the lower limb

  • It is more difficult to obstruct the blood supply of lower limbs, and a larger volume of anaesthetic is required. Hence, Bier’s block is not typically used for lower limb procedures.

Option C: Head and neck surgery

  • It is mainly used for upper limb and orthopaedic procedures. General anaesthesia is given for head and neck surgery

Option D: Caesarean section

  • Spinal anaesthesia is preferred for a Caesarean section than Intravenous regional anaesthesia.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used in treatment of Congestive heart failure and can cause vasodilation and increased cardiac output?
questions.solution:
Option C: Amrinone

  • This is a case of congestive heart failure.
  • Amrinone is a bipyridine compound that inhibits phosphodiesterase isozyme-3 (PDE3).
  • The two most important actions of amrinone are positive inotropy and direct vasodilatation.
  • It is also known as an inodilator which increases myocardial contractility by increasing inward calcium influx in the heart during action potential and brings about vasodilatation.
  • In CHF patients, it increases left ventricular ejection fraction and decreases peripheral vascular resistance, central venous pressure, left ventricular end-diastolic volume and pressure.
  • It is used as a short-term therapy in severe and refractory CHF.

Option A: Spironolactone

  • Spironolactone is an aldosterone antagonist considered to be one of the potassium-sparing diuretics.
  • Its principal action in heart failure is to reduce venous pressure and ventricular preload.
  • It decreases preload and improves ventricular efficiency by reducing circulating volume.
  • It decreases morbidity and mortality in patients with severe heart failure.

Option B: Amiodarone

  • Amiodarone is included in class III antiarrhythmics that prolong the duration of action potential and the refractory period by blocking K+ channels.
  • It is effective in the treatment of severe refractory supraventricular and ventricular tachyarrhythmias.

Option D: Carvedilol

  • Carvedilol is a non-selective beta blocker and selective alpha-1 blocking agent.
  • It is indicated in mild to moderate CHF.
  • The immediate hemodynamic action of β blockers is to depress cardiac contractility and ejection fraction.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of frequent episodes of renal colic indicating pain due to kidney stones. The stones appeared similar to calcium oxalate renal stones. Which of the following is the most useful diuretic in the treatment of recurrent calcium stones?
questions.solution:
Option C: Hydrochlorthiazide

  • Thiazides cause hypercalcemia by decreasing the renal excretion of Ca2+.
  • These are useful in a patient having hypercalciuria.
  • In such a patient, thiazides decrease the excretion of Ca2+ in the kidney and thus reduce the chances of stone formation.

​​​​​​​

Option A: Furosemide

  • Furosemide increases calcium excretion in the urine; therefore, these are not given in kidney stones due to hypercalciuria.

Option B: Spironolactone

  • Spironolactone does not regulate calcium excretion.
  • Therefore, it has no role in kidney stones.

Option D: Acetazolamide

  • Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor.
  • Carbonic anhydrase catalyzes the dehydration of H2CO3 to CO2 at the luminal membrane and the rehydration of CO2 to H2CO3 in the cytoplasm.
  • By blocking carbonic anhydrase, inhibitors blunt NaHCO3 reabsorption and cause diuresis.
  • It has no role in calcium reabsorption or excretion.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man was brought to the emergency with sudden onset of chest pain for the past 20 minutes. He had no history of hypertension, heart disease, or diabetes mellitus. He was kept under treatment, followed by tests for further investigation. Which drugs can cause hypotension by releasing histamine from mast cells?
questions.solution:
Option C: Morphine

  • Drugs that release histamine from mast cells:

    • Basic drugs like Morphine, d-TC (Tubocurarine), Amphotericin B, Pentamidine, Polymyxin B, Vancomycin, atropine, and some antihistamines (by displacing it from the binding site). Act as histamine liberators and can cause an acute reaction leading to itching, burning sensation, flushing, urticaria, hypotension, tachycardia, headache, colic, and asthma.

    • Opioids cause mast cells to release histamine, which has a number of unfavourable effects, like hypotension, urticaria, pruritus, and tachycardia.

    • Although it is known that this opiate response is non-immunological, the mechanism by which it occurs has remained a mystery. The pharmacology of opiate-induced histamine release from mast cells is different from that of known opiate receptors, according to a review of the histamine-releasing properties of various opiates. There is no proof that functional opiate receptors cause opiate-induced histamine release, despite the possibility that they exist on mast cells and may be able to control IgE-mediated histamine release.

    • Morphine and endogenous opiates are also thought to release histamine from mast cells by directly activating G-proteins.

Option A: Aspirin

  • The stimulation of IgE-mediated histamine release by NSAIDs may be one potential factor contributing to the worsening of symptoms in individuals with chronic urticaria since aspirin increased basophil histamine release through increased Syk kinase activation.

  • As a result, giving aspirin to such patients leads to worsening symptoms of urticaria. However, hypotension is not seen.

Option B: Procaine

  • Morphine act as histamine liberators and can trigger an allergic reaction that results in hives, asthma, colic, urticaria, flushing, hypotension, and tachycardia.

  • Procaine doesn't cause hypotension.

Option D: Sulfadiazine

  • Hypotension is not seen in Sulfadiazine.

questions.text: What treatment is recommended for a 45-year-old male with schizophrenia who developed fever, diarrhea, confusion, high blood pressure, rapid pulse, muscle rigidity, hyperkalemia, and increased creatine kinase after 8 days of haloperidol treatment?
questions.solution:
Option C: Dantrolene

  • The patient has a history of schizophrenia and has recently started using haloperidol. Haloperidol is a first-generation (conventional) antipsychotic that works by competitive blockade of dopamine D2 receptors.
  • The signs and symptoms of generalized muscle rigidity, hyperthermia, autonomic instability (labile blood pressure, diarrhoea, and tachycardia), and altered mental status; associated with antipsychotics are indicative of neuroleptic malignant syndrome. 
  • The neuroleptic malignant syndrome can result in (as in this case) elevation of serum potassium and creatine kinase due to vigorous muscle contraction.
  • The management plan for the neuroleptic malignant syndrome includes:
    • Prompt discontinuation of the antipsychotic drug (haloperidol in this case)
    • Supportive care includes assessing and maintaining the airway, breathing, and circulation.
    • Pharmacotherapy comprises the use of dantrolene. Dantrolene is an antagonist of the Ryanodine receptor and works by preventing the release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum of skeletal muscle cells. This leads to a decrease in the magnitude of muscle rigidity, and resultantly hyperthermia is inhibited too.

Option A: Diazepam

  • Diazepam belongs to the benzodiazepine class of drugs.
  • Benzodiazepines can help relieve psychomotor agitation in such cases; however, dantrolene is the pharmacotherapy of choice for managing neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

Option B: Flumazenil

  • Flumazenil is used to treat the toxicity of benzodiazepines. It is not used in the management of the neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

Option D: High dose of haloperidol

  • The patient’s current signs and symptoms are already caused by the adverse reaction to haloperidol. So, the management includes discontinuation of this drug.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presents with amenorrhea, infertility, and galactorrhoea. She is treated with a drug that successfully restored ovulation and menstruation. She is advised to take the drug orally. What is the drug used to treat this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Cabergoline

  • The symptoms of the patient's amenorrhea, galactorrhea and infertility point towards the diagnosis of hyperprolactinemia.
  • Prolactin hormone produced by the pituitary gland causes the breast to develop, especially during pregnancy and is also responsible for lactation.
  • Hyperprolactinemia is a condition of elevated serum prolactin levels.
  • Some causes of hyperprolactinemia are pregnancy, nursing, Chronic renal or hepatic failures, medications, e.g., antipsychotics, tumours, e.g., prolactinoma, hypothyroidism, stress etc. Pregnancy
  • Some symptoms of hyperprolactinemia include milky nipple discharge, menstrual irregularities (amenorrhea), vaginal dryness, fertility problems, headaches, erectile dysfunction, loss of sexual desires etc.
  • Cabergoline, a dopamine agonist, is used to treat hyperprolactinemia. It can treat menstrual irregularities and fertility problems.
  • It is an ergot medication that blocks the release of prolactin from the pituitary gland.
  • It is stopped when prolactin levels are normal for 6 months.

Option B: Desmopressin

  • Desmopressin is a synthetic analogue of vasopressin.
  • It treats diabetes insipidus, nocturnal enuresis, haemophilia A, and von Willebrand disease.

Option C: Human gonadotropin hormone

  • Human gonadotropin hormone (hCG) is a hormone produced by syncytiotrophoblastic cells of the placenta.
  • It is combined with other fertility drugs to treat hypogonadism and infertility.

Option D: Leuprolide

  • Leuprolide is a synthetic analogue of the gonadotropin-releasing hormone.
  • It is used to manage and treat prostate cancer, endometriosis, uterine fibroids, precocious puberty, etc.

questions.text:
A researcher investigates the features of cancer cells in a laboratory. He studies the proliferation of cells in malignant neoplasms and their changes to cause local invasion and metastasis. He closely observes the role of epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT ) in tumour cells. Which of the following is/are incorrectly describes the purpose of epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) in cancer cells?


	Controlled by the transcription factors SNAIL and TWIST
	Upregulation of E-cadherin expression
	Integral to the metastasis of carcinomas
	Homotypic intercellular adhesion is lost
questions.solution:
The statement that incorrectly describes the purpose of epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) in cancer cells is:

b. Upregulation of E-cadherin expression

Explanation of the correct and incorrect options:

a. Controlled by the transcription factors SNAIL and TWIST: This is correct. EMT is controlled by transcription factors like SNAIL, TWIST, and others that suppress epithelial markers and promote the mesenchymal phenotype.

b. Upregulation of E-cadherin expression: This is incorrect. EMT typically involves the downregulation of E-cadherin expression, which is a hallmark of EMT. E-cadherin is a key epithelial cell adhesion molecule.

c. Integral to the metastasis of carcinomas: This is correct. EMT is indeed integral to the process of metastasis in carcinomas. It allows cancer cells to acquire a more invasive and migratory phenotype, which is crucial for metastatic spread.

d. Homotypic intercellular adhesion is lost: This is correct. EMT often results in the loss of homotypic (like-to-like) intercellular adhesion, as epithelial cells transition to a more individual and migratory mesenchymal phenotype.

questions.text: Which of the following organelles play a role in the process of apoptosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Mitochondria

  • Apoptosis is the programmed cell death that occurs in multicellular organisms.
  • It is characterized by the following:
    • Blebbing
    • Cell shrinkage
    • Nuclear fragmentation
    • Chromatin condensation
    • DNA fragmentation
    • mRNA decay
  • Apoptosis is a highly regulated and controlled process.
  • It can be initiated through:
    • Intrinsic pathway
    • Extrinsic pathway
  • The intrinsic pathway is also known as the mitochondrial pathway.
  • Cytochrome c is released from the mitochondria by proteins Bax and Bak.
  • Cytochrome c binds with apoptotic protease activating factor-1 (Apaf-1) and ATP.
  • This combination further binds to pro-caspase-9 to create a protein complex called an apoptosome.
  • This apoptosome cleaves the pro-caspase to its active form, which initiates apoptosis.
  • Mitochondria play a central role in the intrinsic pathway of apoptosis.

Option A: Cytoplasm

  • Caspases are present in the cytoplasm of cells.
  • Mitochondria play a central role in the intrinsic pathway of apoptosis.

Option B: Golgi complex

  • Mitochondria play a central role in the intrinsic pathway of apoptosis.
  • The Golgi apparatus is not involved in this process.

Option D: Nucleus

  • Mitochondria play a central role in the intrinsic pathway of apoptosis.
  • Activation of necrosis results in nuclear fragmentation.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl comes to the outpatient department complaining of having a very depressing feeling and being short-tempered with a loss of appetite as her father died of liver failure one month back. She feels moody and won't join others, so she thinks about joining her father. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Option B: Grief

    • Feeling depressed, mood changes and longing after the death of a loved one are all suggestive of grief.
    • It is a natural response after losing something or someone important to you.
    • One may feel a variety of emotions as sadness or loneliness.
    • It could be due to the loss of some beloved one's death, a breakup, or a failure in life.
    • One suffering from grief can face several issues, like digestive problems, headaches, and lower immunity.
    • There are seven stages of grief,
  2. Shock
  3. Denial
  4. Anger
  5. Bargaining
  6. Depression
  7. Acceptance and hope
  8. Processing grief
  • Normal grief: Up to 6 months.
  • Complicated grief: Prolonged grief with intense emotions.

 

 

Option A: Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder

  • Failure to recover after an encounter or witnessing a terrifying event
  • Symptoms include re-experiencing trauma in the form of flashbacks, vivid memories, nightmares or avoidance, and other hyperarousal symptoms
  • Since no such symptoms are described in the question, this case cannot be diagnosed as PTSD.

Option C: Depression

  • It is a mood disorder.
  • Persistent feelings of sadness and loss of interest.

Option D: Bipolar Disorder

  • It is a mood disorder
  • Several episodes of mood swings ranging from depressive lows to manic highs.

questions.text: ICD-10 suggests including anxious, preoccupied, or "dreamy" apathetic children whose problems are probably different also under Hyperkinetic disorders. Which of the following is not seen in a hyperkinetic child?
questions.solution:
Option C: Left to right disorientation

  • "Left to right disorientation" is a word used to describe a complete inability to identify left from right, a common symptom of Gerstmann's illness.

  • Gerstmann's syndrome is characterized by damage to the parietal lobe's angular gyrus.

  • A stroke in this area of the brain is the most common cause.

  • In ADHD, "left-to-right discrimination" difficulties can also be found.

  • The best answer here would be left-to-right disorientation.

Option A: Aggressive outbursts

  • Aggressive outburst is a feature of ADHD.

Option B: Decreased attention span

  • One of the hyperkinetic disordersis ADHD.

  • It is characterized by decreased attention span.

Option D: Soft neurological signs

  • Soft neurological signs are poor motor coordination, sensory perceptual difficulties, and involuntary movements.

  • They are seen in hyperkinetic disorder

questions.text: Operant conditioning in which pain stimulus are given to a child for decreasing a certain undesired behavior can be classified as:
questions.solution:
• Punishment is decrease in frequency of a behavior due to unpleasant consequences.
  • Positive reinforcement - Frequency of behavior increases because it leads to positive consequences.
  • Negative reinforcement - Frequency of behavior increases as it is followed by negative consequence.eg cleaning room to avoid scolding.
  • All above three are types of operant conditioning.

HOW TO REMEMBER: reInforcement Increase frequency of behaviour while punishment pushes down the frequency.

questions.text: Autopsy reports of a 45-year-old man found dead in his farmhouse, describe a wound that is approximately square-shaped and 5x5 cm by dimension. The forensic expert safely assumes that the shape of the wound indicates the weapon used, which was likely a hammer found with blood stains in the shed behind the house. Further investigation of the wound confirms that it is indeed a "fracture ala signature" In simpler terms, how would you document this finding?
questions.solution:
Option B: Depressed fracture

  • When a portion of a fractured bone is driven inwards to a distance equivalent to the thickness of the skull table, it is known as a depressed fracture.
  • It is also called ‘fracture ala signature’ (signature fracture), as the shape often points towards the shape of the offending weapon.
  • They are caused by blows with a heavy weapon having a small striking surface, such as a hammer, axe, brick or chopper.

Option A: Gutter fracture

  • A gutter fracture is formed when part of the thickness of the bone is removed so as to form a gutter, e.g. oblique bullet wounds.
  • It is usually accompanied by comminuted depressed fracture of the inner table of the skull, and the fragments causing injury to the meninges and brain.

Option C: Ring fracture

  • Ring fracture: Fracture around the foramen magnum.
  • It is associated with falling from a height & landing on the foot.
  • All the force is transmitted from the leg and vertebral column to the base of the skull.

Option D: Sutural Fracture

  • Sutural separation due to blow on the skull [fracture lines run along the sutural line].
  • It is also known as a diastatic fracture.
  • Most commonly seen in young adults.
  • The most common suture involved is the sagittal suture.

questions.text: A 45-year-old laborer was admitted with complaints of multiple sinuses discharging foul-smelling pus in the lower jaw bone. The man was employed at a firework factory. While taking a history of his presenting complaints, the doctor was informed that it had begun with toothache about 6 months prior. He had treated himself with over-the-counter pain medication. Gradually he had noticed the swelling of his jaw and also lost 2 teeth in the 6 months since symptoms began. This is caused by which one of the following?
questions.solution:
Option C: Phosphorus

  • The frequent inhalation of fumes over a period of years causes necrosis of the lower jaw in the region of a decayed tooth.
  • The vapors act on the jaw through a carious tooth or an interspace due to a missing tooth where suppurative microorganisms are already present.
  • At first, there is a toothache, which is followed by swelling of the jaw, loosening of the teeth, necrosis of gums, and sequestration of bone in the mandible. This condition is known as 'phossy jaw' (glass jaw) in which osteomyelitis and necrosis of the jaw occur, with multiple sinuses discharging foul-smelling pus.

Option A: Lead

  • A: Anaemia
  • B: Burtonian line/Basophilic stippling, Bone lines
  • C: Colic, Constipation (dry belly ache)
  • D: Drop (wrist/Foot drop) - Lead palsy
  • E: Encephalopathy
  • F: Facial pallor (earliest sign)
  • G: Gout (saturnine gout)
  • H: Hypertension
  • I: Impotence

Option B: Mercury

  • Chronic exposure to elemental mercury yields a classic triad of gingivitis and salivation, tremors, and neuropsychiatric changes. The symptoms are salivation, inflammation of gums and occasionally a blue line at their junction with teeth, sore mouth and throat, loosening of teeth, gastrointestinal disturbances, anemia, anorexia, loss of weight, and chronic inflammation of kidneys with progressive uremia. Tremors (sometimes called Danbury tremors) occur first in the hands, then progress to lips and tongue, and finally involve arms and legs. The tremor is moderately coarse and is interspersed with jerky movements. The advanced condition is called hatter's shakes or glass-blower's shakes because they are common in persons working in glass-blowing and hat industries.
  • Mercurial erethism is seen in persons working with mercury in minor manufacturing firms. This term is used to refer to the psychological effects of mercury toxicity.
  • Mercurialent is: It is a peculiar eye change due to exposure to mercury vapor.
  • Acrodynia or pink disease (because it is characterized by a generalized body rash) is thought to be an idiosyncratic hypersensitivity reaction particularly seen in children. This can be caused by chronic mercury exposure in any form.
  • Minimata disease is a type of organic mercurial poisoning due to eating of fish poisoned by mercury.

Option D: Arsenic

  • Clinical Features of Chronic Arsenic poisoning:
    • GIT symptoms: Loss of weight, malaise, loss of appetite, salivation, colicky pain, diarrhea, and vomiting.
    • Liver: Hepatomegaly, jaundice, cirrhosis
    • Skin symptoms: Usually begin with a persistent erythematous flush leading to hyperkeratotic skin and desquamation. Hyperkeratosis is most prominent in the distal parts of the body. Pigmentation is patchy (raindrops pigmentation). Skin cancer (Squamous cell carcinoma and basal cell carcinoma) also occurs.
    • Nails: Aldrich Mees lines (transverse white striae of the fingernails) may also be seen.
    • Hairs: Alopecia occurs
    • Hematological: Anemia, leukopenia, Thrombocytopenia, and Bone marrow hypoplasia are seen. Anemia is normocytic and normochromic
    • Peripheral neuropathy: Sensory and motor polyneuritis (sensory symptoms usually predominate) manifesting as numbness and tingling in a ‘stocking glove’ distribution.
    • Blackfoot disease: Due to platelet activation and hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries.
    • Encephalopathy
    • Nephritis

questions.text: A 27-year-old man comes to the office because of weakness in both legs for a day. Two weeks ago, he had a 4-day bout of gastroenteritis, and yesterday he developed burning sensations in his toes. Examination shows facial flushing, a systolic blood pressure range of 70-160 mm Hg, profuse diaphoresis, and bilateral facial paralysis. Lumbar puncture shows a normal white cell count and elevated protein. He is treated with plasma exchange and intravenous immunoglobulin and steadily recovers over three months.Which of the following most similarly describes the type of hypersensitivity reaction that caused this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer 

Option B: Type II hypersensitivity

  • The patient's presentation is consistent with Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS), a neurological disorder characterized by progressive muscle weakness and often ascending paralysis. Given the clinical details provided, the hypersensitivity reaction that caused this patient's condition is Type II Hypersensitivity Reaction.

    Type II hypersensitivity reactions involve the activation of antibodies (IgG or IgM) against specific antigens present on cell surfaces or in tissues. In Guillain-Barré syndrome, the immune system mistakenly targets the peripheral nerves, leading to demyelination and impaired nerve conduction. The autoantibodies target components of the peripheral nerve myelin, causing nerve damage and subsequent weakness and paralysis.

 

Option A: Type 1 hypersensitivity

  • This option is incorrect 

Option C: Type 3 hypersensitivity

  • This option is incorrect

Option D: Type 4 hypersensitivity

  • This option is incorrect

questions.text: How many ATPs are produced when NADH is transported from the cytoplasm to mitochondria through a malate shuttle and used in the electron transport chain?
questions.solution:
Option D: 2.5

  • The substrates for ETC i.e., NADH cannot cross the mitochondrial membrane. So, it have to be transported by using shuttles.
  • There are two types of shuttles in the cell, i.e., the Malate-aspartate shuttle and the Glycerol-phosphate shuttle.
  • The Glycerol phosphate shuttle is present in brown adipose tissue, while the Malate-aspartate shuttle is present in the rest of the body.
  • In Malate shuttle, an enzyme called transaminase transfers the amino group from aspartate, converting it into oxaloacetate.
  • Then an enzyme, Malate dehydrogenase, converts oxaloacetate to Malate the electrons in the NADH are used here.
  • The Malate formed is transferred to mitochondria as it can move across the membrane.
  • In mitochondria, it is oxidised back to oxaloacetate by mitochondrial MDH, and electrons are transferred to NAD+ to form NADH.
  • This NADH is used in ETC to generate a proton gradient and finally this proton gradient is used by an enzyme ATP synthase to give 2.5 ATPs (See fig).

Option A: 1

  • 1 ATP is not formed in any of the shuttles.

Option B: 1.5 ATP

In Glycerol-3-P shuttle:

  • NADH in the cytoplasm reaches mitochondria as FADH2.
  • So, in mitochondria, instead of NADH, FADH2 enters ETC, making only 1.5 ATPs.

Option C: 2

  • 2 ATPs are not formed in any of the shuttles

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins can be given as a remedial measure for patients with type 2B familial hyperlipidemia?
questions.solution:
Option C: Nicotinic acid

  • Type 2B familial hyperlipidemia is characterized by increased plasma LDL and VLDL causing increased TG and cholesterol.
  • It can be treated by giving nicotinic acid (Vit B3) in high doses, which is antihyperlipidemic. It inhibits hormone-sensitive lipase, so triglycerides from adipose tissue are not broken down, and free fatty acids do not reach the blood and liver. This leads to ↓ VLDL and ↓ LDL. HDL levels ↑ due to a decrease in their catabolic rate.
Treatment option for
Increased TG Increased cholesterol
  • Fibrates
  • Omega-3 FAs
  • High dose Nicotinic acid
  • Statins
  • Bile acid sequestrants
  • LDL apharesis (selective removal of LDL from blood)

Option A: Pantothenic acid

  • Vitamin B5, known as pantothenic acid, is important for blood cell production.
  • It converts protein and carbohydrates into energy.
  • It increases glutathione levels and protects cells from peroxidative damage.

Option B: Riboflavin

  • Vitamin B2, also known as riboflavin used in redox reactions through cofactor flavin adenine dinucleotide.
  • It is a water-soluble vitamin.
  • Riboflavin deficiency causes glossitis, stomatitis, normocytic anemia, and corneal revascularization.

Option D: Thiamine

  • Vitamin B1 is also known as thiamine.
  • Thiamin is also water-soluble.
  • Thiamine deficiency causes Beri-Beri, lactic acidosis and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome in chronic alcoholics.

questions.text: A patient presented to casualty with nausea and vomiting. Intravenous glucose was given & the patient recovered. After a few months, the patient presented with the same complaints, along with increased blood glutamine and elevated uracil levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Ornithine transcarbamoylase deficiency

  • In the urea cycle, ammonia combines with carbon dioxide and forms carbamoyl phosphate. The carbamoyl phosphate combines with ornithine and forms citrulline. The enzyme responsible for the reaction is carbamoyl phosphate synthase and ornithine carbamoyl transferase, respectively.
  • If the enzyme ornithine transcarbamoylase is deficient, it leads to elevated levels of ammonia in the blood and carbamoyl phosphate from in liver mitochondria .
  • The excess carbamoyl phosphate from mitochondria enters the cytoplasm and takes part in pyrimidine synthesis leading to increased uracil synthesis (see fig).
  • Orotic acid, OMP, and UMP are all increased in OTC defect.

  • Ornithine transcarbamoylase deficiency presents with the symptoms of refusal to eat, vomiting, lethargy, irritability, seizures, etc.
  • It is an X-linked recessive disorder. It is the most common urea cycle disorder.
  • It is characterized by decreased levels of blood urea nitrogen.
  • CPS-II (carbamoyl phosphate synthetase-II) is an enzyme involved in pyrimidine synthesis, not in the urea cycle.

Choice A: CPS-I deficiency

  • CPS-I enzyme is involved in the urea cycle. It is present in the mitochondria.
  • It leads to elevated ammonia levels in the blood, which can have toxic effects on the brain.
  • It does not lead to elevated levels of orotic acids in the blood.

Choice B: Arginosuccinate synthetase deficiency

  • Arginosuccinate synthase enzyme is a part of the urea cycle. It is involved in the synthesis of argininosuccinate via the enzyme argininosuccinate synthase.
  • If citrulline is increased, then it means that Arginosuccinate synthetase is the deficient enzyme.

Choice C: CPS-II deficiency

  • CPS-II is involved in the de novo synthesis of pyrimidine.
  • It is activated by ATP and is inhibited by UMP.
  • ​​​​​​​Its deficiency is associated with the decreased synthesis of pyrimidine.

questions.text: A community has a total population of 10,000. children ranging from 0-6 years old are 2000. Literate people aged > 7 years are 4000. What is the effective literacy rate?
questions.solution:
Option C: 50%

  • A Person is deemed literate if he or she can read and write with understanding in any language.
  • An effective literacy rate is the total number of literates aged 7 and above divided by the total population aged 7 and above.
  • Effective literacy rate (ELR) = no. of literates / Total population > 7 years age × 100

In the given question,

  • Total population = 10000
  • Population 0-6 years age = 2000
  • So, the population > 7 years age = 10000-2000 = 8000.

Effective literacy rate (ELR) = no. of literates / Total population > 7 years age × 100

  • ELR = 4000/8000 X 100 = 50%

questions.text: A rural village population was asked to consume iodized salt to stay protected against illness due to iodine deficiency. What is the daily total requirement of iodine by an adult person?
questions.solution:
Option C: 150 mcg

  • According to recent national guidelines for RDA, the Daily total requirement for Iodine is 150 mcg per day for both males and females.
  • Recommended daily allowance for pregnant women is 250 mcg per day.
  • Recommended daily allowance for lactating mother's is 280 mcg per day.

questions.text: A 33-year-old male develops nephrotic range proteinuria. He has a history of radiologically confirmed reflux nephropathy. He has no other chronic medical condition and does not take any medication. The results of the immunofluorescence testing are pending. Which of the following is the most likely working diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis

  • It is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults.
  • Sclerosis is seen in only a segment of the glomerulus.
  • It is associated with the following conditions:
  • HIV infection
  • Reflux nephropathy
  • Sickle cell disease.
  • The patient presents with nephrotic range proteinuria too.

Option B: Minimal change of disease

It is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children.

  • The ailment might be idiopathic or have a trigger, like:
  • Immunization
  •  Infection

Option C: Henoch Schönlein purpura

  • The symptoms of Henoch Schönlein purpura (HSP) include:
  • Intestinal haemorrhage and discomfort in the abdomen; purpuric skin sores; joint-related symptoms
  • Immunofluorescent microscopy: IgA deposits in the mesangial area, occasionally together with C3 and IgG.

Option D: Alport syndrome

  • The following are characteristics of Alport syndrome:
  • Errors in the gene that codes for the type IV collagen α5 chain.
  • The clinical signs include kidney, ear, and eye-related abnormalities.
  • The BM's distinctive basket-weave appearance.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old male presents to the outpatient department due to a progressive cough for 1 week. The cough is productive with yellow-coloured sputum and is associated with severe dyspnea and weight loss. He has smoked 3-pack per day of cigarettes for 50 years. A chest x-ray showed bullae formation in the upper lobes. Spirometry revealed decreased FEV1 and FVC. The image below shows the microscopic picture of the patient's lung condition:

 



Which of the following types of pathology shown above is most likely to be associated with cigarette smoking?
questions.solution:
Option B: Centriacinar

 

 

 

Explanation: Centriacinar emphysema is the most common type of emphysema associated with smoking cigarettes. It primarily affects the central or proximal parts of the acinus, which includes the respiratory bronchioles and the surrounding alveoli. Smoking-induced inflammation and destruction of lung tissue typically start in the centriacinar region.

The other types of emphysema listed are as follows:

Option A. Panacinar emphysema: This type involves the entire acinus and is commonly associated with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, not smoking.

Option C. Distal acinar emphysema: This type affects the distal parts of the acinus and is associated with certain environmental exposures.

Option D. Irregular emphysema: This type is characterized by irregularly shaped areas of emphysema and can have various underlying causes.

In a patient with a history of smoking and the described findings of bullae formation in the upper lobes, centriacinar emphysema is the most likely pathology.

questions.text: Four members of the same family were burnt to death when their hut caught fire, allegedly from embers that had been blown around from the bonfire they had lit earlier that evening to warm themselves. The bodies were seen with their hips and knees flexed. Their hands were held in a defensive pose and with clenched fists. This posture in burn victims is due to which of the following?

choices.text: Coagulation of proteins and present in ante-morterm burn
Coagulation of proteins and present in post-morterm burn
Coagulation of proteins and present in both ante-mortem and post-mortem burn

questions.solution:
Option C: Coagulation of proteins and present in both ante-morterm and post-morterm burn

  • The posture described in burn victims with their hips flexed at the hip and knees and their hands held in a defensive pose with clenched fists is commonly referred to as the "pugilistic attitude" or "pugilistic posture."
  • This posture occurs due to the coagulation of proteins in the muscles and soft tissues.
  • It is typically seen in burn victims, both ante-mortem (before death) and post-mortem (after death).

Incorrect choices:

Option A : Coagulation of proteins and present in ante-mortem burn:

This option is incorrect because the pugilistic posture can be present in both ante-mortem and post-mortem burn cases. It is not exclusive to either one.

Option B : Coagulation of proteins and present in post-mortem burn:

This option is also incorrect because the pugilistic posture can occur in both ante-mortem and post-mortem burn cases. It is not limited to post-mortem situations.

Option D : None of the above:

This option is incorrect because there is a clear phenomenon associated with the pugilistic posture in burn victims

questions.text: The act of Burking includes which one of the following methods?
questions.solution:
Option D: Traumatic asphyxia

  • Burking is a combination of homicidal smothering and traumatic asphyxia.

Option A: Choking

  • Choking is a form of asphyxia caused by an obstruction within the air passages by a foreign object, like a coin, fruit seed, toffees, candies, fish, or any other material.

Option B: Ligature

  • Ligature strangulation: When ligature material is used to compress the neck.
  • A ligature mark is a well-defined groove, which is slightly depressed and of the same width as that of ligature material. The groove may be narrow at parts due to the folding of the ligature.

Option C: Overlaying

  • Overlaying or compression suffocation results from compression of the chest, nose, and mouth, so as to prevent breathing.

questions.text: An autopsy was performed on the 15-year-old boy who had succumbed to injuries sustained in a road traffic accident. The doctor also examined the skull and the brain for signs of damage. He noticed that the base of his sphenoid was not yet fused with the occiput. By which age is the fusion of the bones expected to happen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 20 years:

  • Basiocciput and basisphenoid: 18-20 years.

questions.text: The lawyer who is defending the suspect is making inquiries with the suspect to gather information to support his bail plea. Among the details he is looking for, is the method by which the police inquest was carried out. All the statements regarding a police inquest are true except?
