choices.text: Panchnama has to be signed by investigation officer

questions.solution:
Option D: IO cannot summon

  • IO can summon.
  • The police officer may summon persons who appear to know the facts of the case, and the person is bound to attend and answer questions put to him (Sec. 175 CrPC).

Option A: Senior head constable can investigate

  • The minimum cadre of police for conducting an inquest is a Station Officer (Senior Head Constable).

Option B: Most common inquest

  • Police inquest is the most common type of inquest.

Option C: Panchnama has to be signed by IO

  • IO can proceed to the place of occurrence and holds an inquiry into the matter, in the presence of two or more respectable inhabitants of the locality (witnesses). The witnesses are called panchas.
  • The inquest report so prepared is known as panchnama, which has to be signed by IO.

questions.text: A 42-year old female came to the OPD complaining of pain in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen since yesterday. On palpation, tenderness in the right hypochondrium was elicited. The patient was suspected of having gallstones. What is the investigation of choice in this case?
questions.solution:
Answer

Option A: Ultrasound

  • Ultrasound is considered the most useful initial radiological test of choice for diagnosing cholelithiasis and acute cholecystitis, with a sensitivity and specificity of 70% to 90%
  • Ultrasound is effective in documenting the presence or absence of stones, and it can show gallbladder wall thickening and pericholecystic fluid, both of which are highly suggestive of acute cholecystitis.
  • Most of the gallstones are radiolucent and hence cannot be detected in X-rays

Other Options

Option B: X-ray

  • Because only 10% of stones are calcified, this imaging study has limited usefulness.
  • However, porcelain gallbladder can also be seen in plain X-rays.

Option C: Barium study

  • Barium study is used to highlight the gastrointestinal tract.
  • It is not useful to study gallbladder.

Option D: Oral cholecystography

  • Oral cholecystography is a procedure used to image the gallbladder.
  • Although rarely performed now, following oral administration, the contrast agent gets absorbed by the bowel and concentrated in the gall bladder.
  • Radiolucent gallstones may then be outlined as filling defects on fluoroscopic imaging.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male came to your clinic with a complaint of headache with no other associated symptoms. On inspection of the patient, you see the following finding shown in the image and diagnose a genetic disease. What type of cancer would you expect the patient to have?
questions.solution:
Option A: Pancreatic cancer

  • This patient with hyperpigmented macules on his lips points towards a diagnosis of a genetic disease, the Peutz-Jeghers syndrome
  • Among the cancers given above, Peutz-Jeghers syndrome has a maximum risk of developing pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma
  • Pancreatic cancer
    • Pancreatic cancer is more common in older adults, with most patients being 75 to 84 years old. It is slightly more common in men than women.
    • Risk factors include family history, smoking, alcohol and coffee consumption, high fat diet, and low in fibre, fruits and vegetables, diabetes mellitus, chronic pancreatitis
    • About two-thirds of pancreatic adenocarcinomas arise within the head or uncinate process of the pancreas; 15% are in the body, and 10% are in the tail, with the remaining tumours demonstrating diffuse involvement of the gland
      • Ductal adenocarcinoma makes up 75% of nonendocrine cancers of the pancreas. Other less common types include adenosquamous carcinoma, acinic cell carcinoma
      • Genetics of pancreatic cancer
        • The K-Ras oncogene is currently thought to be the most commonly mutated gene in pancreatic cancer, with approximately 90% of tumours having a mutation. The Her2/neu oncogene is overexpressed in pancreatic cancer. Multiple tumour suppressor genes are deleted and mutated in pancreatic cancer, including p53, p16 and DPC 4 (Smad 4) and in a minority of cases, BRCA 2
        • Rare familial cancer syndromes that are associated with an increased risk of pancreatic cancer include BRCA2, the familial atypical multiple mole melanoma syndrome, hereditary pancreatitis, familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer, Peutz-Jeghers syndrome and ataxia-telangiectasia

Option B: Ganglioma

  • Ganglioma are associated with Multiple endocrine neoplasias 2B (MEN 2B), which consist of Gangliomas, Pheochromocytomas, and medullary thyroid carcinoma

Option C: Testicular cancer

  • Testicular cancer risk can increase in Klinefelter syndrome

Option D: Esophageal cancer

  • Esophageal cancer risk is not increased with Peutz-jeghers syndrome. It is increased by smoking, Barrett's esophagus, acid reflux, and alcohol.

questions.text: A male newborn is delivered vaginally at 38 weeks. Pregnancy is uneventful, and no fetal anomalies are detected at prenatal ultrasound controls. Maternal serologies for HbsAg, HCV, HIV, Toxoplasma, and Rubella are negative, along with insignificant vaginal swabs. Delivery is not complicated; Apgar score is nine at 1st, 5th and 10th of life. The neonate presents at birth with a genitourinary defect, as shown in the image. Which of the following feature is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Visible ureterovesical efflux

  • The newborn discussed above has clinical features, and examination findings suggest Ectopia vesicae. There is visible ureterovesical efflux.
  • Exstrophy of the bladder (ectopia vesicae) is a rare congenital anomaly.
  • It has an incidence of about 1 per 50,000.
  • The tubercle genitalia, the anterior wall of the bladder, and the inferior section of the anterior abdominal wall
  •  are all formed by the imperfect fusing of the mesoderm. Epispadias is present, not the hypospadias in Ectopia vesicae. Umbilical hernia, visible ureterovesical efflux, and waddling gait are seen in Ectopia vesicae.
  • Clinical Features:
    • The posterior wall of the bladder protrudes through the defect, with mucosal edges fused with skin and urine spurts onto the abdominal wall from the ureteral orifices.
    • Rectus muscles which are inserted on the pubic rami, are also widely separated.
    • An umbilical hernia though usually small is present along with the extrophic bladder.
    • In males, complete epispadias with a wide & shallow scrotum. Undescended testis & inguinal hernia are common.
    • Females also have epispadias with bifid clitoris and wide separation of the labia.
    • The anus is dislocated anteriorly in both sexes, and there may be rectal prolapse.
    • Ectopia vesicae increase the risk of Adenocarcinoma of the bladder.         

Option A: Inguinal hernia

  • Rectus muscles which are inserted on the pubic rami, are also widely separated.
  • An umbilical hernia though usually small is present along with the extrophic bladder.
  • Inguinal hernia is not a feature.

Option C: Hypospadias

  • Epispadias is present, not the hypospadias in Ectopia vesicae.
  • In males, complete epispadias with a wide & shallow scrotum. Undescended testis & inguinal hernia are common.
  • Females also have epispadias with bifid clitoris and wide separation of the labia.

Option D: Normal gait

  • Waddling gait is seen in Ectopia vesicae.
  • Gait is not normal.

questions.text: Surya, an 8-month-old baby boy, was brought to the clinic with an abnormal looking penis and passage of urine from the underside of the penis almost near the scrotum. On examination, he had a condition called penoscrotal hypospadias with mild chordee (abnormality where the penis is bent downwards). In this patient, which one of the following surgeries can be done?
questions.solution:
Option C: Duckett technique

Named procedures in hypospadias

  • Dennis - brown technique (Two stages).
  • MAGPI (Meatal advancement and glanuloplasty integrated) for coronal or subcoronal.
  • Mathie procedure (Perimeatal based flap, one stage) for distal penile.
  • Asopa and Duckett technique using vascularized preputial island.
  • Thiersch - Duplay or Bracka technique for proximal penile.

Option A: Circumcision

  • Circumcision is contraindicated in children born with Penoscrotal hypospadias.
  • The foreskin that is removed by circumcision is used for the reconstruction of hypospadias.

Option B: Ombredann’s

  • Ombredann’s is not used for penoscrotal hypospadias.

Option D: External beam radiation

  • External beam radiation is not recommended in Penoscrotal Hypospadias.
  • It is used for the management of tumors.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with previously good health presented to the emergency department with new testicular pain and swelling. Physical examination and ultrasonography revealed a large, heterogeneous, vascularized mass in the right scrotum. The patient underwent high inguinal orchidectomy, and histopathology showed that the mass had invaded the tunica albuginea and the epididymis. What is the disease stage?
questions.solution:
Option A: T1

  • This is a case of teratoma, as testes are hard with moderate tenderness.

 

TNM staging for testicular tumours

T: Primary tumour

 

 N: Regional lymph nodes(Clinical)

 
pTis: Intratubular germ cell neoplasia (carcinoma in situ)

 

 N1: Metastasis within one or more lymph nodes less than 2 cm in size

 
pT1: Limited to the testis & epididymis and no vascular/ lymphatic invasion; Tumor may invade tunica albuginea but not tunica vaginalis

 

 N2: Metastasis within one or more lymph nodes greater than 2 cm but less than 5 cm in size

 
pT2: Limited to the testis & epididymis with vascular/ lymphatic invasion or extending through tunica albuginea with involvement of tunica vaginalis

 

 N3: Metastasis within one or more lymph nodes greater than 5 cm in size

 
pT3: Invades the spermatic cord with or without invading vascular/lymphatic

 

 M1: Distant metastases

 

M1a: Non-regional nodal or pulmonary metastases

M1b: Distant metastasis at a site other than non-regional lymph nodes or lung
pT4: Invades the scrotum with or without invading vascular/lymphatic

 

 Serum tumour markers (S)

 

S1 : LDH <1.5 x normal, hCG <5000 IU/L, AFP < 1000 ng/mL

S2 : LDH 1.5-10 x normal, hCG 5000 - 50000 IU/L, AFP 1000 - 10000 ng/mL

S3 : LDH >10 x normal, hCG >50000 IU/L, AFP >10000 ng/mL

 

Option B: T2

  • In T2, there is the involvement of tunica vaginalis.
  • In this, there is the involvement of lymphatic and vascular invasion.

Option C: T3

  • In T3 spermatic cord is involved.

Option D: T4

  • In T4 scrotum is involved

questions.text: A 19-year-old female student presented in to the emergency, complaining of numbness in her left toe. She had a 3-year smoking history. Angiography revealed peripheral arterial occlusion of both legs and arms. A detailed laboratory examination excluded collagen disease, hypercoagulable state, and juvenile atherosclerosis. A below knee amputation of the left leg was performed. Typical histologic findings of Buerger’s disease were observed in the crural arteries and saphenous veins. Which of the following structures is affected by the disease?
questions.solution:
Option A: Small vessels

  • Numbness and sensation of coldness in a young female with a smoking history are suggestive of Buerger's disease. Angiography showing peripheral arterial occlusion further confirms the diagnosis.
  • Thromboangiitis obliterans (Buerger's disease) is a non-atherosclerotic, segmental inflammatory, and occlusive disease that affects small and medium-sized arteries and veins in the upper and lower extremities.
  • The cause remains unknown; however, the use of tobacco is central to the initiation and progression of the disease.
  • The most effective treatment for TOA is smoking cessation.
  • Medical line of treatment with vasodilators, pentoxifylline and cilostazol may help improve pain-free walking but cannot prevent disease progression.

Option B: Muscles

  • Muscles are soft tissues. Three different types of muscle are:
    • Smooth muscle
    • Skeletal muscle
    • Cardiac muscle
  • Buerger’s disease does not affect muscles.

Option C: Bones

  • Bone is a specialized form of dense connective tissue consisting of osteocytes embedded in a non-living matrix; osseous tissue. Bone matrix is made of calcium carbonate, calcium phosphate, and collagen fibres.
  • Bones form the skeleton of the body.
  • The most common disease of bones in old age is osteoarthritis, affecting mainly females.

Option D: Skin

  • Skin is the largest organ of the body.
  • Layers of skin are;
    • Basal cell layer
    • Squamous cell layer
    • Stratum granulosum and stratum lucidum
    • Stratum corneum
    • Papillary layer
    • Reticular layer

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient presented to the dermatology department with a history of rapidly growing skin lesions over the scalp. The lesion started around three months ago and rapidly increased to the present size of  5 cm in diameter. A punch biopsy of the lesion showed features suggestive of Kaposi's sarcoma with advice given for excision biopsy.  The lesion was excised with the inclusion of a 1-cm margin of clinically normal tissue. After excision, a circular defect of around 7 cm diameter was formed on the scalp. Which technique should be used to close this defect in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: Local flap

  • This patient is most likely suffering from Kaposi sarcoma. He needs closure of the defect after the surgical excision of the tumour. A circular defect of around 7 cm diameter present on the scalp should be closed by a local flap in this patient.
  • A flap is characterised by a tissue transferred from one particular site (donor site) to another (recipient site).
  • During the process of transferring the tissue, its blood supply is maintained. The types of tissue flaps are:
    • Local flaps
    • Regional flaps
    • Distant flaps
  • Local flaps are transferred from an area adjacent to the defect.
  • Absolute indications for flaps include:
  • Exposed bone
  • Radiated vessel
  • Exposed brain
  • Open joint or non-biological implant materials
  • Pressure sores at bony prominences
  • This patient with a defect of 7 cm diameter can be optimally repaired with a local flap.

Option A: Primary simple closure

  • Primary simple closure is characterised by the type of tissue repair in which the skin is closed at the end of the surgery. However, it requires adequate soft tissue to avoid excessive wound tension. A wound closed under excessive tension results in wound dehiscence and an unacceptably wide scar. So, a wound with tissue defect cannot be used via a simple primary closure.

Option B: Split skin grafting

  • A split-thickness skin graft (STSG) contains the epidermis and a portion of the dermis and consists of the epidermis and dermis only.
  • Hence it should not be used in this patient.

Option C: Secondary closure

  • The secondary closure is characterised by the process in which the wound is left open at the end of surgery and heals by granulation and contraction. The indications of the secondary closure include the following:
    • Infected wounds
    • Wounds with implanted foreign bodies
    • Bite wounds that do not meet the criteria for primary closure
    • Large wounds with irregular edges that cannot be approximated
    • Secondary closure results in scar formation, so it should be avoided in this patient.

questions.text: Smoking increases the risk of which of the following cancers?
questions.solution:
Option B: Urinary bladder

  • Cigarette smoke increases the risk of many cancers. It includes:
    • First-hand smoke: smoke inhaled by the smoker
    • Second-hand smoke: exhaled smoke that is inhaled by others in the vicinity of the smoker
    • Third-hand smoke: smoke particles that adhere to surfaces in the surroundings of the smoker
      • All three have been proven to be carcinogenic
  • Smoking is an important risk factor for:
    • Transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder
    • Squamous cell carcinoma (cervix, oropharynx, esophagus, larynx, lung)
    • Small cell lung cancer
    • Pancreatic adenocarcinoma
    • Adenocarcinoma of the esophagus
    • Renal cell carcinoma

Option A: Thyroid

  • Smoking is not a risk factor for thyroid cancer.

Option C: Blood

  • Cigarette smoke does not increase the risk of blood cancer.

Option D: Gallbladder

  • Smoking is not a risk factor for carcinoma gallbladder.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male is admitted to the emergency department with traumatic brain injury due to a road traffic accident. On examination, he is unconscious with a blood pressure of 160/100 mmHg and a pulse rate is 56 per minute. He is taken to the operation theatre for emergency decompressive craniotomy under general anaesthesia. Which of the following agent has a maximum cerebral blood flow increasing effect at a given MAC value?
questions.solution:
Option A: Halothane

  • The potent, halogenated inhalation anaesthetics (Sevoflurane, desflurane, isoflurane, halothane) are all dose-dependent cerebral vasodilators.
  • While they reduce cerebral metabolic rate (CMR), they can blunt cerebral autoregulation by uncoupling cerebral blood flow (CBF) and metabolism, thereby increasing CBF and intracranial pressure (ICP).
  • At MAC values <1 MAC, the net effect is a modest decrease in CBF and responsiveness to CO2 is generally maintained.
  • However, CBF increases more significantly at concentrations >1 MAC.
  • Halothane has a maximum cerebral blood flow-increasing effect.
  • The cerebral blood flow of the different anaesthetics is shown below:

FIG: Cerebral blood flow measured in the presence of normocapnia and in the absence of surgical. *P<0.05

Option B: Isoflurane

  • Isoflurane has less CBF-increasing effect.
  • It can be given to patients with a head injury who is undergoing surgery

Option C: Sevoflurane

  • The effect of Sevoflurane in increasing CBF is much less than halothane.
  • Halothane must be avoided in patients with raised ICP.

Option D: Desflurane

  • Desflurane has a pungent odour and can cause laryngospasm.
  • The cerebral blood-increasing effect is less potent.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient with a mitral stenosis case was posted for mitral valve replacement surgery. The patient was induced with inj. Fentanyl 10 mcg/kg and inj. Thiopentone 100 mg intravenously. The anesthesiologist was unable to perform mask ventilation after induction. inj. Vecuronium 6 mg Iv was given, and mask ventilation was followed by intubation. The probable reason for this is:
questions.solution:
Option A: Fentanyl

  • This is a case of mitral stenosis in which the patient is posted for mitral valve replacement surgery.
  • Rapid administration of larger doses of opioids (particularly fentanyl, sufentanil, remifentanil, and alfentanil) can induce generalized skeletal muscle rigidity severe enough to prevent adequate bag and mask ventilation.
  • Fentanyl and other opioid agonists suppress respiration by acting on -opioid receptors at multiple sites to reduce the response to increased pCO2 and decreased pO2 and, thus, the drive to breathe.
  • The majority of ventilation resistance is due to laryngeal musculature contraction. This is due to the striatal release of gamma-aminobutyric acid, and increased dopamine production explains the opioid-induced increased skeletal muscle tone.

Option B: Thiopentone sodium

  • Pentothal (thiopental sodium for injection, USP) is a central nervous system depressant that induces hypnosis and anaesthesia but not analgesia.
  • Thiopental sodium is a bronchoconstrictor causes respiratory depression and a decrease in cardiac output in patients with cardiovascular disease, particularly constrictive pericarditis, and may precipitate acute circulatory failure.
  • Respiratory depression, myocardial depression, cardiac arrhythmias, prolonged tiredness and recovery, sneezing, coughing, bronchospasm, laryngospasm, and shivering are all possible side effects.

Option C: Vecuronium

  • This neuromuscular blocking agent is frequently used in general anaesthesia patients to facilitate endotracheal intubation and surgical relaxation.
  • Vecuronium bromide is used as a supplement to general anaesthesia to help with endotracheal intubation and to relax skeletal muscles during surgery or mechanical ventilation.
  • Vecuronium bromide is not recommended for patients who are known to be hypersensitive to it.

Option D: Meperidine

  • Intradural meperidine has been used as the sole anaesthetic agent in various surgeries, with the primary benefit of providing long-lasting postoperative analgesia.
  • Meperidine, an opioid, induces spinal anaesthesia and blocks nerve action potentials, indicating that it is a local anaesthetic.
  • The injection of meperidine is used to treat moderate to severe pain. It is also useful before and during surgery and other medical procedures.
  • Meperidine injection belongs to the class of drugs known as opiate (narcotic) analgesics. It works by altering the way the body perceives pain.

questions.text: After administering 3.25 ml of 0.5% hyperbaric bupivacaine intrathecally for spinal anesthesia in a 40-year-old male with a right inguinal hernia, which nerve fiber should be assessed first?
questions.solution:
Option C: Aδ

  • The above-given case is a right inguinal hernia.
  • Aδ is the nerve fibres tested earlier.
  • There are afferent fibres of nociceptors.
  • They carry information from peripheral mechanoreceptors and thermoreceptors to the dorsal horn of the anterior ganglion.
  • Different fibre types are differentially sensitive to the local anaesthetic blockade.
  • Small myelinated axons (Aγ motor and Aδ sensory fibres) are the most susceptible to impulse suppression.
  • Large myelinated fibres Aα and Aβ are next in order of block. Small non-myelinated C fibres are the least susceptible.
  • Clinically, testing of block efficacy that targets Aδ sensory fibres.

Option A: C fibre

  • C fibres have low conduction velocity.
  • There are unmyelinated fibres that are small in diameter.

Option B: Dorsal root ganglia

  • Dorsal root ganglia contain cell bodies with sensory nerves that carry sensory information to the spinal cord.
  • The dorsal root ganglia is a nodular structure located in the posterior root of spinal nerves.

Option D: Aα

  • Aα are primary receptors of the Golgi tendon organ and muscle spindles.
  • They include type la and lb sensory receptors and are large myelinated fibres.

questions.text: A known case of papillary carcinoma of the right breast had come to your hospital for surgery. A modified radical mastectomy procedure was done, and on the 2nd postoperative day, the patient presents with the following finding, as shown in the figure below. Which nerve would have been damaged during the operative procedure?
questions.solution:
Option B: The long thoracic nerve of Bell

  • The finding in the image given above is winging of the scapula.
  • Winging of the scapula is seen after mastectomy due to long thoracic nerve injury.
  • The long thoracic nerve of the Bell:
    • Courses closed to the chest wall on the axial side of the axilla were encountered during axillary dissection.
    • Also known as the external respiratory nerve of Bell.
    • Innervates serratus anterior - It fixes the scapula to the chest wall during shoulder adduction and arm extension.
    • Division of this nerve results in winged scapula deformity.

Option A: Musculocutaneous nerve

  • Supplies the biceps brachii and brachialis muscles
  • Its injury can cause weakness in the elbow or shoulder flexion, atrophy of the biceps brachii, and pain or paresthesia at the lateral forearm.

Option C: Intercostobrachial nerve

  • Intercostobrachial nerve supplies sensation to the undersurface of the upper arm and skin of the chest wall along the posterior axilla. Injury to this nerve results in cutaneous anesthesia in these areas.

Option D: Thoracodorsal nerve

  • Encountered during axillary dissection
  • Innervates latissimus dorsi
  • Injury can cause weakness of internal rotation and abduction of the shoulder.

questions.text: Which of the following is the investigation of choice for a patient with esophageal rupture?

choices.text: Water soluble low molecular weight contrast swallow

questions.solution:
Option D: Water soluble low molecular weight contrast swallow

  • The investigation of choice for esophageal rupture is water soluble low molecular weight contrast swallow.
  • The use of a water-soluble medium such as Gastrografin is preferred due to the concern of exacerbating contamination if barium were used and leaked.
  • Esophageal rupture:
    • Pain is a striking and consistent symptom and strongly suggests that an esophageal rupture has occurred, particularly in the cervical area, following instrumentation of the esophagus or substernal in a patient with vomiting.
    • If subcutaneous emphysema is present, the diagnosis is almost certain
    • Within the first 8 to 24 hours following injury, frank sepsis may develop if the contamination is extensive
    • Investigations:
      • Initial screening evaluation is with a plain upright chest radiograph which may reveal a pleural effusion, pneumothorax, pneumoperitoneum, subcutaneous or mediastinal emphysema, or mediastinal widening suggestive of perforation. But normal X-ray does not rule out the possibility of a leak.
    • Abnormalities of chest radiograms are dependent on three factors: 
      • The time interval between perforation and radiographic examination
      • Site of perforation
      • The integrity of the mediastinal pleura
    • The diagnosis is confirmed with a contrast esophagram which will demonstrate extravasation in 90% of patients.
    • A 10% False negative rate is noted.
    • CT is another diagnostic modality which can be used.

Option A: Dynamic MRI

  • Dynamic MRI is not the investigation of choice in case of esophageal rupture.

Option B: Rigid esophagoscopy

  • Rigid esophagoscopy is not the investigation of choice in case of esophageal rupture.

Option C: Barium swallow

  • Barium swallow is the investigation of choice for zenker's diverticulum.

questions.text: A 52 years male presented in the emergency department with acute confusion, visual hallucination, persecutory idea, upward gaze palsy of the left eye, gait ataxia, restlessness, and nonfluctuating disorientation for four days. He had a history of alcohol consumption for the last 25 years, with average daily consumption of more than 1 litre of alcohol. An initial diagnosis of Wernicke's encephalopathy was made. Which area of the thalamus is involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option B: Dorsomedial Nucleus

  • Wernicke–Korsakoff syndrome (WKS) is caused by thiamine deficiency and is most commonly observed as an effect of alcohol abuse in populations over 40.
  • Because thiamine helps to produce the energy needed for proper neuronal function, insufficient thiamine can cause neuronal damage or death.
  • The thalamus and mammillary bodies are particularly sensitive to damage due to thiamine deficiency.
  • This diagnosis can be supported by neuroimaging or autopsy findings showing degeneration of the thalamus and mammillary bodies and loss of brain volume around the fourth ventricle.
  • Patients exhibit a confused state, eye movement disturbances, and ataxia in the acute phase.
  • In the chronic phase, patients exhibit dense anterograde amnesia that is attributed to neural damage in the anterior and dorsomedial nuclei of the thalamus and mammillothalamic tract.

Option A: Reticular Nucleus

  • The reticular nucleus is a narrow, shell-shaped nucleus that wraps around the lateral margin of the thalamus and extends from the rostral pole to the pulvinar and the lateral geniculate nucleus.
  • It is found adjacent to the lateral thalamic nuclei, separated from them by the external medullary lamina.
  • The reticular nucleus is the only nucleus that does not project to the cortex.
  • This nucleus receives inputs from other thalamic nuclei and the cerebral cortex and sends projections that circle back to the thalamus.

Option C: Lateral thalamic nuclei

  • Lateral thalamic nuclei also referred to as the lateral nuclear group, are a collection of neuronal cell bodies found laterally in the internal medullary lamina.
  • These are the largest division of the thalamic nuclei, divided into dorsal and ventral tiers of nuclei.
  • The ventral tier nuclei are the ventral anterior (VA), ventral lateral (VL) and ventral posterior (VP) nuclei.
  • The dorsal tier nuclei are the medial geniculate nucleus (MGN), lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN), lateral dorsal (LD) nucleus, lateral posterior (LP) nucleus, and pulvinar.

Option D: Intralaminar nuclei of the thalamus​​​​​​​

  • These are collections of nerve cells within the internal medullary lamina; the "Y" shaped white matter sheet discussed before.
  • Two groups of nuclei are involved: the anterior (rostral) and posterior (caudal).
  • The intralaminar nuclei play a role in activating the cortex from the brainstem reticular formation.
  • It is also involved in sensory-motor integration.

questions.text: A 71-year-old male presents to the medical emergency with a history of progressive chest pain and dysphagia for the last 15 days. After eating, he reports constant difficulty in swallowing; however, there are no other symptoms like nausea, vomiting, melena, or fever. An esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) is done, which reveals a rough oesophagal mucosa, and large discrete ulcers are visible. The barium image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: CMV esophagitis

  • The most likely diagnosis here is CMV esophagitis.
  • Esophagitis, including HIV and CMV esophagitis, usually manifests as one or more large ovoid or diamond-shaped ulcers.

  • CMV esophagitis is the second most common GIT manifestation of CMV disease. The first is colitis.
  • The typical symptoms include:
    • Odynophagia and dysphagia.
  • There is the presence of large ulcers or ulcers in the middle to distal oesophagus.
  • A definitive diagnostic tool is an esophagogastroduodenoscopy with biopsy.
  • The treatment of CMV esophagitis includes:
    • Induction therapy for 3 to 6 weeks with intravenous ganciclovir or foscarnet is commenced.

Option A: Achalasia cardia

  • Achalasia (primary achalasia) is a failure of organised oesophageal peristalsis, causing impaired relaxation of the lower oesophageal sphincter resulting in food stasis and often marked dilatation of the oesophagus.
  • Barium swallow imaging shows a bird beak appearance seen in achalasia cardia.

 Option B: Plummer-Vinson syndrome

  • It is also known as the Paterson-Brown Kelly syndrome, a rare condition comprising a classic triad of dysphagia, iron-deficiency anaemia, and upper oesophagal webs.

Option C: Carcinoma oesophagus

  •  Features of carcinoma oesophagus on barium swallow:
    • Irregular stricture.
    • Pre-stricture dilatation with 'hold up.
    • Shouldering of the stricture.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe back pain for the past one hour. His medical history is consistent with tuberculous coxitis since early childhood. He has been taken up for total hip Replacement by the surgeon. What is the most common complication which can lead to death in this patient?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of death in a patient undergoing total hip replacement is myocardial infarction.

Option A: Myocardial infarction

Total Hip replacement:

  • Total hip arthroplasty (THA), also known as total hip replacement, consists of resection of the diseased articular surfaces of the hip, followed by replacement with prosthetic hip components.
  • For the properly selected patient, the procedure results in significant pain relief, as well as improved function and quality of life.
  • In spite of the potential benefits of THA, it is typically an elective procedure and should only be considered after a thorough discussion of the risks, benefits, and alternatives.
  • The most common indication for THA is for the relief of pain associated with osteoarthritis of the hip in patients who have failed nonoperative treatments.
  • Other conditions that cause pain and loss of function that may result in the need for THA include inflammatory arthritides (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, psoriatic arthritis, spondyloarthropathies), femoroacetabular impingement syndrome, developmental hip dysplasia, childhood hip disorders (e.g., Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease, slipped capital femoral epiphysis), trauma, neoplasms, and osteonecrosis.
  • Active infection is perhaps the most significant contraindication to THA. Other contraindications include preexisting or significant medical problems (e.g., recent myocardial infarction, unstable angina, heart failure, severe anemia), skeletal immaturity, quadriplegia, or permanent or irreversible muscle weakness in the absence of pain.
  • Relative contraindications include paraplegia, inability to ambulate that is not related to the hip disorder per se, absence of hip abductor muscle function, progressive neurologic deficit, and a neuropathic (Charcot) joint, and patients with severe obesity.
  • Complications are infection (rare) and dislocation (rare)
  • Mortality Cause: Myocardial infarction>Cardiorespiratory arrest >Pulmonary embolism
  • Metal ion-associated complications are hypersensitivity, teratogenicity (Contraindicated in young females), renal insufficiency, chromosomal abnormalities (prostate& lung CA), and carcinogenesis.

Option B: cardiopulmonary arrest

  • Myocardial infarction is the most common cause of death than cardiopulmonary arrest.

Option C: pulmonary embolism

  • Myocardial infarction is the most common cause of death than pulmonary embolism.

Option D: infections

  • Myocardial infarction is the most common cause of death than infections.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presented in the outpatient department with a complaint of recurrent abdominal pain and constipation for two weeks. She has been experiencing these symptoms since adolescence, with periods of improvement and exacerbation. Over the past year, her symptoms have been occurring more frequently. On examination, she was a well-nourished woman in no acute distress. Her vital signs were as follows: blood pressure at 110/80 mmHg, pulse at 60 beats per minute, and respiratory rate at 12 breaths per minute. She was diagnosed with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS- constipation dominant). Which of the following drugs can be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Lubiprostone

  • Recurrent episodes of abdominal pain along with constipation in a normal-looking female for a period of time are suggestive of constipation-dominant irritable bowel syndrome. The mainstay of treatment in such cases is to treat the symptom. Lubiprostone is used to treat constipation by increasing intraluminal fluid.
  • Lubiprostone stimulates Cl-channel opening in the intestine, increasing liquid secretion in the gut and decreasing transit time, therefore used for chronic constipation. It has also been used for constipation-dominant IBS in women.
  • Irritable bowel syndrome is characterized by abdominal discomfort, bloating and altered bowel habits.
  • For diarrhea-dominant IBS, drugs that can be used are;
    • Loperamide and diphenoxylate
    • New kappa-opioid receptor antagonist- fedotozine
    • 5 HT-3 antagonist – Alosetron
    • Clonidine
  • For constipation-dominant IBS, effective drugs are;
    • 5 HT4 agonists – tegaserod, prucalopride
    • Loxiglumide
    • Lubiprostone
    • Plecanatide

Option B: Loperamide

  • Loperamide acts by inhibiting the release of acetylcholine and prostaglandins in the gut wall, resulting in decreased propulsive movements and an increase in transit time. Therefore, it is used in the treatment of diarrhoea-dominant IBS.

Option C: Alosetron

  • Alosetron is 5-Hydroxytryptamine-3 receptor antogonist.
  • Serotonin is secreted by enterochromaffin cells in the ileum resulting in increased peristaltic movements of the intestine.
  • Alosetron inhibits these receptors, thus inhibiting peristalsis time resulting in increased water absorption. Therefore, this drug is used to treat diarrhoea.

Option D: Clonidine

  • Clonidine is a centrally-acting alpha agonist.
  • The alpha receptors in the body are stimulated by clonidine, causing arterial wall muscles to relax and decreasing arterial blood pressure.
  • Clonidine also relieves pain as it stimulates alpha receptors in the spinal cord, which blocks sensation signals throughout the spinal cord.

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman presented to the physician's office complaining of a feeling of swollen and enlarged  neck for the past month. The patient had no previous history of such swelling and no family history of thyroid-related disorders or other neoplasms. An endocrine examination showed that the patient was euthyroid, and there were no thyroid autoantibodies.On ultrasound, a diffusely enlarged left thyroid tumor showing a heterogenous pattern without clear capsule formation is seen in the cervical region. Which of the following is the best investigation for diagnosing this disease?
questions.solution:
Option A: Biopsy

Follicular adenoma

  • It is a common benign neoplasm that usually presents as a solitary thyroid nodule.

  • Follicular adenomas are mostly sporadic; multiple other causes include iodine deficiency and genetic alterations, e.g. PTEN inactivation, BRAF, NRAS, RET, and KRAS mutations; in addition, prior iodine (I-131) radiation exposure increases the risk of malignant lesions of the thyroid.

  • Patients present with solitary thyroid nodules that may be associated with thyroiditis or nodular hyperplasia. There is a solitary, slowly growing mass in the neck with a pressure sensation. Pain occurs with a spontaneous haemorrhage or cystic degeneration in the nodule.

  • After history and examination, serum TSH is done, followed by an ultrasound scan. However, the sonographic features of both adenoma and carcinoma are similar and thus not helpful.

  • Diagnosis is made by doing a biopsy of the sample. This is because, on biopsy, malignancy can be defined based on the invasion of the tumor cells into the vascular endothelium or across the thyroid gland capsule. Based on this, a biopsy of the thyroid tissue is the diagnostic test.

Option B: FNAC

  • FNAC is cytology sampling done to examine the cells from adenoma and carcinoma. However, based on the histology of the cells, the decision cannot be made to differentiate between adenoma and carcinoma. Rather, malignancy is defined by the capsular and vascular invasion of the thyroid follicles.

Option C: CT scan

  • CT scan has a limited role in the evaluation of solitary thyroid nodules. However, they can be employed in external compression of the surrounding structures and invasion of or compression of surrounding tissue in the case of follicular carcinoma.

Option D: MRI

  • MRI has a limited role in the initial evaluation of solitary thyroid nodules; however, it is helpful to differentiate between follicular adenoma and carcinoma based on the invasion and extension of the tissue into the surrounding mediastinum.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male, an elderly diabetic patient, is brought to the medical outpatient department by his daughter with complaints of altered mental status, headache, and nasal congestion. He has been suffering from these symptoms for a week now. He is also complaining of blurred vision. On examination, he has facial swelling on one side. On the chest X-ray, cavitary lesions are seen. The doctor orders a fungal screen. The biopsy showed LCB-stained periorbital exudates in severe panophthalmitis with cellulitis and showed obtuse angle branching aseptate and broad hyphae. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option

Option D: Rhizopus species

  • The most likely diagnosis is Rhizopus species.
  • The clinical scenario given in the question suggests Rhinocerebral Zygomycosis caused by Rhizopus species.
  • Rhinocerebral Zygomycosis is a serious fulminating infection, angioinvasive, thrombosis, and ischaemic tissue necrosis.
  • Other clinical forms of Zygomycosis:
    • Pulmonary
    • Gastrointestinal
    • Disseminated
    • Dermal
    • Cutaneous
  • Points in favour of Rhizopus:
    • Non-septate broad hyphae
    • Obtuse angled branching
    • Forms asexual spores: Sporangia
    • Sexual spores → Zygospores

  • Agents of Zygomycosis -
    • Rhizopus
    • Mucor
    • Absidia
    • Apophysomyces
  • Rhizoids arrangement:
    • No rhizoids: Mucor
    • Internodal arrangement: Absidia
    • Directly opposite to sporangia: Rhizopus
  • Zygomycota is aseptate fungi that cause serious infections, primarily in ketoacidosis diabetic and cancer patients.

 

RHINOCEREBRAL MUCORMYCOSIS

Clinical  features

  • Onset with nasal stuffiness, epistaxis and facial pain.

  • Later, proptosis, chemosis and ophthalmoplegia.

  • Fever and Confusion

  • Black necrotic eschar on the nasal turbinates or palate: very characteristic

Other Options

Option A: Candida

  • Yeast-like fungi that usually has pseudohyphae
  • Does not cause Rhinocerebral mycosis.
  • It is a normal commensal of the oral cavity, gut and vagina.
  • It causes problems only if the immunity is decreased or normal skin or mucous membrane is breached.

Option B: Aspergillus

  • Narrow septate hyaline hyphae with acute angle branching moulds.
  • In immunocompromised patients, Aspergillus can cause Sino-pulmonary infections.
  • It is found on fruits and vegetables in the form of 'black mould' therefore known as a food spoilage organism.

Option C: Penicillium

  • Hyaline thin septate hyphae, vesicles are absent, and conidia arranged as brush border appearance moulds.
  • Causes allergic reactions and infections in people with a weak immune system.

questions.text: A 33-year-old female presents with a chief complaint of shortness of breath on exertion. She reports that she was treated for similar symptoms six months ago. At that time, she was diagnosed with acute bronchitis and treated. This management did not improve her symptoms; which have gradually worsened over the past six months. The physician suspected it was a case of Darling's disease. The medium of choice for culturing the causative organism of this disease would be?

choices.text: SDA with antibiotics, incubated at 37 degrees Celsius
Any medium incubated at 35-37 degrees Celsius

questions.solution:
Correct Option

Option C:  SDA with antibiotics, incubated at 37 degrees Celsius

  • The fungus Histoplasma capsulatum causes Darling's disease.
  • The fungus culture can be grown on SDA at 37 degrees Celsius. Antibiotics are added to the culture medium to avoid contamination with bacteria.
  • On SDA, white, cottony, mycelial growth appears. Large, thick-walled, spherical spores with tubercles are also seen.
  • Darling identified this disease in 1905. Hence named Darling's disease.
  • Histoplasma capsulatum is found in soil. Decaying trees and found particularly abundant in bird droppings.
  • The pulmonary disease by this pathogen resembles tuberculosis and is specific for Histoplasmosis.

Other Options

Option A: BHI

  • BHI agar is a nutrient-rich media used to cultivate various microorganisms.
  • It is a non-selective medium and can be contaminated.

Option B: SDA

  • SDA without antibiotics is a non-selective medium.
  • Cultural growth in this medium can be contaminated.
  • This gives false positive results for other microorganisms.

Option D: Any medium incubated at 35-37 degrees Celsius

  • Histoplasma species grow best at 37-degree Celsius.
  • The growth of Histoplasma can be affected by changes in the culture medium.
  • All culture mediums do not yield the same growth. Therefore, a specific culture is required for the growth of Histoplasma species.

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient came to the clinic complaining of fever, chills, sore throat, runny nose, cough and body aches. Further testing revealed a single-stranded RNA virus with a segmented genome as the causative agent. The person usually eats pork meat. Which of the following strain is associated with the given condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: H1N1

  • H1N1 Swine flu is a subtype of the influenza A virus (a contagious viral disease).
  • Swine flu causes upper and potentially lower respiratory tract infections in the host, resulting in symptoms such as nasal secretions, chills, fever, decreased appetite, and possibly lower respiratory tract disease.
  • Swine flu is due to H1N1.
  • Structure of Influenza virus:
    • Single-stranded RNA
    • Have segmented genome
  • Surface proteins:
    • Glycoprotein H [Hemagglutinin] → Adheres to cell
    • Glycoprotein N [Neuraminidase] → Receptor Destroying Enzyme. The process is known as elution.

 

Transmission:

  • People who work with poultry and swine, especially those with intense exposure.
  • Antigenic variations:
    • The surface antigens HA and NA show variations and are primarily responsible for antigenic variations exhibited by influenza viruses.
    • Antigenic variations are of two types: antigenic shift and antigenic drift.

Option B: H5N1

  • H5N1 is known as Avian influenza or bird flu
  • H5N1 stands for highly pathogenic avian influenza virus A(H5N1)
  • A virus was transmitted directly from chicken to humans
  • This special notorious strain is the HPAI influenza virus H5N1, which has a mortality rate of approximately 60%
  • Infected birds transmit to humans.
  • Human-to-human transmission is not possible.
    • PBIF2 gene → targets the mitochondria of the cell & damages it.

Option C: H2N2

  • In February 1957, a new influenza A (H2N2) virus emerged in East Asia, triggering a pandemic called Asian flu.
  • Avian influenza is mainly spread by direct contact between infected birds and healthy birds
  • It can also be transmitted when birds come in contact with equipment or materials (including water and feed) contaminated with faeces or secretions from the nose or mouth of infected birds.

Option D: H3N2

  • H3N2 is a non-human influenza virus that normally circulates in pigs and has infected humans.
  • To prevent H3N2 infection, you should avoid contact with anyone with flu-like symptoms.
  • Infected people should remain isolated for 7 to 10 days to avoid transmitting the virus to others.

questions.text: Correct sequence of events in acute inflammation is?
questions.solution:
The journey of leukocytes from the vessel lumen to the tissue is a multistep process that is mediated and controlled by adhesion molecules and cytokines called chemokines.

This process can be divided into sequential phases:  

1.    In the lumen: margination, rolling, and adhesion to endothelium. Vascular endothelium in its normal, unactivated state does not bind circulating cells or impede their passage. In inflammation, the endothelium is activated and can bind leukocytes as a prelude to their exit from the blood vessels.

2.    Migration across the endothelium and vessel wall.

3.    Migration in the tissues toward a chemotactic stimulus

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents to the emergency department due to severe, crushing substernal pain for 20 minutes. ECG shows inferior wall myocardial infarction. During management, the patient develops an arrhythmia and fails to recover. The histological examination of the heart reveals the formation of early granulation tissue. Which of the following gives the exact time of granulation tissue formation after a myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B: Within 24 hours: Granulation tissue formation is part of the early healing response following a myocardial infarction. It typically starts within the first 24 hours after the infarction as the body initiates the process of tissue repair and remodeling.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Less than 1 hour: This is extremely early for granulation tissue formation after a myocardial infarction. The process usually takes slightly more time to begin.

Option C: Within 1 week: While there is ongoing tissue repair and remodeling during the first week after a myocardial infarction, granulation tissue formation is an earlier event, often initiated within the first 24 hours.

Option D: After 1 week: By one week after a myocardial infarction, the healing process has progressed beyond the initial stages, and granulation tissue is already forming during the earlier phases of recovery.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to OPD with a complaint of abdominal pain associated with nausea and vomiting for the last two days. She also reports headaches, insomnia and generalised weakness. His examination reveals a high blood pressure of 160/110mmHg with a pulse rate of 90 beats per minute. On examination, hepatomegaly is noticed. Additionally, her vitamin B-12 levels are low. The clinical diagnosis of malignant hydatid disease is made. Which of the following is true about malignant hydatid disease in the patient?

choices.text: Hydatid disease in the immunocompromised host

questions.solution:
Option B: Infection with E. multilocularis

  • The scenario is hydatid disease, in which there is abdominal pain and hepatomegaly. Hydatid disease is an infection with Echinococcus multilocularis.
  • The liver is the most common organ affected (98% of cases).
  • The disease may resemble a slowly growing carcinoma and cause intrahepatic portal hypertension symptoms.
  • Hepatomegaly and hypertension are seen.
  • The cyst appears as a solid, firm mass with an irregular outer layer and can migrate rapidly to other organs to mimic a malignant tumour.
  • Man is an accidental intermediate host.
  • Definitive agent- Foxes and wolves (and also dogs and cats).
  • Intermediate hosts- Small wild rodents like squirrels, voles, mice, etc.
  • This disease is found in Russia, Kazakhstan, China, etc.

Option A: Malignant changes into hydatid cyst

  • There are no malignant changes in hydatid disease.
  • Humans are not included in the parasitic life cycle of Echinococcus granulosus.

Option C: Hydatid disease in the immunocompromised host

  • The scenario mentioned above is hydatid disease.
  • Cystic and alveolar echinococcosis occurs in the immunocompromised host.

Option D: Caused by Echinococcus granulosus

  • Hydatid disease is an infection with Echinococcus multilocularis.
  • Cystic Echinococcosis (C.E.), also known as hydatid disease, is caused by infection with the larval stage of Echinococcus granulosus.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of fever and hyperpigmentation of the skin. He further explains that he has a double temperature rise within 24 hours. The doctor diagnosed it as kala-azar. The patient's splenic biopsy was done, showing the presence of an amastigote form. Which of the following cells shows the same form as in the patient's biopsy?
questions.solution:
Option B: RES (reticuloendothelial)

  • This is a case of kala-azar in which the patient presents with complaints of fever and hyperpigmentation of the skin. The fever has a double-rise pattern in 24 hours.
  • The species of leishmania exist in two forms:-
    • Amastigote (aflagellar)
    • Promastigote (flagellated) in their life cycle.
  • Amastigote (Non-flagellate form) occurs in the infected lesion of man in reticuloendothelial cells like macrophages, neutrophils, endothelial cells of the liver, spleen, bone marrow, etc.
  • Amastigote form is also called Leishmania donovani body. It is an obligate intracellular form and infective to sand-fly.
  • Promastigote form is an extracellular form and infective to humans. It is mainly found in sandflies and culture.
  • Leishmania donovani promastigotes in the culture fluid.

Option A: Eosinophil

  • Eosinophils are a type of white blood cell.
  • They are an important component of the immune system.

Option C: Lymphocytes

  • The lymphocytes are formed in the bone marrow and are present in lymphoid tissues.
  • Their levels are higher in viral infections.

Option D: RBC

  • RBCs are the most important cells found in the blood.
  • Polycythemia is caused due to high RBC count.

questions.text: A microbiologist was making an antibody derived from a single clone of the plasma cell. These types of antibodies are used in the treatment of some types of cancers. These antibodies can recognize the cancerous cells and kill them. The microbiologist said to the students that these techniques are very useful for the antibodies production. Which technique is used to produce these antibodies?
questions.solution:
Option A: Hybridoma technique

  • The hybridoma technique is used to produce specific antibodies- Monoclonal antibodies (mAb).
  • Hybridoma technique:-
    • The Nobel prize was awarded to Kohler and Milstein for the same.
    • Monoclonal antibodies (mAb) are defined as the antibodies derived from a single clone of plasma cells, all having the same antigen specificity, i.e. produced against a single epitope of an antigen.
  • Principle- B cells fused with myeloma cells to produce hybridoma cells on HAT media (hypoxanthine aminopterin thymine media).

Types of cells:

  • Unfused spleen B cells: can grow but don't survive long (mortal).
  • Unfused myeloma cells: can't grow but are immortal.
  • Hybridoma cells have the property of both B cells and myeloma cells (immortal): they can grow and survive long.

Types of monoclonal antibodies:

  • Mouse mAb contains 100% mouse-derived proteins.
  • The mouse proteins being foreign can induce an immune response in humans producing human anti-mouse antibodies (HAMA), which in turn, eliminate the mAb faster from the body.
  • Chimeric mAb is prepared by recombination of 34% mouse proteins (variable region) and 66% human proteins (constant region).
  • Humanized mAb: Here, only the antigen binding site is mouse-derived (10%), and the remaining part of mAb is human-derived.
  • Human mAb: 100% of amino acids are human-derived.
  • It is the best-accepted mAb.

Option B: Complement formation

  • The complement system contains small numbers of proteins.
  • These proteins circulate in the bloodstream as inactive precursors.
  • It is not used for antibody production.

Option C: Unique technique

  • The hybridoma technique is used for the production of monoclonal antibodies, not with a unique technique.

Option D: Interleukins production

  • These are a type of cytokines.
  • First, it is produced by leukocytes, then later produced by many other body cells.
  • It is important for the activation and differentiation of immune cells.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of fever, rashes on the palms and sole of foot and headaches for 1 week. He gives no history of any other abnormalities. He has no history of any chronic illnesses. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal a maculopapular rash on the palms and soles. The microscopy confirmed the causative organism as Treponema pallidum. Which of the following stain can be used for the organism involved in the patient's current pathology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer

Option A: Fontana's stain

  • This is a case of syphilis in which the patient presents with complaints of fever, rashes on the palms and sole of foot and headaches for 1 week.
  • On examination of the patient, there is a maculopapular rash on the palms and soles of the patient.
  • Syphilis is caused by Treponema pallidum.
  • Fontana stain is used for Treponema pallidum.
  • Microscopy:
    • Silver impregnation method:
      • Levaditi stain (for tissue section): corkscrew-shaped Treponema pallidum.
      • Fontana stain (smear)- showing the spiral morphology.

Other Options

Option B: Acid-fast

  • Acid-fast stain/ ZN stain is used to stain acid-fast organisms (Mycobacterium) or structures (Endospore).

Option C: Methenamine-silver

  • Gomori Methenamine-Silver (GMS) stain: for fungal organisms.

Option D: PAS

  • Periodic Acid–Schiff (PAS) is a staining method used to detect polysaccharides such as glycogen and mucosubstances such as glycoproteins, glycolipids and mucins in tissues.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male presents due with a sore throat for 6 days. It is associated with swollen gums and painful ulcers in the mouth. He reports sloughing off tissue from the mouth and throat due to the spread of infection from the gums. A provisional diagnosis of Vincent's angina is made based on the clinical features. Which of the following is known to be the causative agent for Vincent's angina?
questions.solution:
Option D: Borrelia

  • Vincent Angina (Trench Mouth)
  • Progressive painful infection with ulceration, swelling and sloughing off dead tissue from the mouth and throat due to the spread of infection from the gums.
  • Causative organism: Bacillus fusiformis and Borrelia vincentii.
  • The clinical features are painful, swollen, bleeding gums, small, painful ulcers over the gums, and characteristic fetid breath. The ulcers may spread to the throat and tonsils.
  • It is insidious in onset, with less fever and less discomfort in the throat.
  • The membrane, which usually forms over one tonsil, can be easily removed, revealing an irregular ulcer on the tonsil.
  • A throat swab will show both organisms typical of the disease, namely fusiform bacilli and spirochaetes.
  • Treatment: The infection is readily treated by bed rest, administering penicillin or other antibiotics, and using antiseptic mouth rinses. Regular tooth brushing is the most effective preventive measure.

Option A: Streptococci

  • Acute Tonsillitis often affects school-going children but also affects adults.
  • It is rare in infants and persons above 50 years of age.
  • Hemolytic Streptococcus is the most common infecting organism.
  • Other causes of infection may be Staphylococci, Pneumococci, or Hemophilus influenzae.
  • These bacteria may primarily infect the tonsil or may be secondary to a viral infection.

Option B: Candida

  • Candidal infection of the tonsil usually occurs in patients with low immunity.
  • It occurs as white patches in the mouth.
  • Patients usually have a cotton-like feeling in the mouth.

Option C: Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)

  • EBV is the cause of Infectious mononucleosis.
  • It often affects young adults.
  • Both tonsils are enlarged, congested, and covered with a membrane. Local discomfort is marked.
  • Paul–Bunnell test (Monospot test) will show a high titer of heterophil antibody.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy with abrupt onset of pain in hip with hip held in abduction. Hemogram is normal. ESR is raised. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
Urgent USG guided aspiration of hip is needed to examine the fluid and rule out septic arthritis . However lack of systamic symptoms like fever and and normal hemogram indicate towards Transient synovitis of hip.

TRANSIENT (TOXIC) SYNOVITIS OF HIP

  • It is self-limiting, inflammatory condition of synovium. It is common cause of hip pain and limping in children from 6 to 12 years of age.
  • Absence of fever and systemic illness
  • USG reveals mild effusion and widening of joint space.
  • Joint aspiration usually reveal a WBC count between 5,000 and 15,000 cells/mL, with more than 25% polymorphonuclear leukocytes.
  • Aspiration should be done to rule out other causes of synovitis.
  • The primary aim of treatment is to expedite spontaneous resolution with brief period of bed rest and non-weight bearing, light traction and use of oral NSAIDs.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy has been brought to the clinic with fever and right leg pain for the last two days. Examination shows erythema, swelling, and tenderness of the femur. He is reluctant to bear the weight of the affected leg. His laboratory investigations show raised ESR and leukocyte count. Which of the following is the most sensitive investigation for detecting early bone infections?
questions.solution:
Option C: Bone scan

  • This patient with fever, erythema, swelling, tenderness of the femur, raised ESR, and leukocyte count most likely has osteomyelitis, an infection of the bone.
  • Bone scan is next in preference to MRI to pick up infections by picking osteoblastic activity at the site of infection.
  • It has high sensitivity but low specificity.
  • Earliest and 100% surest investigation is Aspiration of pus.

Osteomyelitis:

  • Osteomyelitis most commonly develops from transient, hematogenous dissemination of bacterial infection, which eventually seed in the bone.
  • The bacteria continue to grow in the bone cavity, increasing the intramedullary pressure and causing necrosis of the overlying bone cortex.
  • The bacteria then spread to the nearby tissue creating a localized swelling filled with bacteria, dead bone cells, and leukocytes.
  • Evaluation of osteomyelitis includes bone biopsy and culture with imaging.
  • Osteomyelitis can be detected in the early stages by MRI and bone scan.
  • MRI shows a hyperintense area in the bone marrow, while the bone scan shows an area of increased osteoblast activity at the site of infection.
  • X-ray is more valuable in the later stages to reveal the destruction of the cortex but can miss the early stages of the disease.

Option A: X-ray

  • Changes in X-ray evident by 2 weeks.
  • It helps to differentiate whether to operate or not.

Option B: CT scan

  • CT Shows cortex and calcification
  • Cortex looks white on CT

Option D: USG

  • USG is a non-invasive procedure.
  • It is helpful to diagnose fluid collection, soft tissue abnormalities, and periosteal involvement.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the clinic with a complaint of hip pain for the past 6 months. He also complains that hip pain is mild, and it does not radiate. On examination, no visible swelling is noted. The range of motion is limited. An X-ray of the hip is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Giant cell tumor

This patient’s radiographic findings often are diagnostic for the giant cell tumor.

The characteristic x-ray findings of giant cell tumors are:

  1. Eccentric
  2. Expansile
  3. Lobulated
  4. Lytic
  5. Metaphyseal
  6. NO matrix calcification of periosteal new bone formation

Option A: Giant cell tumor

  • A benign but locally aggressive tumor composed of giant cells that arise from the bone marrow
  • Peak incidence between 20 and 40 years
  • Clinical features:
  • Found in the epiphysis or metaphysis of long bones (especially the knee region)
  • Pathological fractures
  • Local pain and swelling
  • Limited range of motion
  • It is the only tumor to involve the joint.
  • Diagnostics :
  •  X-ray: multicystic osteolytic lesions (soap-bubble appearance)
  • Histopathology:
  • Mononuclear, RANKL-expressing cells (neoplastic)
  • Multinucleated giant cells (are reactive and resemble osteoclasts)
  • Treatment: curettage and bone grafting or en-bloc resection to minimize recurrence rate
  • Prognosis: risk of malignant degeneration increases with age; it may spread to the lungs

Option B: Simple Bone Cyst

  • Also known as unicameral Bone Cyst
  • Filled with straw-colored fluid
  • Radiological finding: Trapdoor sign and Fallen leaf sign (Fallen fragment sign)

Option C: Adamantinoma

  • The part affected: Diaphysis

Option D: Ewing's sarcoma

  • The part affected: Diaphysis
  • Origin: marrow cells (marrow biopsy useful to see the extent of the disease)

questions.text: Acetyl-CoA is a common intermediate in carbohydrate, protein, and lipid catabolism and can also be used to synthesize various cell metabolites. Which of the following can not be synthesized from acetyl-CoA?
questions.solution:
Option B: Glucose

  • The acetyl CoA is synthesized from pyruvate via an irreversible reaction with the help of enzyme pyruvate dehydrogenase complex.
  • The overall reaction is: Pyruvate + NAD+ + CoA → Acetyl-CoA + NADH + H+ + CO2

  • Acetyl CoA is never a substrate for gluconeogenesis, i.e., it can never form glucose. It is because acetyl CoA can never be converted back to pyruvate due to the irreversible nature of the Link reaction/PDH reaction under physiological conditions due to highly negative delta-G. 
  • However, acetyl-CoA can stimulate gluconeogenesis by activating pyruvate carboxylase (see fig)

 

 

Option A: Fatty Acids

  • Acetyl CoA is a starting material for fatty acid synthesis. In the first and rate-limiting step of the fatty acid synthesis, two acetyl CoA molecules combine to form malonyl CoA which is the principal donor of carbons for fatty acid synthesis.

Options C and D: Ketone Bodies and Cholesterol

  • For cholesterol and ketone body synthesis, two molecules of acetyl CoA join to form acetoacetyl CoA in the first step. The third molecule of acetyl CoA is added in a second rate-limiting reaction to form HMG CoA.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child presents with complaints of aggressive behavior and developmental delay. On examination, light brown hair is seen, whereas both of his parents had black hair. A diagnosis is made after further investigations, and he has been advised to supplementation of large doses of tryptophan, leucine, and tyrosine in his diet. Which one of the following is the reason behind this treatment?
questions.solution:
Option C: To restore neurotransmitter synthesis

This patient with aggressive behavior, developmental delay, and light brown hair most likely have Classic phenylketonuria.

  • Classic phenylketonuria (PKU) is a family of diseases caused by 100 or more mutations in the gene that codes for Phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH), a key enzyme for the conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine.
  • The inability of phenylalanine to get converted to tyrosine leads to unusually high levels of phenylalanine which are instead converted to phenyl lactate, phenylpyruvate, and phenylacetate.
  • This disease gets its name from high levels of phenyl ketones in the body.
  • These unusually high phenylalanine levels and its metabolites result in CNS symptoms, including mental retardation, developmental delays, failure to walk or talk, and seizures).
  • Patients with classic show features of hypopigmentation (fair hair, light skin, and blue eyes). It is due to the competitive inhibition of tyrosinase by unusually higher levels of phenylalanine, an essential enzyme for the first step in converting tyrosine to melanin.
  • In the normal metabolism of phenylalanine, tyrosine is a non-essential amino acid as it is endogenously produced. Nevertheless, in classic PKU, tyrosine becomes an essential amino acid.
  • Tyrosine is then metabolized to dopamine and norepinephrine – two critical neurotransmitters in the brain.
  • High phenylalanine concentrations decrease brain neurotransmitter concentrations by out-competing the absorption of tyrosine, tryptophan, and leucine.
  • Therefore, the standard dietary regimen in classic PKU consists of a diet low in phenylalanine and high in tyrosine and tryptophan to restore adequate levels of neurotransmitters in the brain and minimize the risk of mental retardation.

Option A: To inhibit PAH activity

  • Phenylalanine hydroxylase needs obligatory cofactor tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) for its regulation, and no other factors significantly affect the enzymatic activity.
  • Increased dietary intake of tyrosine, tryptophan, and leucine may affect the absorption of phenylalanine in the GI tract but does not affect the enzymatic activity of PAH.
  • Additionally, the activity of PAH is already compromised in PKU.

Option B: To activate PAH activity

  • As explained above, PAH's activity is regulated by coenzyme BH4 only, and no other factors affect this activity.
  • Additionally, the activity of PAH is already compromised in PKU.

Option D: To stimulate protein synthesis

  • Amino acids consumed more than the amounts needed for nitrogenous tissue constituents are not stored but are degraded.
  • Leucine is the only amino acid that can stimulate muscle protein synthesis at a very high dose, an effect enhanced in vivo by insulin secretion in response to the leucine dose.
  • The purpose of high doses of these amino acids aims to outcompete phenylalanine to restore neurotransmitters rather than stimulate protein synthesis.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male presents to the clinic with frontal headache. After the careful assessment, a diagnosis of the frontal sinusitis is made. Sinusitis is the inflammation of the sinuses. These sinuses are pneumatized. The pneumatization of the marked structure mainly begins at?
questions.solution:
Option D: 2 Years after the birth

Sphenoid Sinus:

  • The sphenoid Sinus is recognizable at around the third intrauterine month as an evagination from the spheno-ethmoidal recess, and again a small cavity is found at birth.
  • At the two years of life, the main pneumatization of the sphenoid bone progresses, and at age seven has frequently reached the floor of the Sella.
  • Attains adult size by 15 yrs of age.

Option A: Birth

  • The sphenoid Sinus is recognizable at around the third intrauterine month and pneumatization for this sinus occurs at two years of life.
  • The sphenoid sinus attains adult size by 15 yrs of age.

Option B: 2 weeks after birth

  • The sphenoid Sinus is the structure that is marked above.
  • It attains the pneumatization at the age of the 2 years.

Option C: 2 months after birth

  • By the age of the two years, the pneumatization of the sphenoid sinus takes place.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female patient presented to the clinic with the complaint of loss of smell and hearing. She has a history of a road traffic accident in which she suffered a mild concussion 4 months ago. She reports no other symptoms. Regarding her complaint of loss of smell which of the following cranial nerve is not involved in olfaction?
questions.solution:
Option C: Hypoglossal nerve

  • The smell is perceived in the nose's olfactory region, which is high up in the nasal cavity.
  • This area contains millions of olfactory receptor cells.
  • The peripheral process of each olfactory cell reaches the mucosal surface and is expanded into a ventricle with several cilia on it. It acts as a sensory receptor to receive odorous substances.
  • Central processes of the olfactory cells are grouped into olfactory nerves, which pass through the cribriform plate of ethmoid and end in the mitral cells of the olfactory bulb.
  • Axons of mitral cells form the olfactory tract and carry smell to the prepyriform cortex and the amygdaloid nucleus, where it reaches consciousness.
  • The trigeminal nerve carries chemical and noxious stimuli as somatosensory sensations resulting in reflux of mucus secretion & halting of inhalation.
  • The olfactory neuroepithelium harbours sensory receptors of the main olfactory (CN I) system & some trigeminal (CN V) somatosensory nerve endings. This way 5th, 9th & 10th nerves modulate olfactory perception
  • The olfactory system is also associated with the autonomic system at the hypothalamic level.
  • Hypoglossal is a true motor nerve and is not a sensory nerve, so no sensory function is carried by it.

Option A: Glossopharyngeal

  • The glossopharyngeal nerve helps modulate olfactory perception.
  • It also provides motor innervation to the stylopharyngeus muscle, elevating the larynx and pharynx.

Option B: Vagus nerve

  • The Vagus nerve helps modulate olfactory perception.
  • It innervates olfactory and gustatory processing.

Option D: Trigeminal nerve

  • The trigeminal nerve helps modulate olfactory perception.
  • They also carry chemical and noxious stimuli as somatosensory sensations.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a history of nasal discharge and congestion. The attending doctor orders nasal endoscopy to evaluate internal nasal structures. While doing endoscopy, the surgeon approaches an area through which it is difficult to pass an endoscope. The surgeon tells his junior that this is the narrowest part of the nasal septum. Which of the following terms best describes the narrowest part of the nasal cavity?
questions.solution:
Option A: Nasal Valve

  • The nasal valve is formed by the limen nasi and inferior turbinate laterally and the septum medially.
  • The velocity of the air increases as it passes through the nasal valve, the narrowest site of the upper respiratory tract. At this point, turbulent flow is observed in the nasal cavity, with different air layers swirling together. The change from laminar to turbulent flow is paramount as it allows the velocity of the air to reduce, thus allowing prolonged contact of inspired air with the nasal mucosa and therefore allowing the nose to perform its vital functions.
  • During expiration, the narrowest part of the nasal cavity, i.e., the nasal valve area, offers maximum resistance to the nasal airflow leading to the formation of eddy currents that ventilates the sinuses.

Option B: Choanae

  • The Choanae (singular choana), posterior nasal apertures, or internal nostrils are two openings found at the back of the nasal passage between the nasal cavity and the nasopharynx in tetrapods.

Option C: Middle Turbinate

  • Middle Turbinate: It is an ethmoturbinal- a part of the ethmoid bone.
  • It is attached to the lateral wall by a bony lamella called ground or basal lamella.

Option D: Vestibule

  • The anterior and inferior part of the nasal cavity is called the vestibule.
  • It is lined by the skin and contains sebaceous glands, hair follicles, and the hair called vibrissae.
  • Its upper limit on the lateral wall is marked by limen nasi.

questions.text: Sentinel surveillance is the "monitoring of the rate of occurrence of specific diseases/conditions through a voluntary network of doctors, laboratories and public health departments with a view to assessing the stability or change in health levels of a population". Measures involved in sentinel surveillance include all of the following, except?

choices.text: Identifying missing cases in the notification of diseases

questions.solution:
Option D: Identifying cases free of disability

  • Identifying cases free of disability is not included in sentinel surveillance.

Option A: Identifying missing cases in the notification of diseases

  • Identifying the missing cases and thereby supplementing the notified cases is involved in the sentinel surveillance.

Option B: Identifying new cases of infection

  • Identifying new cases and recording the data are also involved in sentinel surveillance.

Option C: Identifying old and new cases

  • Detecting both old and new cases is also involved in sentinel surveillance.

questions.text: A 50-year-old alcoholic presented in an unconscious state and recovered by injection of thiamine followed by overnight parenteral glucose. The next morning, he had normal serum thiamine with blood glucose = 73 mg/dL. Which of the following enzymes/proteins would have low significant physiologic activity in this patient soon after discharge?
questions.solution:
• After an overnight fast (plasma glucose 73 mg/dL), the glucose concentration will be low.
  • At low glucose levels, hexokinase with its higher afﬁnity for glucose can convert all the glucose to glucose 6-phosphate without triggering the release of its isozyme for glucokinase hence glucokinase concentration remains low.
  • Glucokinase has a higher Michaelis-Menten constant (Km) than hexokinase, so, it is mostly active in post prandial state when glucose levels are high in the liver.
  • So, in this patient, the activity of glucokinase would be insignificant as it requires high glucose concentration to be effective.

questions.text: A 25 years old female recently delivered a healthy baby in your hospital. You were the assistant doctor with your senior for the delivery. After successful delivery of the baby your senior asks you what is the ‘first immunization’ of the baby?

choices.text: Handing over the baby to mother

questions.solution:
Colostrum

  • Is the most suitable food immediately after birth of the baby; Regular milk comes 3-6 days after birth.
  • Aka ‘Beestings’, ‘First milk’ or ‘Immune Milk’.
  • High in carbohydrates, proteins, antibodies & low in fat.
  • Contain all five immunoglobulins found in all mammals, IgA (highest), IgD, IgE, IgG & IgM.
  • Known as ‘first immunization’ of newborn.

OPV

  • Oral Polio Vaccine / SABIN is a Bivalent vaccine (P1, P3 strain).
  • Dosage:
    • 1st dose given immediately at birth or as soon as possible, then at 6weeks followed by 10 and 14 weeks.
    • 1st booster: 16-24 m.
    • Another dose at 5 y along with DPT booster.

Handing over the baby to mother

  • Handing over the baby to mother is a wrong option.

DPT + BCG

  • 1st dose of DPT is give at 6 weeks after birth and 1st dose of BCG is given at the time of birth or as early as possible till one year of age.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old female presents to the emergency with complaints of difficulty in breathing. She reports no associated cough or fever. On examination, her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), her pulse is 120/min, her respiration rate is 28/min, and her blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. There are scattered wheezes on pulmonary examination. A chest x-ray is shown below:



Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Option A: Short-acting beta 2 agonists

  • This patient is most likely suffering from acute exacerbation of asthma. The management of acute exacerbation of asthma involves the use of short-acting beta 2 agonists like salbutamol.
  • Short-acting beta 2 agonist drugs are the drugs of choice for treating acute exacerbation of severe asthma. The management of asthma is summarised as follows:

Option B: Long-acting beta 2 agonist

  • Long-acting beta-agonists are a class of bronchodilator drugs with a long duration of action (≥ 12 hours).
  • Their onset of action is variable, which is quick for formoterol and longer for salmeterol.
  • These drugs are used for the long-term control of asthma and COPD symptoms. Usually administered via a nebuliser or metered-dosed inhaler.

Option C: Oral theophylline

  • Oral theophylline is used in the management of asthma. However, it has no role in the treatment of acute exacerbation of asthma.

Option D: Inhaled ipratropium bromide

  • These drugs are used in the treatment of COPD. However, these are not preferred for the treatment of asthma.

questions.text: What's incorrect about the blood vessel causing left arm weakness, numbness, and low blood pressure compared to the right arm in a 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and previous myocardial infarction?

choices.text: On the left side arises from the arch of the aorta
On the right side arises from the brachiocephalic trunk
Vertebral artery arises from 2nd part of the subclavian artery
Divided by scalenus anterior muscle into three parts

questions.solution:
Option C: Vertebral artery arises from 2nd part of the subclavian artery.

  • The vertebral artery arises from 1st part of the subclavian artery.

Option A: On the left side arises from the arch of the aorta
