  • On the left side, the subclavian artery comes directly off the aortic arch.

Option B: On the right side arises from the brachiocephalic trunk

  • The subclavian artery on the right side arises from the brachiocephalic trunk.

Option D: Divided by scalenus anterior muscle into three parts

  • Scalenus anterior muscle divides the subclavian artery into three parts. So, this is a correct statement.

questions.text: A 6-day-old newborn is brought to the physician because he has become increasingly irritable and restless over the past 2 days. During this period, he has had 12 bowel movements. He feeds 10 to 12 times a day. He was born at 38 weeks gestation and weighed 1800 g. He currently weighs 1700 g. His mother has Graves’ disease and received propylthiouracil during the last trimester of pregnancy. She has a history of intravenous heroin use. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), his pulse is 180/min, and his respirations are 50/min. Examination shows mild diaphoresis and a firm 2-cm midline neck swelling. The actively secreting follicles of the structure involved in the patient's pathology are lined by one of the following?
questions.solution:
Option A: Columnar epithelium

  • This is a case of Hyperthyroidism.
  • Normally a thyroid follicle is mostly lined by cuboidal epithelium (central spherical nucleus, with a height of the cell equal to breath)
  • Since the question asked is regarding the secretary follicle, the answer is a columnar epithelium.
  • Secreting active thyroid follicles are lined by a columnar type of epithelium.

Option B: Cuboidal epithelium

  • The thyroid follicle epithelial lining depends on the cells' activity in the secretion of thyroxine.
  • Normally a thyroid follicle is mostly lined by cuboidal epithelium (central spherical nucleus, with a height of the cell equal to breath).
  • Secreting active thyroid follicles are lined by a columnar type of epithelium.

Option C: Squamous epithelium

  • Simple Squamous: Thin rim of cytoplasm above flat /globular nucleus
  • Scanty (resting follicle): Simple squamous

Option D: Pseudostratified squamous

  • The pseudostratified epithelium is very rare in cuboidal and squamous cells. It is seen in columnar form and lines the respiratory tract, male genital tract etc.
  • Normally a thyroid follicle is mostly lined by cuboidal epithelium(not pseudostratified).

questions.text: The spleen is comprised of red pulp and white pulp. The red pulp is the site of blood filtration and the white pulp is the lymphoid tissue that responds to blood-borne antigens. Given that this is true, which of the following is not a component of white pulp?
questions.solution:
Ans: Option B

Solution:

Option B: Vascular sinus

  • Spleen is composed of the red pulp (~ 90%) having venous sinusoids and splenic cords (of Billroth).
  • ↑RBCs
  • Splenic sinusoids filled with blood , so this option is about red pulp not the white pulp
  • Cords of Billroth
  • Reticulocytes

Option A,C,D:

  • White pulp (~ 10%) of the spleen has lymphoid follicles with B lymphocytes at the germinal centers, whereas T cells lies in the periphery.
  • Antigen-presenting cells (APCs) are present in the marginal zone of lymphoid follicles.

learning objective:

1. LYMPHOID FOLLICLES
o with germinal centre (right stained)
o periphery - dark stained
→ In centre - B lymphocytes
→ periphery- T lymphocytes
2. PALS Central arteriole
o Present in lymphoid follicle
o Eccentric (not in centre]
o Surrounded by T lymphocytes

questions.text: The hilum is a wedge-shaped area on the medial aspect of each lung, that allows the passage of blood vessels and nerves into the lungs and helps anchor the lung roots. The structure passing the most anterior through the right hilum would be:
questions.solution:
• Superior pulmonary vein is the anterior-most structure in the hila of each lung.

Fig.: Arrangement of structures in the roots of right and left lungs.

questions.text: A boy presents with injury to medial epicondyle of the humerus. Which of the following would NOT be seen:

choices.text: Complete paralysis of the IIIrd and IVth digits
Decreased sensation of the hypothenar eminence

questions.solution:
Injury to medial epicondyle damages ulnar nerve →

  • Paralysis of flexor carpi ulnaris (loss of ulnar deviation)
  • Medial half of flexor digitorum profundus (loss of DIP flexion)
  • Hypothenar muscle paralysis (and atrophy) and
  • Sensory loss on the hypothenar eminence.

Flexor digitorum superficialis (supplied by median nerve for finger flexion) and extensor digitorum (supplied by radial nerve for finger extension) are still functional.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents with complaints of primary amenorrhea. Her height is 153 cm, weight is 51 kg. She has well-developed breasts. She has no pubic or axillary hair and no hirsutism. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C : Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome

  • The above history suggests a diagnosis of Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome/Testicular Feminization Syndrome
  • XY ( Karyotype Male and Phenotype Female)
  • Testosterone is produced but androgen receptors are defective
  • Affected individuals typically present with
    • Bilateral Testes
    • Breast development
    • Pubic or axillary hair absent
    • Female External genitalia, a blindly ending vagina, No müllerian derivatives (i.e., uterus and fallopian tubes)
    • Because the patient is a genetic male, testes are present & sertoli cells make antimüllerian hormone (AMH), thus, müllerian regression occurs normally ( Reason for absent uterus & tubes in a phenotypic normal female).

Option A : Turner syndrome is associated with short stature and breast development is absent due to absence of estrogen production from ovaries which are streak.

Option B : Stein-Levinthal syndrome or PCOS may rarely present with primary amenorrhea, more commonly presents with oligomenorrhea or secondary amenorrhea, however, here pubic and axillary hair will be normal and may even be associated with hirsutism.

Option D ; Premature ovarian failure presents with secondary amenorrhea.

questions.text: A 35-year-old P3 has a Pap smear showing a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion of the cervix (CIN III), followed by an inadequate colposcopy. Cone biopsy shows squamous cell cancer that has invaded only 1 mm beyond the basement membrane. There are no confluent tongues of tumor, and there is no evidence of lymphatic or vascular invasion. The margins of the cone biopsy specimen are free of disease. What is your Diagnosis?

choices.text: Atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance

questions.solution:
Option B : This woman has a paps smear suggestive of HSIL. This implies that there are dysplastic changes seen in more than the basal 1/3rd of cervical epithelium.

Dysplastic cells Dysplasia CIN Bethesda system
Normal Normal/inflammatory Inflammatory/ ASCUS/ASC-H  
<1/3rd epithelium Mild dysplasia CIN-1 LSIL
1/3rd- 2/3rd epithelium Moderate dysplasia CIN-2 HSIL
>2/3rd epithelium Severe dysplasia CIN-3 HSIL
Almost entire epithelium with intact basement membrane Carcinoma-in-situ CIN-3 HSIL
Basement membrane involved Invasive carcinoma    

Once HSIL is seen on paps smear, the next step is to confirm it with colposcopy biopsy, or in some cases, directly an excisional procedure may be done. Here a colposcopy is performed.

MANAGEMENT OF POSITIVE CERVICAL CYTOLOGY

In the given scenario, since colposcopy is unsatisfactory the next step is to go for an excisional procedure.EXCISIONAL PROCEDURES : include LEEP/LLETZ, punch biopsy and cone biopsy. These provide tissue for diagnosis, are preferred in cases of inadequate or unsatisfactory colposcopy, recurrent CIN-2/3, positive endocervical curettage.

Now, the cone biopsy shows squamous cell cancer that has invaded only 1 mm beyond the basement membrane (with no confluent tongues of tumor and no evidence of lymphatic or vascular invasion.) The margins of the cone biopsy specimen are free of disease. This implies aMicroinvasive carcinoma of the cervix, which is defined as

  • Invasion depth limited to no greater than 5 mm
  • Not visible to Naked eye
Stage I

Limited to Cervix

IA : Microscopic cancer

IA1 : Stromal invasion <3 mm in depth

IA2 : Stromal invasion 3 mm-5 mm in depth

Option A : CIN III was diagnosed on paps smear, however on further investigation via tissue diagnosis, basement membrane was found to be involved, hence the diagnosis is no longer CIN III but microinvasive cancer.

Option C : ASCUS or Atypical cells of undetermined significance may reflect an exuberant benign change or a potentially serious lesion which are unequivocally classified, they are interpreted as being “undetermined significance.” These are not always precursors of cervical pre-malignancy but they need timely diagnosis and careful periodical follow-up. These are non cancerous changes, however here there is squamous cancer involving basement membrane, hence this option is ruled out.

Option D : Carcinoma in situ is cervical cancer, not involving basement membrane.

questions.text: In a 28-year-old woman with endometriosis, what is considered the gold standard investigation to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A :

  • The patient has presented with infertility, menorrhagia and a fixed pelvic mass. There can be 2 main diagnoses here, Endometriosis and Tuberculosis.
  • Menorrhagia is common with early tubercular endometritis but in this question, there is a history of an abdominal mass and its likely a chronic presentation.
  • Endometriosis is a condition of estrogen access and is frequently associated with menorrhagia.
  • A laparoscopy is the best tool to diagnose endometriosis and also to take biopsies to confirm/rule out Tuberculosis

Option B : Tubal microsurgery is done in patient with infertility with diagnosed tubal factor.

Option C : Anti-tubercular drugs are given for pelvic TB, which is less likely the case here as explained above, also the first step here would be to diagnose the pathology by laparoscopy

Option D : Hysterectomy is not an option here as she is a case of infertility with an uncertain diagnosis. Only in women with complete family history and those not responding to medical treatment with severe symptoms, are treated with hysterectomy as a last resort.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, at 14 weeks of pregnancy, presents for routine evaluation. Her blood pressure (BP) is 100/62 mm Hg. Her BP in the first trimester and before pregnancy was 110-130/70-80 mm Hg. Regarding hemodynamic changes in pregnancy, all of the following are true except?

choices.text: Hemodynamic changes start taking place after 12 weeks of gestation
Venocaval compression begins at about 20 weeks of gestation
There is a mid-trimester fall in blood pressure

questions.solution:
Option A: Hemodynamic changes start taking place after 12 weeks of gestation

Cardiac Output:

  • Starts increasing as early as the 5th week
  • Increases by 30 % (6 litres/min)
  • Reaches peak at 32nd –34th week antenatally
  • Even higher during labour and its maximum immediate postpartum

 

 

Heart Sounds in Pregnancy:

  • Exaggerated splitting of the first heart sound and increased loudness of both components
  • A loud, easily heard third sound
  • > 95% develop systolic murmur, which disappears after delivery. 20% have a transient diastolic murmur
  • > 10% develop continuous murmur due to increased mammary blood flow

 

Option B: Venocaval compression begins at about 20 weeks of gestation

  • It typically occurs in pregnant females, usually after 20 weeks of gestation, when the patient is in the supine position. Blood flow from the lower extremities back to the maternal heart and central circulation is impeded due to the uterus compressing the inferior vena cava and aorta.

 

Option C: There is a mid-trimester fall in blood pressure

  • The systolic and diastolic blood pressure fall up to mid-pregnancy. Afterwards, it increases progressively.

 

Option D: Systolic murmur may occur normally

  • There is the presence of systolic murmur in more than 90% of the cases, and the murmur resolves as soon as the baby is delivered.

questions.text: A 51-year-old male diagnosed with pancreatic carcinoma is being prepped for the operation. The doctor counselled the patient regarding Whipple’s procedure and its effects. The patient has given consent for the surgery and anaesthesia. Which of the following would be an inappropriate choice of anaesthesia for its operation?

choices.text: Neuraxial blocks as a primary anesthetic technique
General anesthesia with continuous neuraxial analgesia

questions.solution:
Option A: Neuraxial blocks as a primary anaesthetic technique

  • Utilising medications to block pain during surgery and other operations is known as anaesthesia. Anaesthetics is the name given to these drugs. Injections, inhalations, topical creams, sprays, eye drops, and skin patches are all possible delivery methods. One experiences a loss of awareness or emotion as a result of them.
  • Local anaesthesia numbs a small part of the body. It might be applied to a tiny region surrounding a wound that requires suturing or a tooth that needs to be extracted. During local anaesthesia, patients are awake and conscious.
  • Regional anaesthetic is employed for larger body parts like an arm, a leg, or everything below the waist. One can be given sedation, or one might be awake during the process. A regional anaesthetic may be utilised during childbirth, a Cesarean section (C-section), or small procedures.
  • General anaesthesia affects the entire body. One becomes immobile and unconscious as a result. It is utilised during critical procedures such as organ transplants, back surgeries, head surgeries, and surgeries on the heart and brain.
  • The administration of local anaesthetic in or near the CNS is referred to as “neuraxial anaesthesia.” Local anaesthetic is injected into the intrathecal region during spinal and neuraxial anaesthesia (subarachnoid space).
  • Using neuraxial anaesthesia for upper abdominal surgery is risky to obtain a comfortable sensory level for the patient. Therefore, an epidural is utilised with general anaesthesia for upper abdominal surgery.

Option B: General anaesthesia

  • The main objective of general anaesthesia is to make a patient comatose, numb to pain, and in control of autonomic reflexes. Intravenous (IV) anaesthetics, inhalational anaesthetics, intravenous sedatives, synthetic opioids, and neuromuscular blocking medications are the five primary categories of anaesthetics.
  • As long as there are no contraindications, general anaesthesia is best suited for patients with surgical procedures that require prolonged profound relaxation. General anaesthesia is required for surgeries that cannot be sufficiently sedated with a local or regional anaesthetic.

Option C: General anaesthesia with neuraxial blocks

  • In patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease undergoing major abdominal surgery, epidural analgesia combined with general anaesthesia lowers the incidence of postoperative pneumonia.
  • Indications are usually similar to general anaesthesia, including penile procedures, Inguinal hernia repair, Lower limb orthopaedic procedures, thoracotomy, Cardiac bypass, and other cardiac surgeries.

Option D: General anaesthesia with continuous neuraxial analgesia

  • An approach for perioperative pain management with many uses in anesthesiology is epidural anaesthesia. 
  • Pain in patients operated under general anaesthesia can be managed by prolonged postoperative analgesia that is achieved with continuous or patient-controlled infusions of local anaesthetics, opioids, adjuvants, or a combination of labour epidural analgesia and a single-shot epidural injection of depot version of morphine.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presents with an ovarian mass for which a fertility-sparing surgery was performed and histopathology showed schiller-duval bodies. Are all of the following true about this ovarian tumor, except?

choices.text: It is a type of malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary
It produces hCG, which is a valuable tumor marker
Surgical staging and unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy are generally the treatment of choice.

questions.solution:
Option C : The presence of schiller-duval bodies is suggestive of an endodermal sinus ovarian tumour. The tumour marker for this ovarian tumour is AFP.

The endodermal sinus tumor (yolk sac tumor)

  • Mostly observed between 15-20 yrs of age
  • Derived from the primitive yolk sac
  • Third most frequent malignant germ cell tumors of the ovary( After Dysgerminoma, Immature teratoma)
  • Abdominal or pelvic pain is the most frequent initial symptom, occurring in about 75% of patients,
  • Characteristic histological feature is the presence of cystic spaces lined by flattened epithelium, within this space; a tuft of vascular tissue is often seen. This is called as Schiller - Duval body.

  • Surgical staging and unilateral salpingo-oopherectomy in generally the treatment of choice.
  • Tumor produces alpha feto protein which is a useful marker to monitor regression and detect recurrence. Another important tumour marker is alfa-1 anti-trypsin

Option A :It is a type of malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary.

Option B : It is derived from primitive yolk sac

Option D : Surgical staging and unilateral salpingo-oopherectomy in generally the treatment of choice.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presents with involuntary urine loss for 2 months while coughing, laughing, lifting weights, or standing. She had 3 vaginal deliveries, last childbirth was 5 years ago. Urodynamic studies are advised. Ultrasound shows average post-void urine volume. What is the likely cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Stress incontinence

  • The history is most likely suggestive of stress incontinence.
  • Urinary incontinence is of two main types: stress and urges urinary incontinence, which may occur in isolation or present as mixed urinary incontinence.
    • Stress incontinence is the involuntary loss of urine when the intravesical pressure exceeds the maximum urethral pressure with an increase in the abdominal pressure, i.e., coughing or sneezing.
  • There is no specific medical treatment for stress incontinence. However, pelvic floor exercises and weight loss can help. Surgery is the best treatment option.
  • Different types of urinary incontinence are:

 

 

  • When the woman voids a small quantity of urine involuntarily while sneezing, coughing or laughing.
  • The condition also develops during pregnancy and soon after delivery.
  • No desire to pass urine but dribbles a small quantity on stress.

Option A: Fistula

  • A fistula communicates between two cavities, such as vesicovaginal fistula, urethrovaginal, and uterovaginal fistulas. These fistulas present with incontinence, unrelated to activity or raised intra-abdominal pressure.

Option C: Urge incontinence

  • It is associated with a sudden and abrupt desire to void. It is associated with detrusor instability (overactive bladder) or detrusor hyperreflexia secondary to neurological disease.
  • Although stress incontinence is the most common type of urinary continence in all women, urge incontinence is the more common in older women.

Option D: Overflow incontinence

  • It refers to the leakage of a small amount of urine from mechanical forces on the overdistended bladder.

questions.text: A full-term multigravida is in labor for 12 hours. Physical examination revealed that the tongue was dry, and uterine contractions lasting for 45 seconds were felt every 3 minutes. Per vaginal examination revealed that the cervix is thick, dilated 6-7 cm, amniotic membranes are absent, and the fetal head is at station -2 with a caput till +3 station. Urine is blood-stained. Vitals signs are as follows; pulse rate 116/min, blood pressure 90/60. What is the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Option C: Obstructed Labor

  • It is a case of obstructed labour since the patient has been experiencing strong contractions for a considerable amount of time; there are indicators of dehydration, an excessive caput, and blood-stained urine due to the bladder's prolonged compression.
  • Even with strong uterine contractions, obstructed labour occurs when a mechanical obstacle prevents the presenting part's gradual descent.
  • Causes
    • Cephalopelvic misalignment
    • Soft tissue impediment
    • Malpresentations and malpositions
    • A large or deformed foetus
  • Clinical characteristics and issues
    • Maternal fatigue
    • Dehydration
    • Sepsis 
    • Caput succedaneum
    • Asphyxia, acidosis, cerebral bleeding, and mortality in foetuses
    • Hematuria: Due to the pubic symphysis and the presenting section compressing the bladder's base
    • Shock
    • Complications : Uterine rupture, PPH, Genitourinary fistula (by pressure necrosis), maternal and fetal morbidity and mortality

Option A: Advanced labour with expected findings

 

  • In this case, cervical dilatation is incomplete, i.e. 6-7 cm and fetal head being at station -1 caput at station +3 along with signs of maternal exhausion and bladder compression.

Option B: Prolonged latent phase

  • The latent phase is until the dilatation of the cervix reaches 3-4 cm.
  • The latent phase can be extended by more than 20 hours in the nullipara and 14 hours in the multipara.
  • However, the cervical dilatation, in this case, is already 6-7 cm, indicating that the labour has progressed from the latent phase into the active phase.

Option D: Shoulder dystocia

  • Shoulder dystocia occurs when the foetal shoulders fail to deliver spontaneously after the head has been delivered due to the impaction of the anterior shoulder against the pubic bone.
  • In this case, the head of the fetus has not been delivered yet; therefore, shoulder dystocia is not possible.

questions.text: A 29-year-old presents to the physician with complaints of pain during her menstrual bleeding. She is nulliparous and has not been unable to conceive for 3 years, even after having multiple intercourse per week with her husband. The patient is vitally stable, and other physical examinations show no abnormalities. The patient's ultrasound shows an endometriotic cyst of 8 cm in the right ovary. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: IUI as early as possible, to utilize the remaining fertility potential
Ovulation induction and follow fertile period

questions.solution:
Option B: Surgery first & then infertility treatment

  • This is a case of female infertility secondary to the endometriotic cyst.
  • In this case, the patient has presented with complaints of dysmenorrhea and inability to conceive for 3 years.

An infertile patient with an endometriotic cyst is best treated by excision of the cyst followed by medical treatment of infertility, including ovulation induction, IUI or assisted reproduction.

  • Surgical management of endometriosis broadly includes:
    • Patients with infertility: Laparoscopic ovarian cystectomy, adhesiolysis, and electrocoagulation of endometriotic implants.
    • If the family is complete and the patient has severe pain or menstrual complaints: Hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy.

Option A: IUI as early as possible to utilize the remaining fertility potential

  • Before doing intrauterine insemination (IUI), we must treat the endometriotic cyst surgically.

Option C: Danazol first and then IUI/IVF

  • Medical treatment of endometriosis is not preferred here as the cyst is large and can be easily and effectively treated by cystectomy
  • Danazol is also not preferred in women of reproductive age as it may cause virilization of fetus in case a pregnancy happens

Option D: Ovulation induction and follow a fertile period

  • Ovulation induction and following the fertile period is the treatment of infertility, but in this case, the cyst should be excised first before the treatment of infertility.

questions.text: Identify the shape of the maternal pelvis shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Option C : The pelvis explained in the question is suggestive of anthropoid pelvis

  • The anthropoid pelvis is marked by an oval inlet (but the anteroposterior diameter exceeds the transverse), the pelvic side walls diverge, and the sacrum is inclined posteriorly.
  • Its associated with Persistent occipito posterior presentation and Face pubis delivery
  • The android (male-like) pelvis, where the inlet is wedge shaped, the pelvic sidewalls are convergent, the ischial spines are prominent, the subpubic arch is narrow, and the sacrum is inclined anteriorly in its lower one third. It is likely to be associated deep transverse arrest dystocia.

Comparison of types of pelvis

  Gynaecoid  Anthropoid  Android  Platypelloid
INLET  Round  Antero-posteriorly oval Triangular/Heart shaped  Transversely oval/Flat 
CAVITY (Side walls) Straight/slightly divergent  Straight  Convergent  Straight/Divergent 
CAIVTY (Sacrosciatic) Wide Wide  Narrow  Narrow 
OUTLET (Sub-pubic angle) Wide (85 deg) Slightly narrow  Narrow  Very wide (>90 deg)
OUTLET (Ischial spines) Not prominent Not prominent Prominent Not prominent

Option A : A gynaecoid pelvis is more or less round in shape and is associated with best chances of vaginal delivery.

Option B : Android pelvis has a triangular or heart shaped pelvis and is associated with deep transverse arrest in occipito-posterior position. Short anterior rotation occurs such that the position becomes occipito-transverse as there is no space anteriorly for further rotation. Mode of delivery : Manual rotation and Forceps extraction :(Sagittal suture of baby should be in AP plane of pelvis) or Cesarean section.

Option D : Platypelloid or flat pelvis has a transversely oval inlet.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman who is pregnant for the first time visits the gynecology outpatient department with a complaint of not having her menstrual period for 36 weeks. She also reports experiencing abdominal pain on and off for the last seven days and has a history of Strassman metroplasty. During the abdominal examination, uterine contractions are observed, and the cervix is found to be dilated to 3 cm. What is the recommended course of action in this case?

choices.text: Induction of labor with prostaglandins after pelvic assessment
Start oxytocin drip and monitor closely.
Give antispasmodics and send the patient back.

questions.solution:
Option B: Elective Lower segment caesarian section(LSCS)

  • The patient has presented in labour with uterine contractions and dilatation of the cervix.
  •  Unification surgical procedures (Strassman operation, Tompkins operation, or Jones’ wedge metro­plasty operation) or Hysteroscopic resection of uterine sep­tum are the corrective procedures for Uterine anomalies.
  • These are done for a history of recurrent pregnancy losses.
  • Therefore, the mode of delivery in all these corrective procedures is Caesarean section due to the risk of scar rupture in labour.

Indications for LSCS

  • Cephalopelvic disproportion or contracted pelvis
  • Placenta previa
  • Fetal hypoxia
  • Previous Caesarean: >=2, previous classical Caesarean, previous hysterotomy
  • Pelvic tumours
  • Active genital herpes
  • Transverse lie, complicated breech, non-cephalic presenting twin
  • Uterine rupture
  • Scarred uterus such as previous myomectomy, unification surgery
  • Other medical or surgical complications necessitating surgery

Option A: Induction of labour with prostaglandins after pelvic assessment

  • Induction or augmentation of labour are contraindicated in such cases as vaginal delivery must not be done

Option C: Start oxytocin drip and monitor closely

  • Oxytocin is a drug used for augmentation of uterine contraction
  • It is contraindicated in patients who have a history of previous corrective uterine surgery.
  • As it may lead to rupture of the previous uterine scar.

Option D: Give antispasmodics and send the patient back

  • It is an incorrect option because there is no role of antispasmodics or even tocolytics at 36 weeks in labour.

questions.text: A 29-year-old primigravida presenting in labor is admitted at term for delivery. As the second stage of labor is prolonged, the obstetrician decides to apply a forceps. He now assesses the PV findings to check the applicability of forceps. In which of the following pelvic findings can forceps NOT be applied?

choices.text: Saggital suture of the head is 15 degrees short of rotation in the pelvis
Presenting part is at zero station

questions.solution:
Option C : Forceps in modern obstetrics is not applied higher than +2 station. Low and outlet forceps are used at below +2 station and head at perineum respectively. The use of forceps is indicated when it is required to cut short second stage of labour in certain maternal conditions, inadequate progress or fetal distress.

Following are the criteria for operative vaginal delivery

  Criteria for forceps delivery
Outlet

Fetal scalp visible without separating the labia

Fetal skull has reached the pelvic floor

Sagittal suture is in the anterio - posterior diameter or right or left occiput anterior or posterior position (rotation does not exceed 45o)
Low

Leading point of the skull (not caput) is at station plus 2 cm or more and not on the pelvic floor.

Two Subdivisions:

  • Rotation of 45o or less from the occipito - anterior position.
  • Rotation of more than 45o including the occipito - posterior position

Low and outlet procedures are acceptable now and mid and high are not done in modern obstetrics since they are associated with increased maternal and fetal morbidity.

Forceps can be applied for mento-anterior face presentation and in the presence of caput. These both are contraindications for applying vacuum

Option A : Forceps can be applied when sagittal suture of head is at the most 45 degree short of rotation in pelvis.

Option B : Forceps can be applied for mento anterior face presentation, while vacuum cannot as it may cause soft tissue trauma to the face.

Specific Pre-requisites and contraindications
Forceps Vacuum
  • Fully rotated head or <45° remaining
  • Vertex
  • After coming head of breech
  • Mento-anterior face
  • Fully dilated Cervix
  • Station → +2 & below
  • Can be used in preterm
  • Can be used in presence of Caput
  • Rotated head or Non rotated head
  • Used for Cephalic presentation only
  • Not used for breech or face
  • >6 cm dilated Cervix
  • Station → +2 & below
  • Cannot be used for preterm fetus / fetal coagulopathy
  • Cannot be used in presence of Caput

Option D : Forceps can be used in presence of caput while vacuum cannot be.

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman arrives at the pulmonology ward complaining of a dry cough, nonspecific chest pain, and dyspnea on exertion for the past two years. Given persistent symptoms, she is evaluated with chest x-rays, which show bilateral lower zone nodular opacities with calcification and a right pleural effusion. Her CBC reveals an elevated platelet count of 650,000/mm3. The pleural fluid cytological and biochemical examination shows an exudative lymphocyte-predominant pleural effusion with normal levels of adenosine deaminase. Pleural fluid malignant cytology shows a few atypical cells. The histopathological examination of the pleural biopsy suggests metastatic deposits of dyscohesive malignant cells of epithelioid variety, which are favorable for calretinin and WT-1 on immunohistochemistry. What will be the probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Malignant Mesothelioma

  • These clinical signs are suggestive of malignant mesothelioma.
  • Malignant mesothelioma is the most common tumour of the pleura.

  • In 20% of malignant mesotheliomas, the tumour arises from the peritoneum.
  • Exposure to asbestos is the major known risk factor.
  • More common in males, most common after 40 years of age.
  • There are three types:
    • Epithelial
    • Sarcomatous
    • Biphasic
  • Hemorrhagic pleural effusion is usually seen with malignant mesothelioma.

Option A: Small cell lung cancer

  • Small-cell lung cancer is the development of malignant cells in the lung tissues.
  • The primary risk factor for small cell lung cancer is smoking.
  • Coughing and shortness of breath are small-cell lung cancer symptoms.

Option B: Thoracic Pheochromocytoma

  • The increased release of catecholamines causes elevated blood pressure and other pheochromocytoma-specific symptoms.
  • Less frequent symptoms may also include pain in the chest or abdomen, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, pallor, weakness, and weight loss.

Option D: Carcinoid tumour

  • A particular variety of neuroendocrine tumour that develops from neuroendocrine cells is the carcinoid tumour.
  • The symptoms of carcinoid tumour are:
  • Diarrhea
  • Wheezing
  • Flushing
  • Abdominal cramping
  • Peripheral edema

questions.text: A 54-year-male patient got admitted to a hospital with a chief complaint of bulging veins in both lower limbs. On the Doppler test, abnormal blood flow in lower limbs was noted. A diagnosis of bilateral varicose veins in the lower limbs was made. The patient was posted for surgery, and the varicose veins were successfully stripped bilaterally from the ankle to the groin. What is the most common complication that can be expected after varicose vein stripping?
questions.solution:
Option C: Ecchymosis

  • Complications of varicose vein surgery
    • Recurrence is the most common incidence, which occurs after surgery in up to 10%
    • Hematoma or Ecchymosis is the most common cause of discomfort after varicose vein surgery.
    • Sensory nerve injury can also be caused after varicose veins surgery.
    • The greater saphenous vein should only be stripped to just below the knee to avoid damage to the accompanying saphenous nerve.
    • The sural nerve must be carefully dissected off the lesser saphenous vein at the ankle.

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​Option A: Infection

  • Infection is not associated with long saphenous vein stripping to the knee.
  • There are rare chances of infection after long saphenous vein stripping to the knee, but sometimes it can cause cellulitis.

​​​​​​​Option B: Hemorrhage

  • Hemorrhage is not the complication below-knee stripping.
  • Hemorrhage can be a complication of traumatic brain injury.

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​Option D: Thromboembolism

  • The most common complication after varicose vein surgery is Ecchymosis.
  • It can be caused by lower limb injury or fracture and surgery of the lower extremities.

​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 66-year-old female presents to the clinic with right-sided exophthalmos. Outside proptosis of the right eye was first seen six years ago. Thyroid hormone levels revealed a total T4 level of 10 μg/dL, and a total T3 level of 100 ng/dL, while the TSH levels were 2 mU/L. An MRI examination revealed the lesion seen in the figure below.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Optic nerve sheath meningioma:

  • Optic nerve sheath meningiomas are extremely rare benign tumors.
  • They arise from the arachnoid cap cells of the optic nerve.
  • They compress the optic nerve and present a gradual loss of vision in one eye, pain, protrusion, and diplopia, in the affected eye.
  • Despite their slow growth, they immediately impact the anterior visual pathway, which can cause profound vision loss.
  • Removing the tumor without further difficulties is difficult because of the condition's proximity to the optic nerve.
  • Optic nerve sheath meningioma would show a "tram track appearance" of the optic nerve in a contrast-enhanced study.

  • Calcification of the optic nerve sheath and adjacent bony hyperostosis seen on CT scan
  • Apical expansion of the tumor
  • Optic nerve sheath thickening and enhancement with relative sparing of the optic nerve substance ("tram track" sign)
  • Prominent contrast enhancement on MRI and CT scan
  • Extradural tumor extension
  • No Calcification or hyperostosis seen on CT scan
  • Kinking or buckling of the optic nerve
  • Thickening of optic nerve and sheath by the tumor
  • Variable contrast enhancement with MRI and CT
  • Cystic spaces within the optic nerve

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Optic glioma:

  • Gliomas of the optic pathway are benign CNS tumors that mainly affect children.
  • Despite these tumors' relatively modest growth, their position prevents removal without causing vision loss in at least one eye.
  • The computerized tomography CT scan exhibits fusiform or saccular dilatation of the optic nerve, which is diagnostic for optic glioma.
  • Optic gliomas are associated with neurofibromatosis 1.

 

Option C - Retinoblastoma:

  • Retinoblasts, basophilic cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and scanty cytoplasm, make up retinoblastoma.
  • Most retinoblastomas are undifferentiated. However, variable levels of differentiation are evident because rosettes occur.
  • The tumor may be in the subretinal space or the vitreous chamber, with the tumor cells dispersing throughout the eye, or it may appear with a combination of both features.
  • Optic nerve invasion occurs when a tumor spreads into the brain's subarachnoid region.
  • In the CT scan of retinoblastoma, intra-orbital calcifications are usually observed.

 

Option D - Thyroid ophthalmopathy:

  • Thyroid ophthalmopathy is a complex inflammatory condition of the orbit.
  • The orbital fibroblasts, adipocytes, extraocular muscles, optic nerve, and orbital vasculature are affected in this process.
  • The state of the systemic thyroid can have an unpredictable impact on how the ophthalmopathy develops.
  • In euthyroid patients, it is difficult to diagnose.
  • Clinical manifestations might range from unilateral dry eye to bilateral problems that could endanger vision.
  • Thyroid ophthalmopathy shows a "Coca-Cola bottle appearance" of the extraocular muscles due to fusiform dilatation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the hospital with his wife and presents with acute onset of severe pain in his right great toe. He has long-standing diabetes mellitus and hypertension. On physical examination, inflammation and erythema of the affected joint are visible. On x-ray, rat bite erosions with overhanging edges are seen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option B: Gouty arthritis

  • Patient with arthritis due to gout often presents with swollen, red, and painful asymmetric joints.
  • Risk factors of gout include hypertension, diabetes mellitus, obesity, chronic alcohol use, and dyslipidemia.
  • A painful metatarsophalangeal joint of the great toe is the classical manifestation of gouty arthritis.
  • Tophus formation often occurs on the olecranon bursa, Achilles tendon, and external ear.
  • Radiographically, the typical finding of gout is a punched-out lytic lesion with a sclerotic margin and overhanging edge, defined as the "Martel sign" or "rat-bite" erosion.

 

Figure: Gouty arthritis

Option A: Rheumatoid arthritis

  • The radiographic hallmarks of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) are soft tissue swelling, osteoporosis, joint space narrowing and marginal erosions.
  • arthritis (musculoskeletal manifestations) | Radiology Reference Article | Radiopaedia.org" class="n3VNCb KAlRDb" data-noaft="1" jsaction="load:XAeZkd;" jsname="HiaYvf" src="https://prod-images-static.radiopaedia.org/images/32161/dd9f125ed61b0524efc35c13421116_gallery.jpg" style="width: 270px; height: 270px; margin: 0px;" />

 

Option C: Osteoarthritis

  • The radiographic findings of primary osteoarthritis are-
    • Nonuniform loss of joint spaces
    • Osteophyte formation
    • Cyst formation
    • Subchondral sclerosis.
  • The radiographs of an initial stage of osteoarthritis may not show all of the findings

 

Option D: Ankylosing Spondylitis

  • Radiographic findings of ankylosing spondylitis are bilateral symmetrical sacroiliitis (earliest feature), bamboo-spine (knobby spine, poker back or universal syndesmophytes), syndesmophytes, and enthesitis.

questions.text: Which among the following has the lowest resting membrane potential?
questions.solution:
Correct answer : Option D Red Blood Cells

Cell Type Resting Membrane Potential (mV)
Neurons -70 to -90
Skeletal Muscle Cells -80 to -90
Cardiac Muscle Cells -80 to -90
Smooth Muscle Cells -50 to -60
Red Blood Cells -15 to -20

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is accompanied to the obstetrics and gynecology OPD by her mother. The girl has not yet started menstruation. On examination, she has developed secondary sexual characteristics appropriately. The gynecologist provides counseling and reassurance to them and educates them about the stages of puberty. What is the correct sequence of events in puberty?
questions.solution:
Option D: Thelarche-pubarche-growth spurt-menarche

  • In girls, the sequence of changes in puberty is as follows:
    • Thelarche-pubarche-growth spurt-menarche
  1. Thelarche is the appearance of breast tissue due to the action of estradiol. Estradiol is produced mainly from the ovaries.
  2. Pubarche is the appearance of pubic hair, which is due to the adrenal gland's androgens effects.
  3. The growth spurt is the height increase that affects axial (trunk) and appendicular (limb) components. In later puberty, however, the growth spurt is primarily truncal. Acne first appears.
  4. Menarche is the first menstrual bleed. It occurs 2 to 2.5 years after thelarche. The first menstrual bleed is not associated with ovulation. It is caused by the effect of estradiol on the uterine lining.

Option A: Thelarche-pubarche-menarche-growth spurt

  • Menarche occurs at the end of the growth spurt.
  • It occurs 2 to 2.5 years after thelarche.

Option B: Pubarche-thelarche-growth spurt-menarche

  • The first step of puberty in females is the appearance of breast tissue.
  • It is termed thelarche.

Option C: Menarche-growth spurt-thelarche-pubarche

  • Menarche never occurs as the first step in puberty.
  • It is rather the last event in female puberty.

questions.text: 12 yr old, boy presents to the pediatric OPD of a govt. Hospital with a leaning forward posture and complains of back pain, fever, night sweats and also there is weight loss. On properly examining the patient with all the investigations done, finally he was asked to get X-ray of his spine done. On X-ray it was found that his T12 vertebrae has collapsed. CBNAAT was done and after confirming TB he was started on ATT. After few months his Upper segment: lower segment ratio decreases, now the doctor want to rule out all of the following, except:
questions.solution:
Option C: Achondroplasia

Upper segment: lower segment ratio increases in Achondroplasia- cause of short limb dwarfism.

  • A - Autosomal dominant inheritance
  • C - Champagne glass pelvis on X- ray
  • H - Hand abnormality (Trident Hand)
  • O - Obesity
  • N - Neurological problems
  • D - Delayed motor milestones
  • R - Recognized at birth
  • O - Bowing of legs
  • P - Proximal limb shortening
  • LA - Large head
  • S - Short stature
  • I - Interpedicular distance b/w vertebra decreases

Option B:Alagille syndrome

Neonatal cholestasis

  • Triangular facies
  • Pulmonary stenosis
  • Butterfly vertebra
  • Triangular facies also seen in Russell Silver Syndrome

Option A:Spondylo epiphyseal dysplasia

This disease Caused by mutations in the COL2A1gene

  • Short trunk dwarfism
  • Type II collage defect

Option D: Pott’s disease

Also known as Caries spine

  • Short trunk dwarfism

Learning objective

Short trunk dwarfism (US:LS ratio- decreases) Short limb dwarfism (US:LS ratio- increases)
Short- Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia Rickets
Man- Mucopolysaccharidosis Achondroplasia
May- Mucolipidosis Osteogenesis imperfecta
Climb- Caries spine Congenital hypothyroidism
High- Hemivertebra Chondroectodermal dysplasia

questions.text: A pediatrician on-call duty was called over to the gynecology labor room to look after the newborn; on the way to the hospital, he met with a minor accident and could not make it to the labor room and instead sent his junior resident for the same and is told to conduct the ‘Routine care’ for neonatal resuscitation. Which of the following steps could be skipped by JR?

choices.text: Ongoing evaluation of vital parameters of all babies

questions.solution:
Option B: Suction airway of all babies

  • The suction airway of all babies is not recommended.
  • Baby care is very important after birth.
  • It is important to position the head and neck to open the airways.
  • Suctioning is needed to clear the secretions.
  • 'Routine care' consists of the following;
    • Provide warmth to all babies.
    • Proper positioning of the baby.
    • Suction airways only if necessary.
    • Dry the baby.
    • Ongoing evaluation of vital parameters of all babies.

Option A: Provide warmth to all babies

  • It is very important to warm newborn babies to normalize their body temperature of all babies.
  • The blanket and skin-to-skin contact can be used to warm the babies.
  •  Bed lamps or warmer can also be used to warm babies.

Option C: Dry the baby

  • All babies should be dried by using a blanket or towel after birth.
  • The first step after delivery is to warm and dry the baby

Option D: Ongoing evaluation of vital parameters of all babies

  • It is very important to evaluate the vitals of all newborn babies.
  • Blood pressure, pulse, oxygen saturation, respiration rate, and body temperature are the important vitals to be measured

questions.text: At what levels of potassium do we see muscle paralysis in a pediatric patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Serum Potassium at 2.5 mEq/L

  • Hypokalemia is a serum potassium level below the normal value, usually defined as 3.5 mEq/L.
    • Potassium is primarily an intracellular cation with cells containing approximately 98 per cent of total body potassium.
    • Hypokalemia is classified as mild, moderate and severe as given:
      • Mild hypokalemia – Potassium level between 3 and 3.5 mEq/L
      • Moderate hypokalemia – Potassium level between 2.5 and 3 mEq/L
      • Severe hypokalemia – Potassium level less than 2.5 mEq/L
  • Symptoms generally do not manifest until the serum potassium is below 3 mEq/L unless there is a significant fall in serum potassium.
    • Muscle weakness typically starts in the proximal muscles of the lower extremities and progresses upwards to the trunk and upper extremities.
    • As the potassium drops below 2.5 mEq/L, severe weakness progresses, involving respiratory muscles, which may result in respiratory failure and death.

Option A: Serum Potassium at 5.0 mEq/L

  • 5.0 mEq/L is the normal upper limit for serum potassium, and no symptoms of muscle cramps or paralysis are obvious at this stage.

Option C: Serum Potassium at 3.0 mEq/L

  • A serum potassium level of 3.0 mEq/L is called mild hypokalemia, and no/very mild signs and symptoms are evident.

Option D: Serum Potassium at 3.5 mEq/L

  • The lower normal limit of serum potassium and symptoms start appearing if the potassium levels fall below 3.5 mEq/L.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy has been brought by his mother to the pediatric clinic with complaints of cyanosis and irritability. His mother mentioned that he is not active and socially intelligent like other children of his age and has a different body appearance. On examination, he has a strabismus, flat and broad forehead, a medial eyebrow flare, a flat nasal bridge, and a pan-systolic murmur with high blood pressure. Genetic testing has revealed that the ELN gene has been deleted from a chromosome. Which of the following is the most likely clinical manifestation of this genetic disorder?
questions.solution:
Option B: Supravalvular aortic stenosis

  • This case scenario best explains the clinical manifestation of Williams Syndrome.
  • ELN, CLIP2, GTF21, and LIMK1 are among the genes that are typically deleted from one chromosome in people with William Syndrome.
  • This hemizygosity for the ELN gene, which codes for the protein elastin, is associated with connective-tissue abnormalities and cardiovascular disease.
  • It appears as a discrete hourglass or diffuse long-segment stenosis known as supra-valvular aortic stenosis.
  • This cardiac lesion is the most common lesion found in Williams Syndrome.
  • This stenosis is manifested as the pansystolic murmur at the level of the arch of the aorta.
  • 65% of children with WS have supra-valvular aortic stenosis.
  • The stenosis in this lesion is Supravalvular, not Subvalvular.

Option A: Flat facies

  • Williams Syndrome presents with Elfin facies that appear as a broad forehead, bitemporal narrowness, medial eyebrow flare, strabismus, and flat nasal bridge.
  • The flat facies is usually associated with down syndrome.

Option C: Hypocalcemia

  • Patients with William's Syndrome generally have high ranges of blood calcium levels.
  • These are usually asymptomatic, and the aetiology is currently unknown.

Option D: Hypotension

  • In patients with William's Syndrome, hypertension usually occurs due to renal artery stenosis, abdominal aortic stenotic abnormalities, or increased arterial stiffness due to defective Elastin.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a burn injury to his hands. He is vitally stable. He does not have any significant medical history. Over a few weeks, the burned skin heals without requiring skin grafting. Which of the following is the most critical factor responsible for rapid healing?
questions.solution:
Option A: Remnant skin appendages

  • The given scenario is a case of secondary intention healing.
  • The Adnexal structures(remnant skin appendages) contain epithelial cells which can proliferate and heal a partial thickness wound by epithelialization.
  • The skin consists of two layers.
    • The epidermis is the most superficial layer of the skin, constantly replaced by the basal layer
    • The dermis is thicker than the epidermis and contains adnexal structures.
  • Healing of a wound can occur in three ways:
    • Primary intention healing: Occurs when there is apposition of the wound edges and minimal surrounding tissue trauma that cause the least inflammation and leaves the best scar.
    • Secondary intention healing: Wounds are left open and allowed to heal by granulation, contraction and epithelialisation.
    • Tertiary intention (also called delayed Primary intention): Wound initially left open and edges later opposed when healing conditions are favourable.

Wound Healing - By Intention

Primary Intention

Clean wound with limited tissue loss Wounds edges easily approximated Classic surgical wound closure Using suture, staples, adhesive tape

Secondary Intention

Large tissue loss / heavy contamination Wound cleaned & left open to granulate Surgeon may pack & place drain Wound care q day promotes granulation

Tertiary Intention

Also called: Delayed primary closure Often used with heavy bacteria counts Wound is cleaned, debrided, left open Typically 4-5 days-then surgical closure

Option B: Underlying connective tissues

  • Underlying connective tissue provides strength to the wound.
  • In primary intention healing, connective tissue deposition is small, while in secondary healing, it is large
  • Moreover, it is not a contributing factor to the complete regeneration ability of the tissue.

Option C: Minimal oedema and erythema

  • Although signs of inflammation if minimum, it would mean that inflammation is not extensive and damage is less.
  • This would allow healing to occur faster.
  • However, complete regeneration depends on preserving the stem cells and not on the presence or absence of signs of inflammation.

Option D: Granulation tissue

  • Granulation tissue helps in the healing of a wound by secondary intention.
  • However, if stem cells are damaged, the wound repair will not be perfect, and granulation tissue will be transformed into a scar.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male from Bihar visited the petrol pump for refilling the petrol in his car. A condom vending machine at a petrol pump in a high prevalence area is an example of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option B: Social marketing

  • A condom vending machine at a petrol pump in a high-prevalence area is an example of Social marketing.

Social marketing:

  • Concept: Seeks to develop and integrate marketing concepts with other approaches to influence behaviors that benefit individuals and communities for the greater social good.
  • Social marketing seeks to influence social behaviors not to benefit the marketer, but to benefit the target audience and the general society.

Option A: Appropriate technology

  • Scientifically sound.
  • Suitable for use in the area.
  • Acceptable to users and recipients.
  • Maintainable with available resources.

Option C: Socialization

  • It refers to the process whereby individuals develop qualities essential for functioning effectively in the society in which they live.

Option D: Community participation

  • There must be a continuing effort to secure meaningful involvement of the community in the planning, implementation and
    maintenance of health services, besides maximum reliance on local resources such as manpower, money, and materials.

questions.text: In a well-educated family, all its family members are working and help each other financially. A family where all of its members are playing a part in its management is known as which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option D: Communal family

  • A communal family is a family where all of its members are playing a defined part in its management.
  • It is a good example of the ‘division of labor’ an important function of the family.

Option A: Problem  family

  • It is a family which lags behind the rest of the community.
  • The underlying factors in most problem families are those of personality, relationships, backwardness, poverty, illness,
  • mental and social instability, character defects, and marital disharmony.
  •  The standards of life are generally far below the accepted minimum.
  •  The parents are unable to meet the physical and emotional needs of their children.
  •  Home life is utterly unsatisfactory.

Option B: New family 

  • Family with marriage duration < 10yrs.

Option C: 3 Generation family

  • Household with members of 3 successive generations.
  • Type of joint family & males are related by blood.

questions.text: The anatomy professor is taking a lecture about the neural pathway of sound. He flashed a question on the board, "Which of the following is not concerned with the auditory pathway"?
questions.solution:
Option C: Genu of the internal capsule

  • This statement is false and hence the correct answer because the genu of the internal capsule is not a part of the auditory pathway.
  • Fibers of cortinuclear tracts form the genu of the internal capsule; its function is to allow communication between the cerebral cortex and brainstem, necessary for physical movements and sensory information perception.

Auditory Pathway

E: Eighth nerve (vestibulocochlear nerve)

C: Cochlear nucleus (Spiral ganglion)

O: Superior Olivary complex (Opposite)

L: Lateral lemniscus (Largest)

I: Inferior colliculus

M: Medial geniculate body

A: Auditory cortex (Brodmann area 41)

E: 8th nerve

Option A: Trapezoid body

  • The trapezoid body (the ventral acoustic stria) is part of the auditory pathway where some of the axons coming from the cochlear nucleus (specifically, the anterior cochlear nucleus) decussate (cross over) to the other side before traveling onto the superior olivary nucleus.

Option B: Medial geniculate body

  • The medial geniculate body (MGB) is a complex of nuclei that receive massive input from the IC and thus serve as major synaptic stations in the pathways for information reaching auditory areas of the cerebral cortex.

Option D: Lateral lemniscus

  • The lateral lemniscus is part of the auditory tract of the brainstem. It starts at the level of the superior olivary complex and terminates at the inferior colliculus.
  • The fibers of the contralateral dorsal cochlear nucleus reach the central nucleus of the inferior colliculus directly via the lateral lemniscus.

questions.text: A patient presents to the office after he and his girlfriend eloped. He was struck with a cricket bat by his girlfriend's relatives near the temporal area. Later, he had some difficulty in hearing. His examination revealed a problem in his middle ear. Normally, the advantage gained by the middle ear transformer mechanism is?
questions.solution:
Option C: 22 times

  • It is a correct statement.
  • Effective vibratory area- 55mm2
  • Footplate area- 3.2mm2
  • Areal ratio: 17:1
  • Lever ratio- 1.3:1
  • Total transformer ratio= Areal ratio X Lever ratio= 17 X 1.3= 22
  • The sound gets amplified by 22 times (Advantage gained)

Total transformer ratio= 22:1

  • The tympanic membrane and the ossicles function to overcome the mismatch of impedances between air and the cochlear fluids, and thus the middle ear serves as a transformer or impedance matching device.

Middle ear transformer mechanism

  1. Catenary lever – ear drum – 2 times gain in sound pressure
  2. Ossicular lever – ossicles – handle of malleus 1.3 times longer than long process of incus – mechanical advantage of 1.3
  3. Hydraulic lever – diff in surface TM (55 sq mm) & stapes (3.2 sq mm) – areal ratio – 14:1

  • The outer ear is air-filled, and the cochlea is filled with liquid, which causes an impedance mismatch. This impedance mismatch would cause much of the sound entering the ear to be reflected, and the auditory system would lose much of its sensitivity.
  • For purposes of simplicity, the conductive mechanism of hearing can be divided into three parts: (1) air medium, (2) impedance matching mechanism, and (3) fluid medium between the listener and the sound source, as representing the first part of the conductive mechanism of hearing.
  • The major function of the middle ear is to match relatively low-impedance airborne sounds to the higher-impedance fluid of the inner ear. The term “impedance” in this context describes a medium's resistance to movement.
  • The area ratio (pressure) transformer is the first and most effective of the three impedance matching mechanisms. It results from the difference in surface area between the tympanic membrane and the membrane covering the oval window.
  • Impedance matching is the force delivered through the mechanical advantages of the lever action of the tympanic ossicles and the areal ratio of the tympanic membrane to the oval window to overcome the acoustic impedance between the ambient air and the fluid in the inner ear.

Option A: 18 times

  • It is a false statement.
  • The transformer ratio according to the areal and lever ratio is 22 times.

Option B: 19 times

  • It is a false statement.
  • The transformer ratio according to the areal and lever ratio is 22 times.

Option D: 24 times

  • It is a false statement.
  • The transformer ratio according to the areal and lever ratio is 22 times.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old male patient diagnosed with Meniere's disease comes to the E.N.T. outpatient department, and a 1st-year E.N.T. resident, on his first week at the hospital, asked a question by a senior doctor. Which of the following clinical features are seen in Meniere's disease?


	Vertigo
	Hearing loss
	Tinnitus
	Diplopia
questions.solution:
Option A: 1, 2, and 3 are correct

  • Meniere's disease, also called endolymphatic hydrops, is a disorder of the inner ear where the endolymphatic system is distended with endolymph.

Clinical symptoms of Meniere's disease

  • Episodic vertigo.
  • Fluctuating hearing loss.
  • Tinnitus.
  • Sense of fullness or pressure in the involved ear.
  • Vertigo attacks are usually preceded by an aura consisting of fullness in the ear, increasing tinnitus, and a decrease in hearing.
  • It is a distension of the endolymphatic system, mainly affecting the cochlear duct (scala media), the saccule, and, to a lesser extent, the utricle and semicircular canals. The dilatation of the cochlear duct is such that it may completely fill the scala vestibuli; there is marked bulging of Reissner's membrane, which may even herniate through the helicotrema into the apical part of scala tympani. The distended saccule may come to lie against the stapes footplate. The utricle and saccule may show outpouchings into the semicircular canals.

Option B: Only 1 and 2 are correct

  • This option is incorrect because not only statements 1 and 2 are correct but also statement 3 is correct.
  • According to statement 1, vertigo is the clinical feature of Meniere's disease.
  • According to statement 2, hearing loss is the clinical feature of Meniere's disease.
  • According to statement 3, tinnitus is the clinical feature of Meniere's disease.

Option C: Only 1, 2, and 4 are correct

  • This option is also incorrect because statements 1 and 2 are correct, but statement 4 is incorrect because, according to statement 4, diplopia is the clinical feature of Meniere's disease, which is a wrong statement.
  • Diplopia is the clinical feature of an autoimmune disease, myasthenia gravis.

Option D: All are correct

  • This option is also incorrect because statements 1, 2, and 3 are correct, but statement 4 is incorrect because, according to statement 4, diplopia is the clinical feature of Meniere's disease, which is a wrong statement.
  • Diplopia is the clinical feature of an autoimmune disease, myasthenia gravis.

Clinical symptoms of Meniere's disease:

  • Episodic vertigo.
  • Fluctuating hearing loss.
  • Tinnitus.
  • Sense of fullness or pressure in the involved ear.
  • Vertigo attacks are usually preceded by an aura consisting of fullness in the ear, increasing tinnitus, and a decrease in hearing.

questions.text: While a group of children was rehearsing for a play at an annual function, they were asked to stand in two rows, boys and girls, respectively, and tell their names. These children could do so, but they could not count the 10 coins given to them and could not reliably catch a ball. What could be the age of these children?
questions.solution:
Option B: 3 years

  • As the scenario explains that the children were able to tell their names but were not able to count coins that were given to them. The children who reach 3 years of age can easily tell their names and their parents' names, too; they also know their gender.
  • A child knows her full name and gender by the age of 3 years.

Important social milestones:

  • 3 months

Recognizes mother
  • 6 months

Smiles at a mirror image ('Mirror play')
  • 7 months

Stranger anxiety
  • 8 months

Object permanence
  • 9 months

Waves bye-bye
  • 10 months

Plays peek-a-boo

Kisses on request
  • 12 months

He plays a simple ball game

Points to objects
  • 15 months

Indicates wet pants

Domestic mimicry
  • 18 months

Dry during the daytime (bladder control during the day)
  • 2 years
  • Parallel play
  • Joins in play
  • 3 years
  • Knows name, age & gender
  • Dry during the night

 

Option A: 1 year

  • At the first year of age, the baby is developing many skills, i.e. cruising, crawling, and pointing towards objects.
  • Babies at the age of 1 year sleep for about 14 hours in the daytime and 11 hours at night on average.

Option C: 5 years

  • A five-year-old child is a grown-up child.
  • They can speak very clearly.
  • I like to sing and dance.
  • Can stand on the foot for 10 seconds or more.

Option D: 7 years

  • A seven-year-old child strictly adheres to the rules.
  • Can run up and down stairs
  • Able to brush and comb hair.

questions.text: A 3-year-old male child is brought to the OPD by his parents due to concerns of delayed speech, constipation, and difficulty concentrating for one month. The child has normal developmental milestones. His mother also complains that he does not play with other kids. Upon examination, he had trouble communicating and was very anxious. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in the child?
questions.solution:
Option A: Autism spectrum disorder

  • A male child presents to the doctor with delayed speech, constipation, and difficulty concentrating for 1 month. The child has normal developmental milestones. His mother also complains that he does not play with other kids. On examination, he has trouble communicating and is very anxious. This scenario suggests that the child has autism spectrum disorder.
  • Autistic disorder
    • Qualitative impairment of social behaviour.
    • Impairment of communication skills.
    • Stereotypic & restricted behaviour
    • Onset before 3 years.
    • More common in boys.
  • Most common presentations include lack of eye contact, trouble communicating, delayed speech, delayed learning skills, and seizures in some cases.
  • Since there is no cure for autism spectrum disorder, diagnosing early for better treatment is crucial.

Option B: ADHD

  • Attention, deficit hyperactivity disorder, is one of the most common neurodevelopmental disorders of childhood, and its onset is before the age of 12.
  • In this disorder, a child might have trouble focusing on something or excess movements that are not fitting to the setting. Common features include lack of concentration, impulsivity and hyperactivity.

Option C: Mental retardation

  • Mental retardation, now known as an intellectual disability, refers to sub-normal IQ.
  • It is a cognitive disorder that is present in 2% to 3% of the population.

Option D: Specific learning disability

  • It is a condition with persistent impairment in reading (dyslexia), writing (dysgraphia) and arithmetic (dyscalculia) skills in an individual with preserved cognition, vision, hearing and adequate opportunities.
  • It is typically diagnosed in early school-aged children. In some cases, it is not recognisable until adulthood.

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant woman presents at the 20th week with polyhydramnios and incomplete brain development. When do the anterior and posterior neuropores close during embryonic development, considering the potential prevention of neural tube defects with early folic acid supplementation?
questions.solution:
Option C: Week 4

  • Anterior & posterior neuropores close during week 4 of development—the anterior neuropore by day 25, the posterior neuropore by day 28.
  • Failure of the Fusion of anterior neuropore results in anencephaly.
  • Failure of the fusion of posterior neuropore results in Rachischisis.
  • Failure of fusion of both anterior and posterior neuropore results in Craniorachischisis.

  • The floor of the amniotic cavity will have all 3 germ layers. Ectoderm and endoderm fuse towards the cephalic end and form the buccopharyngeal membrane, and the caudal end forms the cloacal membrane. Both membranes don't have mesoderm because of the fusion of the dorsal ectoderm with ventral endoderm.
  • Some of the epiblast cells migrate towards the pit and go towards the buccopharyngeal membrane, and they are going to form a notochord. So, the notochord is formed by the epiblast lying between the primitive pit and the buccopharyngeal membrane. This notochord is also known as Axial mesoderm. Axial mesoderm stimulates dorsal epiblast or dorsal ectoderm to form the nervous system there.

Option A: Week 2

  • 2nd week is a bilaminar stage. On day 20, fusion at the cervical occipital region occurs, forming the first pair of somites [Neural tube formation begins].

Option B: Week 3

  • Neural Tube is formed in the 3rd week from the neural groove. It then elongates to form primary and secondary brain vesicles, while the posterior part forms the spinal cord.

Option D: Week 5

  • By the 5th week, the neural tube closes, and further development starts to form the proper nervous system.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female librarian is in the emergency department with difficulty swallowing for the last two hours. She has high blood pressure, weakness on the right side of her lower face, and her tongue deviates towards the right side upon protrusion. However, no weakness was observed in her upper or lower limbs. The lesion responsible for these symptoms is located in which of the following areas?

choices.text: Anterior limb of the internal capsule
Genu of the internal capsule, left side

questions.solution:
Option C: Genu of the internal capsule, left side

  • A lesion involving the genu of the internal capsule damages the corticobulbar fibers.
  • The facial nerve nucleus receives bilateral corticobulbar input, the upper face division receives input from both cerebral hemispheres, and the lower face division receives only contralateral input. (So, lesion of left genu will present as right-sided lower face weakness).

  • The nucleus of the hypoglossal nerve receives only contralateral corticobulbar input. So, a lesion of the left genu will present as right-side hypoglossal paralysis. Hence, when the tongue is protruded, it deviates to the right (side of LMN lesion) owing to the unopposed activity of the intact genioglossus.
  • Lesion of the Left genu will cause paralysis of the opposite (right) ago-accessory complex. So, the uvula deviates to the left (entire side / opposite site of LMN lesion) when the patient says "ah."
  • The internal capsule is a V-shaped structure that has 3 parts
    • Anterior limb
    • Posterior limb
    • Genu
  • The body is represented so that sensory-motor fibers of the head region are present at the genu.
  • The internal capsule mainly consists of myelinated nerve fibers of ascending and descending CNS tracts.

Option A: Anterior limb of the internal capsule

  • Anterior limb sandwiched between lentiform (lateral) & caudate (medial) functions for emotions, cognition, and decision-making. A lesion in this area will result in psychiatric illness.

Option B: Claustrum

  • The claustrum is present between the insular cortex and the putamen and supplied by the middle cerebral artery. Any lesion in the claustrum will manifest as loss of consciousness.

Option D: Paracentral lobule, right side

  • Anterior cerebral artery (major artery on medial cerebrum especially supplying paracentral lobule); controlling lower limb and part of pelvis and perineum. Any block in the anterior cerebral artery causes urinary incontinence, lower limb paralysis, and sensory problems. The manifestation will be on the contralateral side of the lesion.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman who is a known case of Hashimoto's thyroiditis presented with dyspepsia and symptoms of malabsorption. Physical examination is unremarkable except for mild paleness in the conjunctive. After an endoscopy and biopsy, she was diagnosed to have atrophic gastritis. Which of the following is a feature of this patient's underlying condition?

choices.text: Excessive acid production in the stomach

questions.solution:
Option D: Vitamin B12 deficiency

  • The patient described in the clinical vignette has atrophic gastritis secondary to anti-parietal cell antibodies- an auto-immune phenomenon.

  • Auto-immune atrophic gastritis is characterized by the following:

    • Antibodies to parietal cells and intrinsic factors that can be detected in serum and gastric secretions
    • Reduced serum pepsinogen I concentration
    • Endocrine cell hyperplasia
    • Vitamin B12 deficiency
    • Defective gastric acid secretion (achlorhydria)
    • Pernicious anaemia and Autoimmune Atrophic Gastritis are often associated with other auto-immune diseases, including Hashimoto's thyroiditis, Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus, and Addison's disease.
  • Clinical features are mainly related to vitamin B12 deficiency, including megaloblastic anaemia, atrophic glossitis, epithelial megaloblastic, and malabsorptive diarrhoea.

Option A: Anti-endocrine cell antibodies

  • Antibodies are produced against parietal cells, not the endocrine cells

Option B: Excessive acid production in the stomach

  • Atrophic gastritis causes low production of acid

Option C: Parietal cell hyperplasia

  • Atrophic gastritis destroys parietal cells, not hyperplasia.

questions.text: A 57-year-old female presented to the outpatient clinic complaining of pain and redness in her left breast. She had never needed to see a doctor in the past ten years. A physical examination revealed an erythematous and swollen breast. On palpation, the breast is warm to the touch and tender. The breast has significant dimpling (peau d'orange), and the left nipple is completely retracted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Inflammatory carcinoma 

  • Inflammatory carcinoma is caused by carcinoma plugging lymphovascular spaces, resulting in swelling and nipple retraction. 
  • Although it is called inflammatory carcinoma, there is no inflammation present. 
  • This is usually of high grade and has distant metastasis. 
  • It has a very poor prognosis. 
  • Common symptoms are 
    • Pain 
    • Erythema 
    • Dimpling of skin (peau d'orange)
    • Skin thickening 
    • Usually, no palpable mass is present
  • Skin dimpling is caused by the involvement of the cooper ligament, which connects the skin to the breast. This gives the breast the appearance of an orange peel (peau d'orange).
  • The presentation is similar to breast infections, resulting in delayed diagnosis. 

Option A: Granulomatous mastitis

  • It is a rare breast disease that can manifest systemic granulomatous disease (Sarcoidosis, Tuberculosis, and so on).
  • The presence of granulomas adjacent to lobules is the histologic pattern, which may contain lipids. 
  • Histologically, the pattern resembles cystic neutrophilic granulomatous mastitis. 
  • It should be treated with antibiotics and, in some cases, steroids. 

Option B: Micropapillary carcinoma

  • Micropapillary carcinoma forms a cell ball that floats in intercellular fluid. 
  • It forms a structure similar to true papillae. 

Option C: Fibrocystic disease of the breast

  • Fibrocystic disease is characterised by the formation of cysts and stromal fibrosis. 
  • Smaller cysts then combine to form larger cysts. 
  • It is a benign breast condition.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the emergency department with swelling in her lower extremities. On examination, pitting edema is noted, and laboratory studies reveal hypoalbuminemia. The physician suspects an imbalance in interstitial fluid volume.Which of the following substances is best suited for estimating changes in interstitial fluid volume?
questions.solution:
Option D: Inulin and 125I-albumin

  • Inulin is the best indicator of ECF (extracellular fluid) volume, and 125I-albumin is most commonly used for plasma volume estimation.
  • Interstitial fluid volume= ECF volume – Plasma volume.

Option A: Inulin and heavy water

  • Heavy water is not used to estimate interstitial fluid volume.
  • Heavy water is used to measure total body water.
  • Inulin is the best indicator of ECF volume, and 125I-albumin is most commonly used for plasma volume estimation.
  • Interstitial fluid volume= ECF volume – Plasma volume.

Option B: Inulin and 22Na

  • 22Na is not used to estimate interstitial fluid volume.
  • Inulin is the best indicator of ECF volume, and 125I-albumin is most commonly used for plasma volume estimation.
  • Interstitial fluid volume= ECF volume – Plasma volume.

Option C: Heavy water and 1251-albumin

  • Heavy water is not used to measure interstitial fluid volume. However, 1251-albumin is most commonly used for plasma volume estimation.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man was brought to the physician's office with complaints of impulsivity, irritability, anger outbursts and aggression for the past few months. He recently started to experience involuntary movements of the distal extremities, weight loss and sleep disturbance. Based on the image below, where the patient is marked with a red star, which of the following diseases is shown in the pedigree analysis below?
questions.solution:
Option C: Huntington's disease

Huntington's disease (HD)

  • It is an autosomal dominant movement disorder that is associated with degeneration of the striatum (caudate and putamen).
  • The disease caused by CAG trinucleotide repeat expansions in the gene located on chromosome 4p16.3 encodes a 348 kD protein known as huntingtin. The disease occurs when the number of repeats of the gene is increased.
  • It is a prototype of the polyglutamine trinucleotide repeat expansion diseases.
  • It is characterized by involuntary jerky movements of all body parts, including the extremities' writhing movements. Early cognitive symptoms include forgetfulness and progress to severe dementia.
  • Autosomal dominant inheritance is manifested in the heterozygous state, so at least one parent in a case is usually affected, and both sexes can transmit the disease. Therefore, if one parent is affected and the other is unaffected, each child has one chance in two (i.e. 50%) of having the disease.

 

Option A: Xeroderma Pigmentosum

 

  • It is an autosomal recessive inherited disorder of DNA repair (nucleotide excision repair defect) with a diverse range of genes involved in the inheritance. Autosomal recessive disorders occur in a pattern of inheritance where both parents carry the defective allele, but none of them has the disease. As a result, in the case of both carrier parents, each child has one chance in four (i.e. 25%) of having the disease.

Option B: Fanconi anemia

  • It is an autosomal recessive inherited disorder of DNA repair (DNA cross-link repair defect) with a diverse range of genes involved. Therefore, the child of carrier parents has a chance of 25% of having the disease.

Option D: Ataxia-telangiectasia

  • It is an autosomal recessive inherited disorder of DNA repair due to a mutation in the ATM gene. The chance of inheritance from carrier parents is 25%.

questions.text: A rural PHC has organized every Saturday of the week as the vaccination day for the children of the village. Which of the following is the correct storage of Vitamin A vaccine?
questions.solution:
Option C: Outside cold chain

  • Vitamin A does not require any cold chain for its storage. It is kept at room temperature.
  • Vit A should be started at 9 months of age (1 lac IU) & given every 6 months (2 lac IU) till the child reaches 5 years of age.
  • Administration- Oral route.

Other options are incorrect regarding vitamin A storage

questions.text: In which of the followingphase of spermatogenesis does reduction in the chromosomal number to half the original number occur?
questions.solution:
Option B: Meiosis - I

  • Meiosis is a process where a single cell divides twice to produce four cells containing half the original amount of genetic information.
  • The first meiotic division is the reduction division, and each primary spermatocyte yields two secondary spermatocytes.
  • Spermatocytes.
  • Each contains 23 (Haploid) chromosomes consisting of two varieties, 22+X and 22+Y. Here 22 are autosomes, and X & Y are sex chromosomes.

Option A: During mitosis

  • Mitosis is a process in which the cell undergoes division to produce offspring. In mitosis, Daughter cells have the same Chromosomes as the parent (diploid).
