  • During the initial phase of spermatogenesis, the oocyte undergoes continuous mitosis division until the formation of the primary spermatocyte.

Option C: Meiosis - II

  • During spermatogenesis, the PGCs undergo several mitotic divisions to form primary spermatocytes. The primary spermatocyte undergoes the first meiotic division to form a secondary spermatocyte, resulting in four equal haploid cells.
  • Meiosis II divides each haploid meiotic cell (primary spermatocyte) into two different daughter cells.

Option D: None of the above

  • The reduction of chromosomes occurs in meiosis I, which is a reduction division.

questions.text: An epidemic is the rapid spread of disease to a large number of people in a given population within a short period of time. Given figure shows which type of epidemic?
questions.solution:
Option D: Single exposure point source epidemic

  • The given figure suggests a Single exposure point source epidemic.
  • A sharp rise and sharp fall in the number of cases are seen.
  • Clustering of cases in a narrow interval of time.
  • All cases develop within one incubation period of the disease.
  • Examples: Food poisoning, Bhopal gas Tragedy.

Other options

Option A: Pandemic

  • A pandemic is an epidemic that spread to more than one country.
  • It includes Covid 19, HIV, Ebola, etc.

Option B: Multiple exposure point source epidemic

  • Exposure is occurring multiple times.
  • There are multiple incubation periods.
  • Multiple exposures is occurring only from a single point source.
  • Sudden rise but fall is interrupted by multiple peaks known as secondary waves.

Option C: Propagated epidemic

  • When an epidemic spreads from one person to another, it is said to have propagated. As with syphilis, transmission typically occurs through direct person-to-person contact.

  • Most of the population gets immunity by repeated exposure and infection.

  • This type of immunity is known as subclinical immunity.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presented to the OPD with excessive thirst, an increase in the frequency of urination, and blurry vision. The physician is screening him for Diabetes mellitus. Which of the following is the Positive Screening test for Diabetes Mellitus?
questions.solution:
Option A: RBS > 200 mg/dl

  • A screening test is a search for an unrecognized disease/defect in apparently healthy individuals by means of RAPIDLY APPLIED TESTS.
  • Random blood sugar (RBS) is used for the screening of diabetes mellitus.
  • Rest all tests are diagnostic tests.

other options

Option B: GTT > 200mg/dl

  • GTT >200 mg/dl is one of the diagnostic tests for diabetes.

Option C: HbA1C > 6.5 %

  • HbA1C > 6.5% is one of the diagnostic tests for diabetes.

Option D: FBS > 126 mg/dl

  • FBS >126 mg/dl is a diagnostic test for diabetes.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presented to the OPD with a persistent cough for 3 weeks, fever, night sweats, and weight loss. The physician is screening him for tuberculosis. A screening test must satisfy all of the following given criteria, except?
questions.solution:
Option D: Accountability

  • Accountability is not needed to be satisfied by a screening test.
  • Screening test must satisfy the following criteria:
    • Acceptability
    • Repeatability
    • Validity

Option A: Acceptability

  • Screening Test should be acceptable to the people at whom it is aimed.
  • In general, tests that are Painful, discomforting or Embarrassing like Rectal and vaginal examination are not likely acceptable in mass campaigns.

Option B: Repeatability

  • An Ideal screening test should have the Property of Repeatability.
  • The test must give consistent results when repeated more than once on the same Individual under the same conditions.

Option C: Validity

  • Validity is also known as Accuracy.
  • Refers to what extent the test accurately measures what it suppose to measure.

questions.text: A primigravida presents at 36 weeks for routine evaluation. She has no complaints. Examination shows a fundal height corresponding to 34 weeks, with an empty pelvic grip, and a ballotable hard part felt in the right side of abdomen. Which of the following is a common association with such presentation?
questions.solution:
Option D : A fundal height less than dates, empty pelvic grip and hard ballotable part (head) on one side of the abdomen is all suggestive of a fetus in a transverse lie.

Some of the more common causes of transverse lie include:

  • Abdominal wall relaxation from high parity,
  • Preterm fetus,
  • Placenta previa,
  • Abnormal uterine anatomy,
  • Hydramnios,
  • Contracted pelvis.

Option A : Face to pubis delivery is seen in direct occiptio-posterior position

Option B : Transverse lie is not associated with abruption.

Option C : Transverse lie is associated with polyhydramnios and not oligohydramnios.

questions.text: With respect to Facility Based Newborn Care (FBNC), which of the following facility exists at MCH Level I (Sub Center & PHC) for care of newborn at birth:
questions.solution:
Option A: Newborn Care Corner (NBCC)

Newborn Care Corner (NBCC):

  • Newborn care corner available at all delivery points
  • It is present within the labour room.
  • Basic resuscitation kits will be there.

Facility Based Newborn Care (FBNC):

  • There are three level of Facility Based Newborn Care
    1. Newborn care corner
    2. Newborn stabilization unit
    3. Special newborn care unit
Newborn Care Facility MCH Level Health Facility
Newborn Care Corner (NBCC) I SC, PHC
Newborn Stabilization Unit (NBSU) II CHC, FRU
Special Newborn Care Unit (SNCU) III District Hospital

Option B: Newborn Stabilization Unit (NBSU)

  • Available at CHC and First referral units.
  • Advance resuscitation kits are available here.

Option C: Special Newborn Care Unit (SNCU)

  • Available at District hospital.
  • They are away from the labour room.

Option D: Nutritional Rehabilitation Centre (NRC)

  • It is for severe acute malnutrition patients.

Learning Objective

Newborn Care Corner (NBCC):

  • Newborn care corner available at all delivery points.
  • It is present within the labour room.
  • Basic resuscitation kits will be there.
  • It is available at Sub center and PHC.

questions.text: A newborn boy is brought by his father to the neonatology department as he notices abnormalities in his facial features. The boy has features of a drooping eyelid, and his mouth has a deep  groove between the nose and the mouth, along with a depressed nose tip. Based on the features as given in the image, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Noonan syndrome

  • Based on abnormalities in his facial features, such as a drooping eyelid, his mouth has a deep groove between the nose and the mouth, along with a depressed nose tip; the neonate is suffering from Noonan syndrome.
  • Noonan syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition associated with a normal karyotype.
  • It is thought to be caused by a defect in a gene on chromosome 12.
  • Features similar to Turner's syndrome (webbed neck, widely-spaced nipples, short stature, pectus carinatum and excavatum), several characteristic clinical signs may also be seen:
    • Unusual facies (i.e., hypertelorism, down slanting eyes, webbed neck)
    • Cardiac: pulmonary valve stenosis
    • Ptosis
    • Triangular-shaped face
    • Low-set ears
    • Coagulation problems: factor XI deficiency
  • Bleeding diathesis in 50% skeletal, genitourinary, neurologic, lymphatic, skin and eye.
  • Findings may be present in varying degrees.

Option B: Downs syndrome

  • Down syndrome is the most common inheritable cause of mental retardation.
  • Symptoms of down’s syndrome (Trisomy 21):
    • Mental retardation
    • Epicanthic folds and
    • flat facial profile
    • Umbilical hernia
    • Simian'screase
    • The gap between the first and second toe
    • Hypotonia
    • Congenital heart defects

Option C: Edwards’s syndrome

  • Trisomy 18 is Edwards’s syndrome.
  • Its symptoms include:
    • Prominent occiput
    • Low-set ears
    • Mental retardation
    • Congenital heart defects
    • Rocker-bottom feet

Option D: Patau syndrome

  • Trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome) symptoms:
    • Microphthalmia
    • Microcephaly and mental retardation
    • Polydactyly
    • Cleft lip and palate
    • Renal defects​​​​​​​

questions.text: What is the total number of ligamentum denticulata found in adults?
questions.solution:
Option D: 40-42

  • This is a case of a spinal cord lesion.
  • Ligamentum denticulatum, also known as the denticulate ligament, is present on each side of the spinal cord.
  • This is usually 20 to 21 ligaments on each side, hence 40 to 42.
  • It is a longitudinally oriented sheet of pia mater that extends laterally from the cord toward the arachnoid and dura mater.
  • Each denticulate ligament, medially, is attached to the spinal cord in a plane between the origins of the posterior and anterior rootlets.
  • Each denticulate ligament, laterally, forms a series of triangular extensions along its free border, with the apex of extension, is anchored through the arachnoid mater to the dura mater.
  • Denticulate ligaments laterally attach between the exit points of adjacent posterior and anterior rootlets. The function of the ligament is to position the spinal cord in the center of the subarachnoid space.

Option A: 10-12

  • The total number of ligamentum denticulatum attached to the spinal cord is 40 to 42.

Option B: 20-22

  • The total number of ligamentum denticulatum attached to the spinal cord is 40 to 42.

Option C: 30-32

  • The total number of ligamentum denticulatum attached to the spinal cord is 40 to 42.

questions.text: Which of the following primary tumors cause metastases to the spleen?
questions.solution:
ANSWER

Option B: Carcinoma lung

  • The patient presented with nephrolithiasis, but on the investigation, he was found to have a metastatic lesion in the spleen.
  • Secondary or metastatic tumours in the spleen are most commonly from melanoma, lung cancer, and breast cancer. 
  • Isolated splenic metastases are extremely unusual, but these may occur in the setting of a concomitant carcinoma.
  • Lung cancer is the tumour that most commonly spreads to the spleen, although colorectal, ovarian, and melanoma may also metastasize.
  • The reported incidence of splenic metastasis from primary lung cancer is 1.2–5.6%

Other

Option A: Carcinoma prostate

  • Prostatic carcinoma metastasizes to lymph nodes, mostly obturator, and internal iliac lymph nodes.
  • It also spreads to the vertebrae and bones.

Option C: Carcinoma liver

  • Hepatocellular carcinoma metastasizes to the lungs, lymph nodes, adrenal gland, and bones, including the skull.

Option D: Carcinoma pancreas

  • Pancreatic cancer most commonly spreads to the liver, peritoneum, and lungs.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented in the ER with a complaint of fresh blood coming from both vomit and stools; during history taking, the patient told the doctor that he had an "Aortic valve replacement" surgery 1 month back and he was taking an anticoagulant drug. The anticoagulant drug is a vitamin K epoxide reductase inhibitor. What immediate treatment will stop the bleeding associated with this drug overdose?
questions.solution:
Option A: Fresh frozen plasma (FFP)

  • Fresh blood coming from vomit and stools is hematemesis and melena. Patients who have undergone procedures involving the replacement of heart valves are usually kept on anticoagulation therapy with drugs like warfarin, a vitamin k epoxide reductase inhibitor, to prevent embolic stroke attacks. This anticoagulation has a severe risk of bleeding, which is treated with fresh frozen plasma because it contains readymade vitamin K-dependent clotting factors.
  • FFP is the liquid portion of whole blood and contains all clotting factors, fibrinogen, plasma proteins (particularly albumin), electrolytes and physiological anticoagulants.
  • It is used to replace multiple anticoagulants at once in patients with deficiencies due to liver disease, iatrogenic factors (warfarin overdose) and patients undergoing surgeries like orthopaedic and gynaecological surgeries.

Option B: Vitamin K injection

  • Vitamin K is usually used to prevent haemorrhagic complications due to warfarin therapy.
  • The onset time is slow, which is why it is not used in the acute treatment of haemorrhage.

Option C: Cryoprecipitate

  • Cryoprecipitate is a concentrate of high molecular weight plasma proteins that precipitate in the cold.
  • The concentrate contains factor VIII, con Willebrand factor, factor XIII and a few other proteins like fibronectin. But it is not used in treating haemorrhage due to warfarin overdose because it doesn't contain vitamin K-dependent clotting factors.

Option D: Whole blood

  • Whole blood contains all the plasma proteins, RBCs, WBCs and platelets.
  • It is not used in warfarin overdose because of its propensity to cause antigenic side effects due to the presence of RBCs.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the medical outpatient department with headache, lethargy, and exertional dyspnea for the past 20 days. He underwent a renal transplant 20 years ago for end-stage renal disease. He had been on long-term immunosuppressants since then. A peripheral blood film reveals a leukoerythroblastic picture with abnormal mononuclear cells. A bone marrow smear showed a markedly hypercellular marrow with diffuse infiltrates of abnormal lymphoid cells. The patient is diagnosed with post-transplant lymphoma, which occurs due to the proliferation of which of the following cells?
questions.solution:
Option B: B cell

  • Clinical signs: Headache, lethargy, and exertional dyspnea history of the renal transplant after the patient is on immunosuppressants therapy and peripheral blood film reveals a leukoerythroblastic picture while bone marrow biopsy shows hypercellular marrow with diffused infiltrates; it all indicates towards the Post-transplant lymphoma.
  • The post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder is a serious disorder that occurs after post-hematopoietic stem cell transplant or solid organ transplantation.
  • Post-transplant lymphoma (Post-transplant Lymphoproliferative disorder or PTLD) occurs due to the proliferation of B cells.
  • A well-known side effect of both solid organ transplantation (SOT) and allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD) (HSCT). One of the most prevalent post-transplant cancers is it.
  • Most of the time, PTLD has been linked to Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection of B-cells, either as a result of posttransplant EBV reactivation or from initial EBV infection.
  • EBV may be acquired from the donor graft in situations of primary infection or, less frequently, by exposure to the environment.

Option A: T cell

  • Following are the examples:
    • T-lymphoblastic lymphoma/leukaemia
    • Peripheral T-cell lymphomas which is one of the following:
    • Cutaneous T-cell lymphomas
    • Angioimmunoblastic T-cell lymphoma
    • Adult T-cell leukaemia/lymphoma
    • Extranodal natural killer/T-cell lymphoma, nasal type

Option C: NK cell

  • Following are the examples:
    • Precursor T-lymphoblastic leukaemia/lymphoma
    • Sézary syndrome
    • Blastic NK-cell lymphoma
    • Mycosis fungoides
    • Adult T-cell leukaemia/lymphoma
    • Extranodal NKTCL, nasal type
    • Primary cutaneous anaplastic large cell lymphoma
    • Subcutaneous panniculitis-like T-cell lymphoma

Option D: Monocyte

  • Innate immune cells of the mononuclear phagocyte system, known as monocytes, have become significant regulators of the initiation and progression of cancer.
  • It does not have any role in Post-transplant Lymphoproliferative disorder.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male, exhibiting sudden onset of shortness of breath, cough, and hemoptysis, is found to have a swollen and tender right calf upon examination. CT angiography confirms the presence of an embolus causing complete obstruction of blood flow to the left lung. In this clinical scenario, which of the following manifestations is most likely associated with the patient's condition?

choices.text: Ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) ratio in the left lung will be zero
Systemic arterial PO2 will be elevated
V/Q ratio in the left lung will be lower than in the right lung
Alveolar PO2 in the left lung will be approximately equal to the PO2 in inspired air

questions.solution:
Option D: Alveolar PO2 in the left lung will be approximately equal to the PO2 in inspired air

  • The alveolar PO2 in the left lung is the same as the PO2 in the inhaled air → There is no blood flow to the left lung → There is no gas exchange between the alveolar air and the pulmonary capillary blood → Consequently, no O2 is added to the capillary blood.
  • The ventilation/perfusion (V / Q) ratio in the left lung is infinite (neither zero nor less than that of the normal right lung) because Q (the denominator) is zero.
  • The systemic arterial PO2 will naturally decrease since the left lung has no gas exchange. The alveolar PO2 in the right lung is not affected.

Option A: Ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) ratio in the left lung will be zero

  • The ventilation/perfusion (V / Q) ratio in the left lung is infinite (neither zero nor less than that of the normal right lung) because Q (the denominator) is zero.

Option B: Systemic arterial PO2 will be elevated

  • The systemic arterial PO2 will naturally decrease since the left lung has no gas exchange. The alveolar PO2 in the right lung is not affected.

Option C: The V/Q ratio in the left lung will be lower than in the right lung

  • The ventilation/perfusion (V / Q) ratio in the left lung is infinite compared to the right lung.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old female presented with diarrhea for the last 3 days while on vacation. On examination, she looked dehydrated, and her capillary fill was 3 seconds. Her vital signs are normal. On the chest, auscultations are S1 and S2 heart sounds and normal respiratory sounds. The following findings are given:

                                       


	
		
			
			Hemoglobin
			
			
			14
			
		
		
			
			WBCs           
			
			
			12,000/mm3
			
		
		
			
			ALT               
			
			
			52 U/L
			
		
		
			
			AST         
			
			
			39 U/L
			
		
		
			
			PH                 
			
			
			7.28
			
		
		
			
			Pco2             
			
			
			23 mm hg
			
		
		
			
			Bicarbonate   
			
			
			11 mEq/L
			
		
		
			
			Serum electrolytes
			
		
		
			
			Potassium =
			
			
			3.1 mEq/L
			
		
		
			
			Sodium =
			
			
			132 mEq/L
			
		
		
			
			Chloride=
			
			
			110 mEq/L
			
		
	


Which of the following is the correct diagnosis for this patient??
questions.solution:
Option A: Metabolic acidosis

  • This female presented with diarrhea for the last 3 days with low PH, low potassium, low sodium, and low bicarbonate and normal anion gap (anion gap= Na - ( K + Hco3), and has a most likely diagnosis of metabolic acidosis.
  • An acidic PH, along with decreased bicarbonate and decreased Pco2, is consistent with metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation, e.g., hyperventilation.
  • The main causes of metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap are: Remember that
    • H for hyperchloremia
    • A for alimentation
    • A for Addison disease
    • R for renal tubular acidosis
    • D for diarrhea
    • A for acetazolamide
    • S for spironolactone
    • S for saline infusion
  • Diarrhea causes loss of bicarbonate, so that's why it causes metabolic acidosis.
  • The easiest way to find the cause of acidosis is first to check the pco2 and bicarbonates. If pco2 is more than 44 mmHg, it would be respiratory acidosis, or if bicarbonate is less than 20 mEq/L, it would be metabolic acidosis. If it is metabolic acidosis, then check the anion gap. If the gap is more than 12 mEq/L, it would be high anion gap metabolic acidosis, or if it is less than 12 mEq /L, it would be non-anion gap metabolic acidosis

Option B: Metabolic alkalosis

  • In metabolic acidosis, pH would be increased, and bicarbonate would also be increased, but in this patient, PH and bicarbonate are low.

Option C: Respiratory acidosis

  • In respiratory acidosis, the pH would be low, and pco2 would be greater than 44 mmHg, but in the patient, pco2 is very low, and pH is also low, so that's why this is not respiratory acidosis.

Option D: Respiratory alkalosis

  • In respiratory alkalosis, PCO2 should be less than 36 mmHg and pH greater than 7.45.

questions.text: Many viruses are linked to oncogenesis, causing human cancers. The Human T-cell leukaemia virus is an RNA oncogenic virus responsible for human oncogenesis. It is a virus with several traits. Which of the following is not a correct statement regarding human T-cell leukaemia virus-1?

choices.text: Leukemia develops in only 3 to 5% of infected individuals
It has a tropism for CD8+ T cell
It has a long latent period of about 40 to 60 years

questions.solution:
Option B: It has a tropism for CD8+ T-cells

Human T-cell leukaemia virus (HTLV-1)

  • Worldwide it infects 15 to 20 million people.
  • Similar to the human immunodeficiency virus, which causes AIDS, HTLV-1 has a tropism for CD4+ T cells; hence, this subset of T cells is the major target for neoplastic transformation. CD8+ T-cells are cytotoxic killer cells, and HTLV-1 has more tropism for CD4+ T-cells.

Option A: Leukemia develops in only 3 to 5% of infected individuals

HTLV­1 causes adult T-cell leukaemia/lymphoma (ATLL), which is endemic in parts of Japan, the Caribbean, South America, and Africa.

  • Leukaemia develops in only 3 to 5 % of the infected individuals, typically after a long latent period of 40 to 60 years.
  • The virus is transmitted by transferring infected T-cells via sexual intercourse, blood products, or breastfeeding.
  • The mechanism of infection is by the Tax gene, which causes viral replication by stimulating the transcription of viral RNA from the 5' long terminal repeat.
  • A high fraction of the leukaemias expresses the transcription factor Fox P3, a marker of regulatory T cells (Tregs) that act to suppress immune responses.

Option C: It has a long latent period of about 40 to 60 years

HTLV­1 causes adult T-cell leukaemia/lymphoma (ATLL), which is endemic in parts of Japan, the Caribbean, South America, and Africa.

  • Leukaemia develops in only 3 to 5 % of the infected individuals, typically after a long latent period of 40 to 60 years.
  • The virus is transmitted by transferring infected T-cells via sexual intercourse, blood products, or breastfeeding.
  • The mechanism of infection is by the Tax gene, which causes viral replication by stimulating the transcription of viral RNA from the 5' long terminal repeat.
  • A high fraction of the leukaemias expresses the transcription factor Fox P3, a marker of regulatory T cells (Tregs) that act to suppress immune responses.

 

Option D: It causes adult T-cell lymphoma/leukaemia:

HTLV­1 causes adult T-cell leukaemia/lymphoma (ATLL), which is endemic in parts of Japan, the Caribbean, South America, and Africa.

  • Leukaemia develops in only 3 to 5 % of the infected individuals, typically after a long latent period of 40 to 60 years.
  • The virus is transmitted by transferring infected T-cells via sexual intercourse, blood products, or breastfeeding.
  • The mechanism of infection is by the Tax gene, which causes viral replication by stimulating the transcription of viral RNA from the 5' long terminal repeat.
  • A high fraction of the leukaemias expresses the transcription factor Fox P3, a marker of regulatory T cells (Tregs) that act to suppress immune responses.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of cyclosporine?

choices.text: Blockade of tissue responses to inflammatory mediators
Inhibition of gene transcription of interleukins

questions.solution:
Option C: Inhibition of gene transcription of interleukins

  • This is a case of end-stage renal disease in which the patient presents to the nephrology ward for a renal transplant.
  • The main mechanism of action is the inhibition of the production of cytokines involved in the regulation of T-cell activation. In particular, cyclosporine inhibits the transcription of interleukin 2
  • Cyclosporine forms a complex with cyclophilin, a cytoplasmic-receptor protein present in target cells.
  • This complex binds to calcineurin, inhibiting Ca2+-stimulated dephosphorylation of the cytosolic component of NFAT.
  • When cytoplasmic NFAT is dephosphorylated, it translocates to the nucleus and complexes with nuclear components required for complete T-cell activation, including transactivation of IL-2 and other lymphokine genes.
  • Calcineurin phosphatase activity is inhibited after physical interaction with the cyclosporine/cyclophilin complex.

Option A: Activation of NK cells

  • Natural killer cells are lymphocytes that play an important role in the early response to infection or malignant transformation.
  • Under these conditions, these cells are activated and promote target cell death through the release of cytolytic granules.
  • Furthermore, they secrete cytokines that regulate the functions of other immune cells.

Option B: Blockade of tissue responses to inflammatory mediators

  • The inflammatory response is an important aspect of the tissue's responses to damaging inflammatory particles.
  • This complex response involves leukocyte cells such as macrophages, neutrophils, and lymphocytes.
  • In response to the inflammatory process, these cells release certain substances, which include vasoactive amines and peptides, eicosanoids, proinflammatory cytokines, and acute-phase reactants, which mediate the inflammatory process by preventing further tissue damage and ultimately resulting in the restoration of the cell activity.

Option D: Interference with antigen recognition

  • Cyclosporine works by inhibiting the gene transcription of the interleukins and not by interfering with antigen recognition.
  • Antigen recognition by T cells is a complex process mediated by the T cell receptors.
  • Antigen recognition by T cells is important for activating the adaptive immune response. This is mediated by T cell receptors expressed on the surface of T cells.
  • Few viruses block the presentation of endogenous antigens by antigen-presenting cells by expressing their viral proteins.

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 30-year-old, 40 weeks pregnant woman is brought to the hospital with lower abdominal pain. She is taken to the labour room for normal vaginal delivery. She delivers a baby of 3kg. The APGAR score of the baby is 8 after 5 minutes of the delivery. Which of the following is the normal growth pattern of eye development?

choices.text: A 4 mm decrease in axial length in the first 6 months of life
A corneal diameter of 5 mm at birth, 8 mm by age 2
A decrease in corneal power in the first 6 months
Anteroposterior diameter of the eyeball is about 12 mm at birth

questions.solution:
Option C: A decrease in corneal power in the first 6 months

  • The average corneal power at birth is 47.5 D, decreasing gradually to the adult value of 42.5 D.

  • Thus the corneal power decreases in the first 6 months.

Development of cornea:

  • This is derived from three embryological sources:

  1. Surface ectoderm: makes up the external corneal epithelium.

  2. Mesoderm: connective tissue which is continuous with the sclera.

  3. Neural crest cells: these travel along the rim of the optic cup along with development and differentiate into the corneal endothelium. It is multi-layered, avascular, and transparent.

Option A: A 4 mm decrease in axial length in the first 6 months of life

  • Initially, axial length increases rapidly: from a mean of 5.1–16.2 mm in week 12 to week 37 gestational age.

  • From 38 weeks, the growth rate decreases from 16.2 mm to a mean of 21.8 mm at 3 years old.
  • Male infants have a larger average axial length than females at birth; the difference is 0.24 mm
  • The axial length increases in the first 6 months of the life.

Option B: A corneal diameter of 5 mm at birth, 8mm by age 2

  • The corneal diameter is about 10 mm at birth.

  • Adult size (11.7 mm) is attained by 2 years of age.

Option D: Anteroposterior diameter of the eyeball is about 12 mm at birth

  • The anteroposterior diameter of the eyeball is about 16.5 mm at birth.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida in her 2nd trimester presented to the hospital to take her Tt dose. Which of the following is true regarding Tt dose(s) in Pregnancy?

choices.text: 1st dose early in pregnancy, 2nd dose 4 weeks after 1st dose

questions.solution:
Option D: 1st dose early in pregnancy, 2nd dose 4 weeks after 1st dose

Td in pregnancy:

  • The primary level of prevention (specific protection).
  • Primigravida: 2 doses (1 month apart) of Td
    • 1st dose early in pregnancy and, 2nd dose 4 weeks after the 1st dose.
  • If the subsequent pregnancy occurs in 3 years of the previous pregnancy and 2 Td doses were received:
    • Only 1 booster dose is required.

Other options

Option A: 1 dose in 2nd Trimester

  • The 1st dose is given early in the pregnancy.

Option B: 3 doses (1 month apart) 2nd Trimester

  • This option is incorrect

Option C: TT4 2 years after 3rd dose

  • This option is incorrect

questions.text: A 30-year-old female came to the OPD with complaints of pruritus and jaundice. On further evaluation patient was found to have an elevated bilirubin level (direct > indirect), alkaline phosphatase levels, and gamma-glutamyl transferase levels. On further evaluation, the patient was found to have a choledochal cyst in the common bile duct. A choledochal cyst is characterised by which of the following?

choices.text: Most commonly used classification system is the Todani modification of the Alonso-Lej classification
Most common type of choledochal cyst is Type III
Treatment of choice is conservative monitoring
Characterised by a triad of abdominal pain, mass, and continuous jaundice

questions.solution:
Option A: Most commonly used classification system is the Todani modification of the Alonso-Lej classification.

  • Choledochal cyst
    • Choledochal cysts are congenital dilatations of the intra and/or extrahepatic biliary system. 
    • Anomalous pancreaticobiliary junction (long common channel >1.5 cm) may play a role in pathogenesis.
    • They affect females more than males.
    • The most commonly used classification system is the Todani modification of the Alonso-Lej classification.
    • Clinical features: Mass + Pain + Jaundice 

Option B: Most common type of choledochal cyst is Type III

  • Type I cysts are the most common and have the highest risk of malignancy (>60%)

Option C: Treatment of choice is conservative monitoring

  • They also have an increased risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma, with the risk varying directly with age at diagnosis.
  • Ultrasonography will confirm the presence of an abnormal cyst, and magnetic resonance imaging (MRCP/MRI) will reveal the anatomy.
  • Radical excision of the cyst is the treatment of choice with a reconstruction of the biliary tract using a Roux-en-Y loop of the jejunum.

Option D: Characterised by a triad of abdominal pain, mass, and continuous jaundice

  • Patients may present at any age with the triad of intermittent jaundice, abdominal pain and a right upper quadrant mass on examination.

questions.text: What is type IIIA in the Nyhus classification of hernias?
questions.solution:
Option A: Direct inguinal hernias

  • Above mentioned case has clinical features consistent with direct inguinal hernia, and it is a Type IIIA hernia according to the Nyhus classification system.
  • Nyhus classification categorizes hernia defects by size, location, and type.
Nyhus classification system
Type I Indirect hernia; internal ring normal: typically, in infants, children, and young adults.
Type II Indirect hernia: internal ring enlarged without impingement on the floor of the inguinal canal: does not extend to be scrotum.
Type IIIA Direct hernia (size is not taken into account).
Type IIIB Indirect hernia enlarged enough to infringe upon the posterior inguinal wall; indirect sliding or scrotal hernias and pantaloon hernias.
Type IIIC Femoral hernia
Type IV A Direct recurrent hernia
Type IV B Indirect recurrent hernia
Type IV C Femoral recurrent hernia
Type IV D Combined recurrent hernia

Option B: Indirect inguinal hernia

  • Indirect inguinal hernia is Type II.
  • The internal ring is enlarged without impingement on the inguinal canal floor: It does not extend to the scrotum.
  • Type IIIB Indirect hernias are hernias that have enlarged enough to infringe upon the posterior inguinal wall, indirect sliding or scrotal hernias, and pantaloon hernias.

Option C: Femoral hernia

  • Femoral hernia is classified as type IIIC

Option D: Femoral recurrent hernia

  • A recurrent femoral hernia is of type IV C.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female with a toxic nodular goiter undergoes total thyroidectomy after achieving a euthyroid state. Postoperatively, she complains of a change in voice. Which of the following is the most common nerve injury during thyroidectomy?
questions.solution:
Option A: External laryngeal nerve

  • The case mentioned above underwent thyroidectomy for a toxic nodular goitre and complains of hoarseness of voice. Postoperatively, the most common nerve injured in this case would be the external laryngeal nerve.
  • Total thyroidectomy is a procedure in which the whole of the thyroid gland is removed due to certain thyroid conditions such as cancer or hyperactive thyroid gland, e.g., Graves’ disease or multinodular toxic goitre.
  • Complications of thyroidectomy:
    • Nerve injuries
      • The most common injured nerve is the External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (aka External laryngeal nerve) due to its proximity to the superior thyroid artery.
      • Leads to a loss of tension in the vocal cord with diminished power and range in the voice.
      • Recurrent laryngeal nerve - may be unilateral or bilateral, transient or permanent.
      • Cervical sympathetic trunk.

Option B: Recurrent laryngeal nerve

  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) can be damaged during thyroidectomy, but it may be unilateral or bilateral.
  • It could be transient or permanent damage of RLN, but the most common nerve injured during thyroidectomy is the external laryngeal nerve.

Option C: Vagus nerve

  • The Vagus nerve is damaged in gastroparesis.
  • It is unlikely to get damaged during thyroidectomy.

Option D: Facial Nerve

  • The facial nerve is damaged in the case of Bell's palsy.
  • It is unlikely to get damaged during thyroidectomy as the external laryngeal nerve is the most common nerve to get injured during the procedure.

questions.text: A community medicine intern was given a case of Acrodermatitis enteropathica and was asked to explain its features. Which of the following is the correct statement regarding this condition?

choices.text: Inherited disorder of excessive excretion of zinc from body
Inherited disorder of impaired uptake of zinc from body
Inherited disorder of impaired excretion of copper from body
Inherited disorder of impaired uptake of copper from body

questions.solution:
Option B: Inherited disorder of impaired uptake of zinc from body

  • Acrodermatitis enteropathica is an Inherited disorder of impaired uptake of zinc from the body.

Acrodermatitis enteropathica:

  • Acrodermatitis enteropathica is an Inherited disorder of impaired uptake of zinc from the body.
  • Acrodermatitis enteropathica results from mutations in the zinc transporter gene SLC39A4, leading to improper enteral zinc absorption.

Option A: Inherited disorder of excessive excretion of zinc from body

  • Acrodermatitis enteropathica is an Inherited disorder of impaired Absorption of zinc from the body.
  • Therefore, this is an incorrect choice.

Option C: Inherited disorder of impaired excretion of copper from body

  • Wilson disease is due to impaired excretion of copper, which can lead to the accumulation of copper in the body.

Option D: Inherited disorder of impaired uptake of copper from body

  • Menke's disease is an inherited disorder affecting the absorption of copper.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with mild foot pain. During examination, pain is experienced while everting and inverting the foot. Which joint is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Subtalar joint

  • The patient is most likely suffering from osteoarthritis.
  • Osteoarthritis is the inflammation of joints in which the patient typically presents with joint pain.
  • The pain worsens in the morning and mildly resolves as the day progresses.
  • Inversion and eversion is turning the whole sole inward & outward, respectively.
  • It occurs at the subtalar joint [talocalcaneal joint].
  • It is a plane synovial joint between a large posterior calcaneal facet on the inferior surface of the talus & corresponding posterior talar facet on the superior surface of the calcaneus.

Option B: Tibiotalar joint

  • The tibiotalar joint is also known as the ankle joint.
  • The joint is between the distal tibial and fibula of the talus
  • The movement is plantarflexion and dorsiflexion

Option C: Inferior tibiofibular joint

  • It is a syndesmosis
  • It allows only slight movement
  • It is a complex fibrous joint
  • Tibio-fibular joint
    • Slightly mobile joint
    • Fibrous joint
    • Desmos fiber

Option D: Tarso-metatarsal joint

  • Tarso-metatarsal joint-Adduction-abduction.

questions.text: Which of the following substrates is used for the synthesis of cAMP?
questions.solution:
Option C: ATP

  • cAMP - It consists of adenine, ribose, and phosphate.
  • The membrane-bound enzyme Adenylate cyclase converts ATP to cAMP by cyclization.
  • Insulin will always decrease cAMP, and glucagon will increase its synthesis.
  • cAMP is hydrolyzed by phosphodiesterase to 5' AMP.
  • cAMP is responsible for activating protein kinases by phosphorylation.
  • The hormones which use cAMP as a second messenger are called group IIa hormones, such as Glucagon, LH, FSH, hCG, Calcitonin, Catecholamines

 

 

Option A: ADP

  • 2 molecules of ADP can join to form one molecule of ATP and one molecule of AMP in a reaction catalyzed by adenylate kinase. This reaction is reversible and is necessary to maintain the required level of ADP in the cell.

Option B: GTP

  • Nucleotide GTP gives rise to secondary messenger cGMP by enzyme guanylate cyclase. The hormones which use cGMP as a second messenger are called group IIb hormones. It has a role in the visual cycle, vasodilator effects by NO (nitric oxide), and activation of peptide hormones like ANP and BNP (atrial and brain natriuretic peptides).

Option D: TTP

  • Deoxythymidine triphosphate (dTTP) is one of the four nucleoside triphosphates that are used in the in vivo synthesis of DNA.

questions.text: A 36 years old woman has not had menses for the last 4 months. A pregnancy test is negative. USG pelvis showed no significant abnormality. On per vaginal examination, no abnormality was detected, and the patient is a non-smoker and not using tobacco and illicit drugs. On laboratory evaluation, serum levels of LH & FSH were raised. Serum estradiol level was low. These findings are suggestive of which the following condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Premature menopause

The woman has presented with secondary amenorrhea with raised LH, FSH and low estrogen, which are suggestive of menopause. Menopause occuring at 40 years or less is known as premature menopause.

Menopause is characterised by: 

  • ↑ FSH level
  • ↑ FSH/LH ratio
  • Low E2 level

This patient has raised both LH and FSH, with FSH being higher than LH leading to premature menopause

 

Option A: Bilateral tubal obstruction

  • Bilateral tubal obstruction usually interferes with fertility, but the hormonal profile may be normal or with slight variation but does not cause amenorrhea.

 

Option B: PCOD

  • PCOD shows a reversal of LH: FSH ratio, 2:1 or 3:1; however, this patient does not show any history of cystic ovarian disorder.

 

Option D: Exogenous estrogen administration

  • Exogenous estrogen administration does not cause amenorrhea and is associated with low FSH and high estrogen

questions.text: A community medicine intern was given Crude Birth rate for a sub-center as 20. What the number of pregnant woman registered in sub-center?
questions.solution:
Option D: 60

Crude birth rate is the annual number of live births per 1,000 population.

  • Population of a sub-centre = 5000
  • Crude birth rate = 20 per 1000 mid-year population

Therefore, no. of births = 20/1000 x 5000 = 100

  • Pregnancy wastage factor = 10% (i.e., not all pregnancies result in a live birth, and roughly 10% ANC women have a “wastage” of their pregnancy.
  • Therefore, total ANC = 100+ (10/100 X 100) = 110
  • As a thumb rule, Minimum number of ANC that should be registered at a time = 50%.

Minimum Number registered in the sub-centre = 110 x 50/100 = 55~60

Learning Objective

  • Crude birth rate is the annual number of live births per 1,000 population.
  • Pregnancy wastage factor 10%, because not all pregnancies result in a live birth, and roughly 10% ANC women have a “wastage” of their pregnancy.
  • Minimum number of ANC that should be registered at a time 50%.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida presents to the emergency department at 36 weeks of gestation with spontaneous onset of labor pain. On examination, her vitals are stable, and the fetus's heart rate remains stable at 160 bpm. Further examination revealed a non-tender abdomen, and 3 contractions every 10 minutes were noted. Cervical dilatation is 6 cm. Examination findings are consistent with which stage of labor?
questions.solution:
Option A: First stage

  • There are 4 stages of labour: first, second, third and fourth.
  • The first stage of labour starts from the onset of true labour pain to full cervical dilatation, i.e. 10cm 
  • In the above question, cervical dilatation is 6 cm which is consistent with 1st stage of labour.

 

Stages of labour:

  • The first stage of labour: 
  • It starts from the onset of true labour pain to full dilatation of the cervix, i.e.10cm. The first stage is further divided into:
  • Latent phase:
  • Cervical dilatation ≤ 3 cm
  • Irregular uterine contractions. 
  • Tocolytics in preterm labour is given only in this phase. 
  • Active phase:
  • Cervical dilatation ≥ 4 cm up>
  • Tocolytics in preterm labour cannot be given in the active phase.
  • Second stage:
  • Stage of labour from full cervical dilatation, i.e. 10cm, to delivery of the baby. 
  • Third stage: 
  • The period from delivery of baby to placental delivery. 
  • Fourth stage: 
  • An observation period of 1-2 hours after delivery of the placenta.

 

Option B: Second stage 

  • This stage  refers to the period from full dilatation of the cervix to delivery of the baby.

 

Option C: Third stage 

  • The third stage of labour begins with the delivery of the baby and ends with the delivery of the placenta and membranes. 

 

Option D: Fourth stage 

  • The fourth stage is the observation time for 1-2 hours after delivery of the placenta

questions.text:
A 28-year-old male presents to a clinic with multiple lesions on the back of his scalp. Physical examination reveals purulent discharge oozing out of the lesions. The physician suspects furunculosis and orders the pus to be sent for culture and sensitivity analysis. Based on the patient's medical history, the microbiologist decides to perform gram stain for this sample. What is the correct sequential arrangement of a gram stain?

 

a. Mordant- Iodine Treatment

b. Safranin

c. Crystal Violet

d. Alcohol Wash
questions.solution:
Option C: c → a → d → b

  • The Gram stain is used to differentiate different types of bacteria based on the biochemical properties of their cell walls.
  • Performing a Gram stain consists of the following steps:
    • A heat-fixed smear of processed clinical specimens or bacterial culture is prepared on a glass slide. 
    • Primary stain (crystal violet) is applied to the slide and rinsed with water.
    • The slide is immersed in mordant (Gram’s iodine)
    • Rapid decolourization is performed with acetone or alcohol just for a few seconds.
    • This is then counterstained with safranin, basic fuchsin, or neutral red.
  • Therefore, the correct sequential arrangement of a gram stain is crystal violet → mordant-iodine treatment → alcohol wash → safranin.

Option A: a → b → c → d

  • It is not the correct sequential arrangement of gram staining.
    • The correct sequence arrangement is crystal violet → mordant - iodine treatment → alcohol wash → safranin.

Option B: b → c → a → d

  • It is not the correct sequential arrangement of gram staining.
    • Counterstaining with safranin is the last step in gram staining, and one can't start with it.

Option D: b → a → d → c

  • It is not the correct sequential arrangement of gram staining.
    • Gram staining starts with the application of crystal violet stain, which becomes the last step as per this sequence.

questions.text: A woman at 26 weeks gets an ultrasound done for fetal well-being and is diagnosed with hydrops fetalis. Which of the following fetal infections could have led to this condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Parvovirus B19
Hydrops fetalis -

  • Excessive destruction of the fetal red cells leads to severe anaemia, tissue anoxemia and metabolic acidosis
  • It is an accumulation of fluid in the body of the fetus in two out of three compartments: ascites, pleural effusion, pericardial effusion

  • The most common cause of immune hydrops fetalis - Rh incompatibility
  • Other causes of hydrops fetalis
  • Cardiovascular cause – Congenital heart block ( Most common)
  • Chromosomal cause – Turner syndrome (45 XO ), Triploidy, Trisomes 21,18 and 13
  • Hematological → α 4 – thalassemia, Fetomaternal haemorrhage
  • Infections → Parvovirus B19(mc), Syphilis, Cytomegalovirus, Toxoplasmosis, Rubella, HSV

Option A: Ebstein Barr virus

  • EBV is not associated with hydrop fetalis.
  • It is associated with infectious mononucleosis and nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  • It is also associated with primary CNS lymphoma in immunocompromised patients.

Option B: Human papilloma virus

  • It is not associated with hydrop fetalis.
  • HPV causes cervical carcinoma and laryngeal papillomatosis.

Option D: Influenza Virus

  • The influenza virus causes pneumonia and upper respiratory tract infections.
  • It is not associated with hydrop fetalis

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents to the eye clinic after being struck above the right eyebrow with a large fluorescent light bulb. The general physical examination is unremarkable. On ocular examination, there is no perforation. The only notable sign is hyphema. He is vitally stable otherwise. What is the most likely source of bleeding in this case?
questions.solution:
Option B: Circulus iridis major

  • Iris is weakest at its root. Hence any blunt trauma will affect the major arterial circle.
  • In this case, Circulus iridis major is the source of bleeding.
  • Circulus iridis major is formed by anastomosis of the anterior ciliary arteries with the long posterior ciliary arteries at the ciliary body. It supplies the iris, ciliary body, and choroid.

Option A: Iris's vessels

  • About 5% of the total ocular blood flows through the iris. 
  • Iris blood vessels, derived from the major vessel circle, are contained as radial coils within tube-like formations of the stromal tissue.
  • Iris's vessels have tight junctions and lack fenestrations.
  • In the given scenario. Iris's vessels are not the source of bleeding.

Option C: Short posterior ciliary arteries

  • The short posterior ciliary arteries supply a choroid and parts of the optic nerve.
  • The two long posterior ciliary arteries supply the ciliary body and anastomose with each other, and the anterior ciliary arteries form the major arterial circle of the iris.
  • In the given scenario, short posterior ciliary arteries are not the source of bleeding.

Option D: Circulus iridis minor

  • Circulus iridis minor is the lesser arterial circle of the iris.
  • Circulus iridis minor is an arterial circle near the pupillary margin of the iris.
  • In the given scenario, Circulus iridis minor is not the source of bleeding.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the clinic complaining of unilateral and throbbing headaches. The patient also has a history of Dementia. The doctor starts the MIDAS questionnaire with the patient. Which of the following statement is correct concerning the MIDAS questionnaire?

choices.text: Useful in assessing the severity of Migraine
Useful in assessing the treatment of Migraine
Useful in assessing the disability of Migraine
Useful in assessing patients with Dementia

questions.solution:
Option D: Useful in assessing patients with Dementia

  • MMSE is used to assess patients with Dementia

Option A: Useful in assessing the severity of Migraine

  • The MIDAS questionnaire is used to assess the disability caused by Migraine

Option B: Useful in assessing the treatment of Migraine

  • The MIDAS questionnaire is used to assess the disability caused by Migraine

Option C: Useful in assessing the disability of Migraine

  • MIDAS Questionnaire is used for the assessment of disability in Migraine
  • Headache sufferers answer five questions, scoring the number of days, in the past 3 months, of activity limitations due to Migraine.
Disease Scores
Migraine Disability Assessment Score MIDAS
Screening tool for Dementia MMSE
Used for Diabetic Retinopathy study ETDRS
Used in Multiple Sclerosis EDSS

*MIDAS Questionnaire 

INSTRUCTIONS: Please answer the following questions about ALL headaches you have had over the last 3 months. Write zero if you did not do the activity in the last 3  months. 

  1. On how many days in the last 3 months did you miss work or school because of your headaches ................................. ______ days 
  2. How many days in the last 3 months was your productivity at work or school reduced by half or more because of your headaches (do not include days you counted in question 1 where you missed work of school)? ......................................................................____ days 
  3. On how many days in the last 3 months did you not do household work because of your headaches?  ............................____ days 
  4. How many days in the last 3 months was your productivity in household work reduced by half or more because of your headaches (do not include days you counted in question 3 where you did not do household work)? .................................................................____ days 
  5. On how many days in the last 3 months did you miss family, social, or leisure activities because of your headaches?  ...... ____days 
  6. On how many days in the last 3 months did you have a headache? (if a headache lasted more than one day, count each day) ............... _______ days 
  7. On a scale of 0-10, on average how painful were these headaches? (where 0 = no pain at all, and 10 = pain as bad as it can be) ............... _____ days

*Migraine Disability Assessment Score 

(Question 1-5 are used to calculate the MIDAS score)

Grade I - Minimal or infrequent Disability: 0-5

Grade II - Mild or infrequent Disability: 6-10

Grade III - Moderate Disability: 11-20

Grade IV - Severe Disability: > 20
